headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering, are your better redevelopment expansion opportunities going to be internal with the company like Pike & Rose or may they be external, like your shops in Sunset Place and CocoWalk?
componenttext: I'm just wondering, are your better redevelopment expansion opportunities going to be internal with the company like Pike & Rose or may they be external, like your shops in Sunset Place and CocoWalk?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Craig, I think that -- again as we laid out at our Investor Day, by far, the large preponderance of our investment opportunity exists in what we own and control today. And we went through that in some detail. We augment that tactically with perha
componenttext: I think, Craig, I think that -- again as we laid out at our Investor Day, by far, the large preponderance of our investment opportunity exists in what we own and control today. And we went through that in some detail. We augment that tactically with perhaps an acquisition or two. I think this past year, we found 3 strong ones in San Antonio Center, Sunset Place and CocoWalk, which really kind of filled that pipeline. But preponderance of what we're focused on and executing on, and what you see in the 8-K as we not only detailed the projects that are underway, but then began providing for you on that second page what the future pipeline is, is in real estate that we own.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Craig, and just the only thing I would add to that is, the type of acquisition we make, I think is a differentiator for us. I don't think we look at -- it's not just about buying stable shopping centers. Pike is not a shopping center. It's truly is about
componenttext: Craig, and just the only thing I would add to that is, the type of acquisition we make, I think is a differentiator for us. I don't think we look at -- it's not just about buying stable shopping centers. Pike is not a shopping center. It's truly is about looking at it with a more broad real estate point of view to be able to take advantage of the skills that we've grown and developed over the past decade or so in Massachusetts and redevelopment, and apply them to be the lens by which we look at those acquisitions. I mean, there aren't a lot of companies that are going to go take a shot on Sunset Place. But when we look at it, we may succeed or we may fail. We will see. But we handicap it in such a way, we're looking at it such a way that provides opportunity that is consistent with the skill set that we learned all the way up from Bethesda Row till today. So that's balance Jim is talking about.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, from my perspective, it's like to a rather -- you take on projects that have greater upside, and that would be outside your portfolio, I think generally, or the safer bet, picking what you have really turn properties and making them better.
componenttext: I guess, from my perspective, it's like to a rather -- you take on projects that have greater upside, and that would be outside your portfolio, I think generally, or the safer bet, picking what you have really turn properties and making them better.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know how to tell you, which way it will be. I can tell you, it will be a balance of both. And how that moves, depends on where the opportunity is. One thing we do, and I think it's important, is we truly, if you were in our investment committee me
componenttext: I don't know how to tell you, which way it will be. I can tell you, it will be a balance of both. And how that moves, depends on where the opportunity is. One thing we do, and I think it's important, is we truly, if you were in our investment committee meetings, for each of those type of opportunities, it's still capital. And as a steward of capital, where we risk adjust those returns and what we think we're going to do is the critical part of that balance. You are going to see both as we go forward. I just can't tell you whether it's 60-40, 70-30, 50-50, because that depends on the specific opportunity that comes up.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just quickly, it sounds like you have more appetite for some repurposing of anchor space. Is there a point though, where the economy gets too rough that you may be not want to take those gambles, just from a scoring perspective?
componenttext: Great. And then just quickly, it sounds like you have more appetite for some repurposing of anchor space. Is there a point though, where the economy gets too rough that you may be not want to take those gambles, just from a scoring perspective?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of course, it's funny. I was thinking about one of these 10 shopping centers that we are getting to, I mean, 10 shopping centers that Jim talked about in the core. These are shopping centers that we haven't talked much about. We've got 90 shopping centers
componenttext: Of course, it's funny. I was thinking about one of these 10 shopping centers that we are getting to, I mean, 10 shopping centers that Jim talked about in the core. These are shopping centers that we haven't talked much about. We've got 90 shopping centers. And the idea of unencumbering through restrictive anchor leases, things like Willow Lawn, Brick, Troy, Montrose, Crossroads in Chicago shows you that we -- as you say, we have that appetite. I can tell you that  Crossroads in Chicago for example, there's a Party City. The Party City before 2008, we would have done everything we can to keep them there. We would have lowered the rent, we would've done whatever was needed to do to keep the occupancy and to keep the income coming in the door. In 2016, we do that differently. We are certainly willing to play hardball on the lease terms effectively. You got to go, you got to go. Because we are much more confident with respect to where it is that we can release and what is it that we can do in terms of unencumbering the shopping center. Is there a point attached to these, of course, to the extent the economy turns around and goes the other way, we are going to feel a whole lot different about that just like we did back then. But it's not going be a overnight type of decision. You will have plenty of time and quarters for us to talk through what it is that we're doing with respect to these centers and what it is that we're -- the mantra with respect to future centers.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I could just build on that a little bit, because there is increased concern in the U.S. by the recession today or one approaching if we're not in already. I know Jim is inclined to probably make guidance that much conservative than usual, but wha
componenttext: Maybe if I could just build on that a little bit, because there is increased concern in the U.S. by the recession today or one approaching if we're not in already. I know Jim is inclined to probably make guidance that much conservative than usual, but what specifically have Don, do you think you've changed in your approach to managing the business to address the risk that might not be on the radar screens, say 6 to 12 months ago? And then maybe have you perceived any willingness of retailers to commit the space or even just certain aspects of lease terms?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, it's a good conversation. Let's start this out by --Weilminster, is on the phone I think. I'd love for him to give you a perspective of the leasing world today. And then I'm going to build on that with respect to your question, okay?
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, it's a good conversation. Let's start this out by --Weilminster, is on the phone I think. I'd love for him to give you a perspective of the leasing world today. And then I'm going to build on that with respect to your question, okay?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Jeff, my feedback on the leasing world today is that, we're cautiously opportunistic with regards to the opportunities. And that very much aligns with what we felt realty have. And this is what we see. We have best of class assets, which we see located
componenttext: So Jeff, my feedback on the leasing world today is that, we're cautiously opportunistic with regards to the opportunities. And that very much aligns with what we felt realty have. And this is what we see. We have best of class assets, which we see located on markets that really align with the retailers, desire core customer portfolio, which is incredibly important to them. They know that's our realty's commitment to deliver best in class property level operation, execution, and maintenance and are focused on delivering really best tenant mix available aligned with their ability to be successful. That puts us in the best opportunity to take advantage of the growth that retailers are pursuing. And there clearly is growth in demand from the retailers. They are just -- their outlook is just a lot more -- they are a lot more focused on finding sites that do algin with the core customer. The deals that they are doing are taking much longer. The lease negotiations are certainly more difficult. And they are a lot more selective. So we definitely see opportunity with regard to growth in retailers, and we think that they are looking in the markets where we have our real estate. So I think, from our perspective, we are set out to take advantage of what demand exist out there both on the box side as well as on the small shop segments, its down $20. I mean its very important for us as we unlever some of the restrictions in these opportunities, to take advantage of putting a new relevant box retailers that also that rising tide will allow us to really take advantage of the demand from the small shop tenants. And collectively that will make our assets much better.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me add to that, Jeff. So, your question is a great one. And to the extent this was turning into 2008, you would have a whole different perspective here in terms of what we think and what we're doing and the approach. There is not one find that we
componenttext: Yes, let me add to that, Jeff. So, your question is a great one. And to the extent this was turning into 2008, you would have a whole different perspective here in terms of what we think and what we're doing and the approach. There is not one find that we see with our discussions with our retailers, at our properties, in our locations of anything like that. Worse, it's a -- it's more of a deep breadth. And as Chris said, it's more deliberate. It's a tougher negotiation, all that. That's fine. The reality is, if you were to see or to know, if I took you for a ride over to Graham Park Plaza, which is inside the beltway in Fairfax, we've not been able to do anything with that property for a long time because of the leases in place. This is a particular point in time where we have a shop. If we think we released it to -- or kept the same anchor in and extended those existing leases, we would be losing the shot to create significant value for a decade or more. So when you overall take a look at it, I mean this is with the decision, with everything we've done, we are still 93% occupied. This is hardly, "oh my god empty out the whole place " right. But it does take a very measured and careful approach to a 10 shopping centers in particular, that we've been trying for ever to figure out a way, because demand is there to create value, but they've been encumbered by whether is an A&P lease or an old valley lease or whatever it is that a particular shopping center that was causing it to get it back. That seems like a smart approach to me. It's not all the way over on one side, or all the way over on the other. Again, it's balanced.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And may be to switch gears. Just on the Clarion joint venture, one or two questions. All else equal I would have expected that purchase, considering the cash funding to be slightly accretive to earnings, but if there is no further dispositions and guidanc
componenttext: And may be to switch gears. Just on the Clarion joint venture, one or two questions. All else equal I would have expected that purchase, considering the cash funding to be slightly accretive to earnings, but if there is no further dispositions and guidance, I guess what's restraining that possibility?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I mentioned in the call, we didn't have it factored previously in the guidance -- the sale of Courtyard Shops in Wellington, Florida. So when you factor in that asset sale plus transaction cost, generally neutral for 2016, and we do expect it to b
componenttext: Yes, as I mentioned in the call, we didn't have it factored previously in the guidance -- the sale of Courtyard Shops in Wellington, Florida. So when you factor in that asset sale plus transaction cost, generally neutral for 2016, and we do expect it to be 2x to 3x accretive in '17.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I this is the second part of that. I'm just curious, related to that, portfolio occupancy in that JV has been a little bit lower than the rest of the federal portfolio, can you just remind us, I guess how you guys think about the quality of those assets i
componenttext: I this is the second part of that. I'm just curious, related to that, portfolio occupancy in that JV has been a little bit lower than the rest of the federal portfolio, can you just remind us, I guess how you guys think about the quality of those assets in comparison to your core? And is there a future redevelopment potential there that may be isn't in your schedule today or do you see these assets as eventual sale candidate down the road?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The demographics is not good compared to the rest of the portfolio. And I wish I had a better answer for you as to it's, what can I show you today, that I would say, "Oh my God, buying out the other 70% in that portfolio is a clear home run." I don't
componenttext: Yes. The demographics is not good compared to the rest of the portfolio. And I wish I had a better answer for you as to it's, what can I show you today, that I would say, "Oh my God, buying out the other 70% in that portfolio is a clear home run." I don't have that for you today. What I do have, and again, a lot of it from management perspective in a company like this, is to say, "all right, I now have a very focused team on it." But the initial conversations that we've been having with retailers and with -- and jurisdictions that they are in, suggest that there is some good stuff to do and a couple or three of these shopping centers. And Plaza del Mercado was the first one I mentioned to you. I expect there will others. Give Mooallem and his team a little bit of time to run through this, and in the next couple of quarters, we'll have a far better roadmap for you, if you will, as to how it relates with the rest -- to the rest of the products we have.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one last question. Curious why do federal renewal PIs run so much higher than peers. I just want to expect the majority of your tenants its a costless proposition to renew. There's a little incentive or disincentive for them to leave the property, and
componenttext: And one last question. Curious why do federal renewal PIs run so much higher than peers. I just want to expect the majority of your tenants its a costless proposition to renew. There's a little incentive or disincentive for them to leave the property, and yet, your renewal PIs tend to be $8 to $9 a square-foot versus something that was less than $1 for a lot of your peers. I'm just curious what you think drives that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I have an answer. I'm not sure. One thing I would pause it here is, these shopping centers are better shopping centers in areas that where effectively the economics of the deal on a net basis make a whole lot of sense. And I suspect, in retur
componenttext: I'm not sure I have an answer. I'm not sure. One thing I would pause it here is, these shopping centers are better shopping centers in areas that where effectively the economics of the deal on a net basis make a whole lot of sense. And I suspect, in return for some of that higher rent, there is an expectation for certain small shop tenants to want more done to the space, can we get a redone bathroom, can we effectively refresh, et cetera the space. I suspect that's it, but I don't know for sure. Chris, do you have anything to add to that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd add -- all I'd add is, I think it turns [indiscernible] I think this period as Don mentioned, we did have a transaction up in Melville, where we do have an in-place tenant, where there is going to be a downsizing of GOA in one area of the store t
componenttext: Yes. I'd add -- all I'd add is, I think it turns [indiscernible] I think this period as Don mentioned, we did have a transaction up in Melville, where we do have an in-place tenant, where there is going to be a downsizing of GOA in one area of the store to bring another one of their brands in. So that is the Dicks deal that was mentioned. And so a lot of it has to do with our making sure maximizing the opportunity within the space. Whether that's an expansion or shrinking and/or really is an improvements to some of the infrastructure that we see going beyond just the tenant. And so we are very proactive in analyzing every single step available to make sure that we're getting the best out of each space. When you think about the amount of our portfolio of 100-plus assets, we've got to squeeze every bit of juice out of each one of them. And so we do analyze them. And that's how I think you will see the variation, but I think when you get into defining why on each deal we made these decisions, as Don mentioned in our investment committee. And we do analyze them thoroughly, I hope that helps, Don.

componenttext: Certainly some of that, but much more. This is a much more efficient building. The outside of the building that we were building is no different. componenttext: Frankly, I couldn't feel better. I mean, if there's -- we've spent a whole lot of time over the last two years working exactly what you're talking about, Jason, putting comp arrangements into place to make sure that we're doing the best we can to retain. The key with Federal has always been, from our perspective, you can get the best and the brightest, if you give them the autonomy and you give them the leash to be able to run their businesses. That's effectively what it is it that -- how we are set up. You can have a couple of cocktails with any one of them to get their point of view that way. But I feel real good about not only choices that we'll have for succession down the road, but also the ability to execute our -- this business plan that we've been pretty articulate about.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question for me. If you could, maybe just contrast tenant health from 3 or 4 years ago versus today. It's obviously a Darwinian business, and you're always replacing weak tenants with stronger tenants. But just overall, kind of state o
componenttext: Okay. And then last question for me. If you could, maybe just contrast tenant health from 3 or 4 years ago versus today. It's obviously a Darwinian business, and you're always replacing weak tenants with stronger tenants. But just overall, kind of state of the retailer space, do you feel better today than you did 3 or 4 years ago, relative to your tenants? Or is it -- there's a little softness that's developing with some of these bankrupt --

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason, I do have a very specific point of view with respect to this. I mean 3 or 4 years ago, just coming out of the recession, you're nervous. You're nervous with respect to what the -- what those tenants' business plans are going to be? How they're
componenttext: Yes, Jason, I do have a very specific point of view with respect to this. I mean 3 or 4 years ago, just coming out of the recession, you're nervous. You're nervous with respect to what the -- what those tenants' business plans are going to be? How they're going to work in the new world? Are the cuts that they made in their staffing, gut their organizations, with respect to being able to do all that? And what had happened, and it's predictable, if you kind of take a look at it, is if you could be in every boardroom of all those major retailers and smaller retailers along the way, you would, some of them, with respect to what they changed and where they are moving, into a new economy, became extremely good at it and got stronger. A lot of them kind of found mediocrity. And the success of certain areas, not in other areas, but with an improving economy, they held on, they held on, they held on. There's only so long you can hold on, if your business plan is not effectively resonating. And I do think that what we saw, and we felt it in '15, not normal for what we're talking about for '16, was that those tenants that simply did not have business plans that resonated with consumers going forward, were not going to be able to hold on indefinitely. We started to see that in the second half of '15, we decided then to specifically aggressively target them. We don't turn that on and off and there's a continuation of that into '16. But the better tenants, there are better tenants, and those better tenants are doing very well. There's more of a bifurcation, is what I am saying, between good and not so good, today, then there was 3 or 4 years ago. That's the distinction. And that's why, I guess, I'm talking my own book here, but it's what I believe. That's why the bifurcation between desirable real estate and not desirable real estate is wider than it certainly was 3 or 4 years ago. Those things work in tandem. And that's why we're probably a bit more optimistic with respect to our leasing and this strategy in '16 and '17, than some others are.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: Jason, I do believe that. But I believe that for only the better portfolios. I don't believe that across the board, 3 years ago or 4 years ago, that's across-the-board. Didn't matter. Today it matters.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a question for Chris Weilminster, but you mentioned the broad strength you're seeing on the leasing front, both from anchors and in line, and you talked at length early about being still optimistic about the retail environment. So I'm just wondering
componenttext: Maybe a question for Chris Weilminster, but you mentioned the broad strength you're seeing on the leasing front, both from anchors and in line, and you talked at length early about being still optimistic about the retail environment. So I'm just wondering if you could give us some more specifics or color on where demand is coming from, on both the shop and the box side?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, sure. I can, I'll say that the shop goods retailers, Nordstrom Rack, has made announcements about their growth plans. So there is lot of demand out from the boxes in that category, Rack, TJX, you talk what's going on with HPC in their growth expecta
componenttext: Well, sure. I can, I'll say that the shop goods retailers, Nordstrom Rack, has made announcements about their growth plans. So there is lot of demand out from the boxes in that category, Rack, TJX, you talk what's going on with HPC in their growth expectations. I think for Saks, be it Saks OFF 5TH brand, I think they're rolling out or talking about some brands as it relates to Lord & Taylor. I think that clearly is a box component that is looking for opportunity. We see the grocery category looking to get more nimble, and do more urban oriented stores or smaller. I think there's a new concept out by Ahold called bfresh, which is taking some of what they've learned over in the European market about providing more deliverables on home meal replacement and working the environment. That clearly provides opportunity. And then the QSR business, as we've been talking about for a long time on the smaller shop side, really continues to just amaze at how they're kind of gutting out the mid-tier casual dining category, and providing as quite, with high-quality products, more curated by the consumer in a faster environment. That's the just the low-hanging fruit, but that energy, certainly are -- in those types of retailers, the ones that we clearly see taking advantage of as we re-lease opportunities within our portfolio.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeremy, the other thing you got to keep your eye on, which I think is a real positive for the open air space is, there is -- there are certainly more women's apparel tenants that are considering open air versus, or developing new concepts for open air ver
componenttext: Jeremy, the other thing you got to keep your eye on, which I think is a real positive for the open air space is, there is -- there are certainly more women's apparel tenants that are considering open air versus, or developing new concepts for open air versus just malls. I mean, we did a couple of LemonPop deals over the past few quarters. One in  Melville Mall, that, I just love how it's performing, one in Ellisburg, that was good. And so, kind of -- those retailers' open-mindedness to wear, with respect to their business plans, they can create value, I think is a real positive to the type of product that we have.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that color. And then, Don, in terms of the Sports Authorities. I know it's little early here, and hard to put a probability on, but assuming you could get those back, do any of those have the potential to lead to some bigger redevelopments here
componenttext: Appreciate that color. And then, Don, in terms of the Sports Authorities. I know it's little early here, and hard to put a probability on, but assuming you could get those back, do any of those have the potential to lead to some bigger redevelopments here, given that they're in some of your better centers?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's funny, I mean, Brick is a good one, right? We are working hard at Brick Plaza to redefine that shopping center. And one of the Sports stores is at Brick Plaza. It opened -- it's a box, big box that opens up another set of opportunities. What we'
componenttext: Yes. It's funny, I mean, Brick is a good one, right? We are working hard at Brick Plaza to redefine that shopping center. And one of the Sports stores is at Brick Plaza. It opened -- it's a box, big box that opens up another set of opportunities. What we've been doing, with respect to re-merchandising the East Bay Bridge. We would love, love to get that back, to be able to be re-merchandise it. And then, one at Assembly Square. Assembly Square, that power center is now adjacent to a pretty darn successful mixed-use project. So even though it pays a lot of rent, wouldn't mind that either. So there's -- there, when I look down through them, they can turn into -- to some real positives from a value perspective but again, short term hits.

componenttext: Okay, and then, just one last quick one for Jim here. Should we really be thinking about stabilized yield for those -- the office components of those projects, not hitting until kind of a mid-or late 2017?

componenttext: It's going to coming in at mid-'17, that's correct Jeremy. When you factor in those periods and timing, as we get those tenants moved in. Again, all that space is committed, now it's just a question of getting the tenants in the space.

componenttext: So if I think about what you guys have said during this call, it seems like no real slow down and not slowing down on taking space back and re-leasing it. But how about for bigger items, like a, I'm not sure if there is a phase 3 for some of your larger projects, but given what's going on the road, does it at all impact your decisions to embark on just larger, more heavy capital-ed projects?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are not at a point where we're at a go or no-go, with respect to the third phase of Pike & Rose, the third phase of Assembly. I can tell you, there's a lot of things we're working on. Some of which are pretty darn cool, but when we are at that point, t
componenttext: We are not at a point where we're at a go or no-go, with respect to the third phase of Pike & Rose, the third phase of Assembly. I can tell you, there's a lot of things we're working on. Some of which are pretty darn cool, but when we are at that point, the investment committee decisions, the capital allocation decisions will certainly, decisions, will certainly take into account where we are at that time in the economy, what we believe in terms of the future, and what use we're comfortable of doing and how much risk we'd like to take or offload, which we could do. So as of today, I have -- you should assume nothing different, with respect to third phases or fourth phases of those projects or anything else we're looking at. As the year plays out, as '17 plays out, and we're getting to investment committee stage, you can bet that we'll have more say about it.

The overall IRRs and the risk-adjusted nature of each of those opportunities is what we're going to consider. We're just not ready here, and [indiscernible] to go further.

componenttext: For Don or Jim, on the ten box opportunities with the 450,000 square feet plus. Just to clarify, are all these likely redevelopments, or do you expect that some or most of these will be just relit with normal CapEx? And --

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, the projects, do you expect to be in larger redevelopments. How significant of a capital investment could it be?
componenttext: I guess, the projects, do you expect to be in larger redevelopments. How significant of a capital investment could it be?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so if you were working here and we were looking at these 10 assets and spending time within the cities, in the communities that they're in, doing market studies of what's missing, not only on a retail, but potentially in excuse [ph] basis in each of
componenttext: Yes, so if you were working here and we were looking at these 10 assets and spending time within the cities, in the communities that they're in, doing market studies of what's missing, not only on a retail, but potentially in excuse [ph] basis in each of these places, you know that, you would know takes it takes a little bit of time. And the idea of figuring out what should each of these be, is where we start. We then put on the overall hat of, okay, how likely is it to get it done? Where's the balance in our business plan. If I were a betting man, and I am, I would suggest to you that, that half of these would be re-leasing, a couple of them would be minor redevelopments, and a couple of them would be larger redevelopments. I can't give you a capital number, because I'm just guessing at what I'm saying. But that's the point. What I'm trying to do for you is to give you the process that we're going to go through to make sure that this, I don't want to say once-in-a-lifetime, but once in a decade opportunity of having encumbered sections of real estate, gets viewed very thoroughly, and then we don't just slap in an inferior tenant in order to get ultimately your same-store growth back.

componenttext: I think that's right. But by and large, you'll see it in '17 forwards.

componenttext: That's helpful, and last one for me. Jim, any comments on, where I guess, he -- can you remind us how much common equity is implied in the guidance range? And I guess, just given some of the uncertainty in the world, and your funding needs in the current pipeline, any thoughts on kind of an overnight vis--vis the ATM issuance?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Part of the reason we have the balance sheet we do, is to always have maximum flexibility towards never being in a position to have to raise a particular type of capital at a particular point in time. And that's something that we really work hard to prote
componenttext: Part of the reason we have the balance sheet we do, is to always have maximum flexibility towards never being in a position to have to raise a particular type of capital at a particular point in time. And that's something that we really work hard to protect and preserve. As we look at overall equity needs for the year, probably in the neighborhood of 200 to 250. But again,, we'd have the flexibility to do it through our ATM, potentially an overnight, but I, it's all about making sure that we have the flexibility. And as we've been working really hard, as you can see, to make sure that as we're working through all this value creation that we've actually been prefunding a great deal of it. And you can see that when you look at our debt to EBITDA metric, which has remained low despite the fact that we have a lot of development that's not producing EBITDA yet. So that gives us a lot more flexibility if bad stuff comes on. And importantly, puts us in a position where we can fund the growth that we have underway, multiple ways.

componenttext: Wait, I can. Let me just opine there. But we're certainly very focused on the office supply category, and are already working on backfill opportunities should we get any spaces back.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know everyone's probably winding down. So a quick question, when you guys look at expanding into a new market or increasing your investment in new market, how much of that is opportunistic versus strategic? You've just expanded significantly in Miami, h
componenttext: I know everyone's probably winding down. So a quick question, when you guys look at expanding into a new market or increasing your investment in new market, how much of that is opportunistic versus strategic? You've just expanded significantly in Miami, how much of that was opportunity based, or how much of that was strategic based?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Floris, that's a strategic decision. Clearly, a strategic decision. The one thing that we got comfortable with over the years a little bit, is what it is, where were the places in this country that where logical extensions for us, that we felt very, very
componenttext: Floris, that's a strategic decision. Clearly, a strategic decision. The one thing that we got comfortable with over the years a little bit, is what it is, where were the places in this country that where logical extensions for us, that we felt very, very good about the positive changes on a macro level over the next decade or two. The more we looked at, not Florida, but Miami in particular, within Florida, the more we felt that all the investments that's happening downtown, all the investments that's happening in that market place, was not -- was what it is, but wasn't the same as what was happening where the full-time population lived. The more we looked into those areas, which included Coral Gables and included Coconut Grove, the more we got really excited about the possibilities of those being underserved places that were on a real upswing. Frankly, 6 months later or 12 months later from when we did it, and 2 years later from when we started thinking about it, we're actually more optimistic in terms of what's happening. If you look, go look hard at the press and some of the deals that have been done in and around Coconut Grove over the past, 12 to 15 months, and I think you'll say, "Oh man, maybe these guys are on to something." So that was very much a strategic decision.

componenttextpreview: Don, just maybe to summarize the conversation about where the tenant conversations are. Is it more about their feeling the pain of rents higher, than it is about their caution about store openings, is that kind of where we are with this?
componenttext: Don, just maybe to summarize the conversation about where the tenant conversations are. Is it more about their feeling the pain of rents higher, than it is about their caution about store openings, is that kind of where we are with this?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a combination. I think it's combination, Chris. When you're sitting in your -- I always try to take it to the boardrooms of any company. And in those boardrooms, are conversations about earnings growth and longer-term plans. And it's like any
componenttext: I think it's a combination. I think it's combination, Chris. When you're sitting in your -- I always try to take it to the boardrooms of any company. And in those boardrooms, are conversations about earnings growth and longer-term plans. And it's like anything else. You don't just turn things on and off unless you have crazy times like 2008. And again, there's no sign that we see of anything like that. So instead, you start tweaking all your pieces. Number of store openings, your cost structure, your product lines and store size, all of that stuff. So on a combined basis, there is about one thing that [indiscernible] when we say retailers, applying that there's this one thing out there. There are very many different business plans. And all we try to do as a company and as a business, is to be attractive to as many of them as possible. And not be tied to any one retailer, any one category within those retailers or any one geography. So when you look at that from that perspective, and you truly get back to demand versus supply on your particular real estate, that's why we're probably more optimistic than you're hearing elsewhere.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then my last question. If we circle back to sort of the very of the Q&A, and talk about the acquisition of the Clarion interest. When I think of historically about how you guys have talked about the portfolio, I think, Don, you've always talked
componenttext: Okay, and then my last question. If we circle back to sort of the very of the Q&A, and talk about the acquisition of the Clarion interest. When I think of historically about how you guys have talked about the portfolio, I think, Don, you've always talked about how proud you are of the fact that it's few assets, very highly valuable, large assets. When I look at the 6 assets that are in this portfolio, for of the most part, they tend to be at the smaller end. And they're -- and several of them don't really fit what I would consider Federal markets or micro markets. So when I think about the answer to the question, you talked about having more bandwidth. So the question that I would ask you is, is that, because of the reorganization, which -- should we expect smaller core assets to necessarily be a bigger piece of this portfolio going forward, because you have more bandwidth or how should we be thinking about this transaction?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very fair question, Chris. The answer is no, you should not be thinking that. And that this is a discrete investment decision. And when you said and specifically think about this discrete investment decision, know that we have 11 years of actual experienc
componenttext: Very fair question, Chris. The answer is no, you should not be thinking that. And that this is a discrete investment decision. And when you said and specifically think about this discrete investment decision, know that we have 11 years of actual experience in knowing how these particular assets act and not act. And all 6 of them aren't great. No question about it, from the standpoint of are they -- does one size fit all here? Not at all. But as a portfolio, with an opportunity to either sell the 30% that we did own or buy the 70% that we did not own. In this discrete transaction, we think we can make some money and add some value here. Don't take that and expand that to the company's overall business plan the way you just described, because that wouldn't be the case.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Federal Realty Investment Trust Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I'd now like to introduce your host for today's conference
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Federal Realty Investment Trust Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I'd now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Leah Andress. You may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. I would like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Jim Taylor, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster and Melissa Solis.
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. I would like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Jim Taylor, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster and Melissa Solis. They will be available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results. Also Federal Realty believes that expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions. Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations can be attained.
The earnings release and the supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. These documents are available on our website at www.federalrealty.com.
And with that, I would like to turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of our fourth quarter and year-end 2015 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank, Leah, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. Again, I certainly look forward to seeing all or most of you in a few weeks at Citi Conference in Florida, where we can talk more about our company and our industry. I also want t
componenttext:
Well, thank, Leah, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. Again, I certainly look forward to seeing all or most of you in a few weeks at Citi Conference in Florida, where we can talk more about our company and our industry. I also want to thank so many of you for the recognition and good wishes that you conveyed with the announcement of our admission into the S&P 500 late last month, it makes our whole team feel particularly proud and your nice words made it even sweeter. So thank you, all.
Now, lets talk about 2015 results and 2016 expectations, and start out by noting that FFO per share of $1.37 in the quarter and $5.32 for the year, before early extinguishment of debt costs, are both all-time records for our company and represents 7% quarterly FFO per share growth and 7.7% annual FFO per share growth.
Now, let's just put that growth into context. We always try to walk the talk when it comes to taking the long-term view on our business plan. And that includes sometimes doing things that diminish certain quarterly metrics like same-store growth and occupancy for mid and long-term value enhancement. It's why we went out on a limb a few years back, before Assembly Row opened, to lay out a plan to double our income over the next decade. That was in 2013, when we subsequently finished the year with 7% earnings growth only to follow that with 7.2% growth in 2014 and now, 7.7% growth in 2015.
If you are aware of the rule of 72, you will note that we're on or a bit ahead of schedule. So far so good. And with the first phases of the big development projects coming into their own and the second phases now underway, along with the raw material for future growth that we acquired in Miami and California lately, we are as optimistic today, if not more so, than we were back in 2013 as to our ability to double by 2023. To us, it's more important than ever to have and execute on a long-term consistent and sustainable plan that relies less on outside uncontrollable events and more on the execution within our own portfolio. We're really proud of that.
All right. So what does it mean for 2016 expectations? Well first, it means that we're planning on 6% to 7% FFO growth this year, marginally lower than where we've been, but strong nonetheless. Because of the conscious and aggressive effort that we spoke about on last quarter's call to actively create anchor vacancy by replacing weak tenants with stronger ones. And more importantly, unlocking redevelopment opportunities at a number of our larger core shopping centers, and that was before the most recent news about Sports Authority, where we have 5 locations generating $3.4 million in annual rent. All good news for the future, and providing more growth and value long before 2023, but dilutive to same-store growth and occupancy today.
Hopefully, you remember my remarks from last quarter's call that attempted to prepare investors for the impact that strategy would have on those metrics in the fourth quarter that we just reported and continuing through 2016. Well, I promised to spare you the 5-tool baseball player analogy on this call, I've heard plenty about that from you -- from most of you over the last 3 months, I do want to update you on the plan.
To recap, when we broke the company up between core and mixed-use earlier in the year, and brought in additional real estate talent to lead the core, which by the way caused a higher level of G&A. We did so, in order to ensure that the all-important core portfolio got the attention and aggressive asset management that it deserves. The objective is for the core to produce even more value and continue to act as the strongest possible foundation for the development and acquisition pipeline. In part, that means getting control of space that has long hindered value creation at certain shopping centers.
You'll remember that we spoke about the A&P bankruptcy which was the most obvious example, and we had 4: 1 A&P, 1 Pathmark, and 2 Waldbaums, all in New Jersey and Long Island. All 4 leases had significant value to multiple parties and certainly if we chose not to participate in that bankruptcy process, I'm very confident that all 4 leases would have been bought by someone, which would have resulted in 0 downtime and 0 lost rent in any of those spaces. And if our business plan were one-dimensional, we might have let that happen. But we didn't. Nearly a 185,000 square feet of space, that's nearly a full point of occupancy and over $3 million of annual same-store growth that went out the door with the bankruptcy. And by the way, we had to pay several millions of dollars to get the right to lose all that income. Our assessment is that, that several million dollar investment plus a year or more of downtime would pay back many times over, not only in terms of the 4 walls of those grocery stores, which is how a lot of people look at the lease's value, but by unlocking more redevelopment opportunities that improve the entire shopping centers. While same-store growth and occupancy were negatively impacted in the fourth quarter, and will be in 2016, the future value of these and other centers where we have employed a similar strategy will be far higher.
We are deep into exploring redevelopment plans on all of our newfound opportunities, and I'm excited about the possibilities. Jim will summarize the impacts in his remarks in a few minutes. 
Now I don't know if we could have made that decision if we didn't have a clear long-term plan and same-store growth and yearend occupancy were the only considerations. 
All right, let's back up and talk about leasing for a minute and there is plenty of it happening.
99 deals done in the quarter. 88 of them comparable for over 380,000 feet at an average rent of $31.88, 23% higher than the $26 per foot the prior tenant was paying. The leasing strength was broad with both anchor deals and small shop renewals registering double-digit growth. The tenant improvement dollars per square-foot associated with those leases requires explanation, because most of it comes from two redevelopment projects: The Saks OFF 5TH deal at our headquarter site at Congressional Plaza, and the Dicks Field & Stream deal at Melville Mall on Long Island. Capital for those deals are both included and considered in the overall return thresholds of the project, so -- but careful not to double count that capital as both leasing capital and redevelopment capital. It's one and the same. Anyway you look at it, these are strong leasing results.
In addition to the 88 comparable deals, we also executed 11 non-comparable deals, largely on the new developments, representing an additional 58,000 square feet of space. So 440,000 [ph] square feet of deals in a three-month period. There is plenty of productive leasing being done these days in virtually all markets we do business in. And, we're betting that that will continue in 2016 for our product type and our locations. And it's why we're consciously trying to get back underperforming anchor space. We want to use these favorable economic conditions to re-lease them. We see a good sampling of mediocre retailers that have been holding on for years, who have either given up: A&P, Hudson Trail, City Sports, or who will soon. We are fine with that. And as I said, are anxious to get it to either re-lease or redevelop.
So I haven't touched on acquisitions or development yet, so let me get to the highlights. Man, do we have a lot going on: from continued advancement of the construction and leasing at both Pike & Rose and Assembly; to the continued opening of more and more tenants at the very successful Point development in  El Segundo, California; to continued disciplined construction of fully leased 500 Santana Row, set to house data mining technology powerhouse Splunk by the end of this year; to the closing on October 1 of Sunset Place in South Miami, where we are aggressively working to plan -- to develop a plan to better exploit its A1 location; to the unwind of our 11-year joint venture with Clarion through the acquisition of their 70% interest in 6 shopping centers in Suburban Boston, New York, and D.C., which by the way creates more fresh powder for redevelopment.
So we've got more going on to keep our 5 growth buckets fully productive than I can remember in my 18 years here. Let me give you a few more updates on those big projects and then I will turn it over to Jim. At Pike & Rose, residential lease-up continues to progress quite well with over 40% of the building leased at Pallas, as of today, at rents that are in line or even a bit better than our underwriting. The remainder of that residential leasing will require the rest of 2016 to reach stabilization, which again is consistent with our expectations. Secondly, we are well underway on the next phase. The Phase II garage is done and open, and we've just broken ground on the 2 largest buildings in Phase II this month. It will take 2 years to get it all open with a 700-foot plus long Main Street and a sense of place long missing from Rockville Pike.
In Somerville, Massachusetts, Assembly Row continues to get better and better, with one of our biggest concerns during the second phase construction being adequate parking, since surface lots are now under construction. That's a high-class problem for the initial phase of a mixed-use project, but it's because this is already a very successful new neighborhood in the Greater Boston area it's about to get a whole lot better as partners employees begin occupying the new building by midyear '16. Very exciting progress there, which has clearly spilled over to the adjacent power center, where we hope to be making some important merchandising and economic upgrades in the next few quarters.
In San Jose, 500 Santana Row construction is progressing a bit better than we expected, in terms of both cost and, potentially, schedule, which if it holds will result in a 9% cash-on-cost yield upon stabilization. That would make Santana -- 500 Santana Row the third project in a row with Santana, residential projects Levare and Misora being the first 2, where the initial revenues exceeded our underwriting. That's not a fluke. It speaks to the big picture point about mixed-use projects done well. While the initial phases that need to create the environment are complicated and often a little less smooth than we would like, the long-term value creation through maturation and incremental development of these ambitious projects is extremely rewarding and incredibly enduring.
Similarly, at The Point in El Segundo, the successful initial tenant openings at the end last summer have continued and grown as more and more tenants have opened. A final couple of spaces are expected to be leased and opened in 2016. Again, on-time, on budget. I don't have a significant update for you today on our property acquisitions in South Florida, which are performing as planned, as we underwrote them. Our most senior team, including Don Briggs, Chris Weilminster and Dawn Becker, along with our partner, Grass River and Michael Comras, are fully immersed in redevelopment mode exploring the art of the possible with city officials, retailers and others. And that applies to both CocoWalk and Sunset. Stay tuned there.
And finally, last month we concluded a very successful 11-year shopping center joint venture with Clarion Lion Fund by acquiring their 70% interest in Atlantic Plaza and Campus Plaza in Suburban Boston, Greenlawn Plaza on Long Island, and Free State Shopping Center, Plaza del Mercado and Barcroft Plaza in suburban Washington, D.C. at what we felt was a very fair and favorable purchase price of $154 million. All of these assets are located in markets we know well, and have seen strong growth from. And we've got a number of redevelopment and releasing opportunities at these properties that our core team -- new core team is focused on. More raw material for future growth.
Okay. That's enough for me now. 2015 was a very gratifying year for us, full of not only measurable accomplishments, but as or more importantly, the solidification of a plan and structure focused on accelerated value creation throughout the second half of this decade and beyond. Thank you all for your interest and support. And I'll now turn it over to Jim, and look forward to your questions afterwards.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don and Leah, and good morning, everyone. As Don highlighted, our team delivered yet another record for the trots [ph] in terms of FFO per share, which at $1.37 represented 7% growth over the prior year quarter or 7.7% for the full year. For th
componenttext:
Thank you, Don and Leah, and good morning, everyone. As Don highlighted, our team delivered yet another record for the trots [ph] in terms of FFO per share, which at $1.37 represented 7% growth over the prior year quarter or 7.7% for the full year. For the many of you who parked at the top or just above our guidance, that $1.37 was just below the top end of our previously provided range.
In a quarter where we continued to invest in the future by intentionally taking down additional box vacancy, adding to our team, selling non-core assets and incurring transactional costs for favorable acquisition, we are particularly pleased that the bottom line results driven by our operations, leasing, acquisition and development teams. 
Turning to the numbers. Overall, property operating income grew at 5.9% over the prior year. Even with the decline in occupancy, reflecting higher anchor rollover, our core portfolio continued to be a significant driver of POI growth. That core grew at 2.6% or approximately 3.8% for the full year on a same-store basis including redevelopment.
As in prior quarters, allow me to again emphasize that our same-store pool represents approximately 94% of our total POI. In other words, it represents substantially all of our portfolio, and then truly reflects underlying core performance. This quarter, the downtime associated with the anchor rollover we discussed as well as other onetime items, produced about 150 basis points of drag. We highlighted this trend last quarter and as I will discuss further in guidance, we expect this rollover drag to begin to ameliorate in the latter part of this year, resulting in 2015 same-store NOI growth including redevelopment of approximately 3% to 3.5%. 
Allow me to pause for a moment. I can think of very few portfolios that show growth even while taking down occupancy. That speaks to the bumps embedded in our leases, several quarters of double-digit rent rollover growth and the successful delivery of our redevelopment.
Our first phases of Assembly and Pike & Rose contributed approximately $3 million of POI in the quarter, down slightly on a sequential basis as the Pallas high-rise opening and the office space deliveries triggered full operating expenses. The office lease-up is complete and tenants will continue to take occupancy through this year and early next. In addition, as Don mentioned, the lease-up at Pallas is going well, and we expect to hit a stabilized occupancy in the fourth quarter of this year. 
Finally, our acquisitions of CocoWalk and Sunset Place, which are performing well against our acquisition underwriting, also contributed significantly to our overall POI growth.
G&A remained stable at $8.1 million and interest expense declined $1 million, reflecting the lower average rate achieved through our refinancings during the year of 4.1%, offset by lower capitalized interest during the quarter as we continue to place development into service. Again, bottom line, FFO grew 7% for the quarter or 7.7% for the year.
That absolute bottom line performance while we continue to invest in the future, is something this team takes great pride in. From a balance sheet perspective, we ended the quarter with $53 million drawn under our $600 million revolver, net debt to EBITDA of 5.3x, a weighted average debt tenor of 10 years, which together provides maximum flexibility and liquidity to fund all of our growth and NAV creation underway.
Turning to guidance for 2016, we affirm the previously provided range of $5.65 to $5.71 a share. A range of growth of approximately 6% to 7% or slightly below our long-term plan. As we discussed last quarter, this is a true range that will be impacted by several variables during the year.
As Don covered in his remarks, targeted box recapture and rollover vacancy drives a significant amount of drag in the year. The targeted anchor rollover which represents approximately $6 million of downtime in the year, approximately $8 million of annualized rent is driven by 10 of our properties. The notable spaces include the A&P leases at Troy, Melville, and Brick, the former Hudson Trail space at Montrose Crossing and the former Valley space at Graham Park.
In total, the targeted anchor rollover represents approximately 465,000 square feet at some of our very best assets, where the investment in downtime this year should pay significant dividends in the future. And as Don discussed in his remarks, we are very excited about the opportunity to unlock value at these centers through redevelopment, repositioning and re-leasing. Overall, we expect to significantly exceed the prior in-place rent of approximately $13.50 a foot on these larger spaces. In short, we believe we will drive -- or deliver better retailers at better rents and significantly improve these assets.
In addition to this investment in future growth, there are several other investments in growth to consider from a timing perspective as you look at the year. I mentioned Pallas and again, we expect a stabilization of that approximately $100 million investment to occur in the fourth quarter, from an occupancy perspective. The office space at Pike & Rose and Assembly, which represents approximately $80 million of investment, is now fully committed and will continue to see rent commencing throughout the year and early next as tenants take occupancy. 
500 Santana Row, our 234,000 square foot office building that represents approximately $115 million of investment, is 100% pre-leased and will deliver late in the fourth quarter and rent commence in 2017. The Point redevelopment at Plaza, El Segundo continues to perform exceptionally well, and is expected to stabilize in the fourth quarter of this year. 
Our acquisition of our joint venture partner's 70% interest in the 6 core assets that Don discussed, is expected to be neutral to FFO this year after transaction costs and factoring in the sale of Courtyard Shops, which we completed in the fourth quarter. We do expect this acquisition to contribute approximately $0.02 to $0.03 in 2017. 
And finally, we are well underway on the second phases of Pike & Rose and Assembly that represent another $600 million of investment, and expect those phases to begin delivering in the latter part of '17 and 2018. From a capital standpoint, we expect to fund approximately $350 million of development and redevelopment with a mix of funds from operations, long-term debt and equity under our ATM. Finally, consistent with our practice, our guidance does not factor in any further acquisitions or dispositions that we may execute during the year.
Before turning the call over to questions, I'd like to introduce,  Leah Andress, our new Investor Relations associate. Leah was formerly with Phillips Realty in D.C.,  and prior to that was an analyst with FBR Capital Markets. Unfortunately, she was also a Tar Heel. We look forward to having all of you meet Leah very soon. We also look forward to seeing many of you at the Wells and Citi Conference in the next few weeks. With that operator, I'd like to now turn the call over to questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: Leah, don't be afraid to give Jim some grief back there. So a few questions here. First on the West Coast. Perhaps for Jeff, can you just give us an update of what you're seeing as you're talking to Splunk for their face [ph] as well as I think you guys are contemplating building some office across the street? And just given the headlines, curious if that's still the plan or maybe there's been some change?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex, no change to long-term development plans for Santana Row or Santana West. Obviously, before we make a capital decision, we're going to make sure we are confident that there's going to be a market there when it's time to lease the buildings. So
componenttext: Yes, Alex, no change to long-term development plans for Santana Row or Santana West. Obviously, before we make a capital decision, we're going to make sure we are confident that there's going to be a market there when it's time to lease the buildings. So no change. And as it related to Splunk, we don't have any special information about what's going on at Splunk or any of the other tech companies for that matter. But what we do see on the ground, if you will, is them being very aggressive about doing what they need to do to get into the building as soon as possible. They need the space and they need it as quickly as possible. So everything that's gone on in the last couple of weeks hasn't affected that at all.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, as far as the Clarion JV. Don, I think over the years, you've been asked numerous times about buying that in. And it always seemed like it was more of a Steady Eddie portfolio rather than something that would be more interesting to wholly
componenttext: Okay. And then, as far as the Clarion JV. Don, I think over the years, you've been asked numerous times about buying that in. And it always seemed like it was more of a Steady Eddie portfolio rather than something that would be more interesting to wholly own. So can you just provide some perspective, was this a case where a JV partner wanted to get out or perhaps, given some of the recent retailer things that have come up, maybe there's some new opportunities that made it a little more exciting for you guys to buy in now?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex. That's a very fair question. The single biggest thing, first you need both parties to want to do a deal. And from our perspective, one of the biggest things that changed was, it's all about prioritization. And so, as you know, what we did do la
componenttext: Yes, Alex. That's a very fair question. The single biggest thing, first you need both parties to want to do a deal. And from our perspective, one of the biggest things that changed was, it's all about prioritization. And so, as you know, what we did do last year, was respect [ph] of setting up the core and the way that we set up the core and kind of freeing up that team and building on that team to be able to create value in it, while taking Dawn and freeing up Chris and Briggs, over on the mixed-use side, there was more capacity. So from our perspective, I am feeling great about being able to actually get to stuff that we'd like to get to. Secondly, all that is just timing too. We've already at Plaza del Mercado for example, been able to do a deal, that was in the works last year and has been in the works for the last couple of years with respect to LA Fitness to redevelop that site. That's great news. So it's really about management attention afforded by this new reconfiguration of our company. In addition, Alex, to the timing for Clarion, who were ready to dissolve that partnership for their own reasons, and us ready to take it on.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So how much more -- what should we look for as far as upside potential? As far as with the yield where you brought and where you think it could go over the next -- from a modeling perspective...
componenttext: Okay. So how much more -- what should we look for as far as upside potential? As far as with the yield where you brought and where you think it could go over the next -- from a modeling perspective...

componenttext: Yes, I'm not going to give you a particular answer on that. I can tell you that we're working real hard -- that particularly Mooallem and his team is looking particularly hard at that portfolio. And it's Mooallem and Wendy Seher. I don't know if you know, she is a critical part of our company, Senior Vice President of Leasing just on the core, which is so important. And when we're saying just on the core, it also ties into what we're doing with respect to aggressively going after space. Having that ability to focus and move on that core, the timing is just right. So we'll give you more, and not sure whether Mooallem -- we're going to bring him down to Citi or not, but if we do or if we don't, there will be more exposure for you and folks like you to him to be able to get some of that specifics -- those specifics as we get closer.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
