componenttext: Okay. Well, I have to look for Christy [ph] to fill me in on what you guys say down at the Citi Conference.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering, are your better redevelopment expansion opportunities going to be internal with the company like Pike & Rose or may they be external, like your Shops at Sunset Place and CocoWalk?
componenttext: I'm just wondering, are your better redevelopment expansion opportunities going to be internal with the company like Pike & Rose or may they be external, like your Shops at Sunset Place and CocoWalk?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Craig, I think that -- again as we laid out at our Investor Day, by far, the large preponderance of our investment opportunity exists in what we own and control today. And we went through that in some detail. We augment that tactically with perha
componenttext: I think, Craig, I think that -- again as we laid out at our Investor Day, by far, the large preponderance of our investment opportunity exists in what we own and control today. And we went through that in some detail. We augment that tactically with perhaps an acquisition or two. I think this past year, we found 3 strong ones in San Antonio Center, Sunset Place and CocoWalk, which really kind of fill that pipeline. But the preponderance of what we're focused on and executing on, and what you see in the 8-K as we not only detail the projects that are underway, but then begin providing for you on that second page what the future pipeline is, is in real estate that we own.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Craig, I guess the only thing I would add to that is the type of acquisition we make, I think is a differentiator for us. I don't think we look at -- it's not just about buying stable shopping centers. Pike is not about buying stable shopping centers. It
componenttext: Craig, I guess the only thing I would add to that is the type of acquisition we make, I think is a differentiator for us. I don't think we look at -- it's not just about buying stable shopping centers. Pike is not about buying stable shopping centers. It truly is about looking at it with a more broad real estate point of view to be able to take advantage of the skill set that we've grown and developed over the past decade or so in mixed-use and redevelopment, and apply them to the lens by which we look at those acquisitions. I mean, there aren't a lot of companies that are going to go take a shot on Sunset Place. But when we look at it, we may succeed or we may fail. We'll see. But we handicap it in such a way, we're looking at it such a way that provides opportunity that is consistent with the skill set that we learned all the way up from Bethesda Row till today. So that's the balance Jim is talking about.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, from my perspective, it's like do I rather see you take on projects that have greater upside, and that would be outside your portfolio, I think generally, or the safer bet, picking what you have, really strong properties and making them better.
componenttext: I guess, from my perspective, it's like do I rather see you take on projects that have greater upside, and that would be outside your portfolio, I think generally, or the safer bet, picking what you have, really strong properties and making them better.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know how to tell you, which way it will be. I can tell you, it will be a balance of both. And how that moves, depends on where the opportunity is. One thing we do, and I think it's important, is we truly -- if you were in our investment committee
componenttext: I don't know how to tell you, which way it will be. I can tell you, it will be a balance of both. And how that moves, depends on where the opportunity is. One thing we do, and I think it's important, is we truly -- if you were in our investment committee meetings, for each of those type of opportunities, it's still capital. And as the steward of capital, where we risk adjust those returns and what we think we're going to do is the critical part of that balance. You are going to see both as we go forward. I just can't tell you whether it's 60-40, 70-30, 50-50, because that depends on the specific opportunity that comes up.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just quickly, it sounds like you have more appetite for some repurposing of anchor space. Is there a point though, where the economy gets too rough that you maybe not want to take those gambles, just from a timing perspective?
componenttext: Great. And then just quickly, it sounds like you have more appetite for some repurposing of anchor space. Is there a point though, where the economy gets too rough that you maybe not want to take those gambles, just from a timing perspective?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of course there is. It's funny, I was thinking about it, one of these 10 shopping centers that we are getting to, I mean, 10 shopping centers that Jim talked about in the core. These are shopping centers that we haven't talked much about. We've got 90 sho
componenttext: Of course there is. It's funny, I was thinking about it, one of these 10 shopping centers that we are getting to, I mean, 10 shopping centers that Jim talked about in the core. These are shopping centers that we haven't talked much about. We've got 90 shopping centers. And the idea of unencumbering, through restrictive anchor leases, things like Willow Lawn, Brick, Troy, Montrose, Crossroads in Chicago shows you that we -- as we say, we have that appetite. I can tell you at Crossroads in Chicago for example, there's a Party City. The Party City -- if this were 2008, we would have done everything we can to keep them there. We would have lowered the rent, we would've done whatever was needed to do to keep the occupancy and to keep the income coming in the door. In 2016, we view that differently. We are certainly willing to play hardball on the lease terms effectively. You got to go, you got to go. Because we are much more confident with respect to where it is that we can re-lease and what is it that we can do in terms of unencumbering the shopping center. Is there a point that, that changes, of course, to the extent the economy turns around and goes the other way, we are going to feel a whole lot different about that just like we did back then. But it's not going be an overnight type of decision. You will have plenty of time and quarters for us to talk through what it is that we're doing with respect to these centers and what it is that we're -- the mantra with respect to future centers.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I could just build on that a little bit, because there is increased concern in the U.S. about a recession today or one approaching, if we're not in it already. I know Jim is inclined to probably make guidance that much conservative than usual, bu
componenttext: Maybe if I could just build on that a little bit, because there is increased concern in the U.S. about a recession today or one approaching, if we're not in it already. I know Jim is inclined to probably make guidance that much conservative than usual, but what specifically have, Don, do you think you've changed in your approach to managing the business to address risks that might not be on the radar screens, say 6 to 12 months ago? And then maybe have you perceived any change in the willingness of retailers to commit to space or even just certain aspects of lease terms?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, that's a good conversation. Let's start this out by --Weilminster, is on the phone I think. I'd love for him to give you a perspective of the leasing world today. And then I'm going to build on that with respect to your question, okay?
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, that's a good conversation. Let's start this out by --Weilminster, is on the phone I think. I'd love for him to give you a perspective of the leasing world today. And then I'm going to build on that with respect to your question, okay?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Jeff, my feedback on the leasing world today is that, we're cautiously opportunistic with regards to the opportunities. And that very much aligns with what we at Federal Realty have. And this is what we see. We have best of class assets, which we see l
componenttext: So Jeff, my feedback on the leasing world today is that, we're cautiously opportunistic with regards to the opportunities. And that very much aligns with what we at Federal Realty have. And this is what we see. We have best of class assets, which we see located in markets that really align with the retailers' desired core customer portfolio, which is incredibly important to them. They know that Federal Realty's commitment to deliver best in class property level operation, execution, and maintenance and are focus on delivering really the best tenant mix available aligns with their ability to be successful. That puts us in the best opportunity to take advantage of the growth that retailers are pursuing. And there clearly is growth demand from the retailers. They are just -- their outlook is just a lot more -- they are a lot more focused on finding sites that do algin with the core customer. The deals that they are doing are taking much longer. The lease negotiations are certainly more difficult. And they are a lot more selective. So we definitely see opportunity with regard to growth in retailers, and we think that they are looking in the markets where we have our real estate. So I think, from our perspective, we are set up to take advantage of what demand exist out there, both on the box side as well as on the small shop segment. And as Don pointed out, I mean, its very important for us as we unlever some of the restrictions in these opportunities, to take advantage of putting a new relevant box retailers that also, that rising tide will allow us to really take advantage of the demand from the small shop tenants. And collectively that will make our assets much better.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me add to that, Jeff. So, your question is a great one. And to the extent this was turning into 2008, you'd have a whole different perspective here in terms of what we think and what we're doing and the approach. There is not one sign that we see
componenttext: Yes, let me add to that, Jeff. So, your question is a great one. And to the extent this was turning into 2008, you'd have a whole different perspective here in terms of what we think and what we're doing and the approach. There is not one sign that we see with our discussions with our retailers, at our properties, in our locations of anything like that. Worse, it's a take a deep -- it's more of a deep breath. And as Chris says, it's more deliberate. It's a tougher negotiation, all that. That's fine. The reality is, if you were to see or to know -- if I took you for a ride over to Graham Park Plaza, which is inside the beltway in Fairfax, we have not been able to do anything with that property for a long time because of the leases in place. This is a particular point in time where we have a shot. If we simply released it to -- or kept the same anchor in and extended those existing leases, we would be losing the shot to create significant value for a decade or more. So when you overall take a look at it, I mean this is with the decision, with everything we've done, we are still 93% occupied. This is hardly, "oh my god empty out the whole place" right. But it does take a very measured and careful approach toward 10 shopping centers in particular, that we've been trying forever to figure out a way, because demand is there, to create value, but they've been encumbered by, whether it's an A&P lease or an old Valley lease or whatever it is at a particular shopping center that was causing it, to get it back. That seems like a smart approach to me. It's not all the way over on one side or all the way over on the other. Again, it's balanced.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe to switch gears. Just on the Clarion joint venture, one or two questions. All else equal I would have expected that purchase, considering the cash funding, to be slightly accretive to earnings, but if there is no further dispositions in guidance
componenttext: And maybe to switch gears. Just on the Clarion joint venture, one or two questions. All else equal I would have expected that purchase, considering the cash funding, to be slightly accretive to earnings, but if there is no further dispositions in guidance, I guess what's restraining that possibility?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I mentioned in the call, we didn't have factored previously in the guidance, the sale of Courtyard Shops in Wellington, Florida. So when you factor in that asset sale plus transaction costs, generally neutral for 2016, and we do expect it to be $0.02 t
componenttext: As I mentioned in the call, we didn't have factored previously in the guidance, the sale of Courtyard Shops in Wellington, Florida. So when you factor in that asset sale plus transaction costs, generally neutral for 2016, and we do expect it to be $0.02 to $0.03 accretive in '17.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, I missed the second part of that. I'm just curious, related to that, portfolio occupancy in that JV has been a little bit lower than the rest of the Federal portfolio, can you just remind us, I guess, how you guys think about the quality of those a
componenttext: Sorry, I missed the second part of that. I'm just curious, related to that, portfolio occupancy in that JV has been a little bit lower than the rest of the Federal portfolio, can you just remind us, I guess, how you guys think about the quality of those assets in comparison to your core? And is there a future redevelopment potential there that maybe isn't in your schedules today or do you see these assets as eventual sale candidates down the road?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The demographics are darn good compared to the rest of the portfolio. And I wish I had a better answer for you as to, what can I show you today, that would say, "Oh my God, buying out the other 70% in that portfolio is a clear home run." I don't have
componenttext: Yes. The demographics are darn good compared to the rest of the portfolio. And I wish I had a better answer for you as to, what can I show you today, that would say, "Oh my God, buying out the other 70% in that portfolio is a clear home run." I don't have that for you today. What I do have, and again, a lot of it from management perspective in a company like this, is to say, "All right, I now have a very focused team on it." But the initial conversations that we've been having with retailers and with the cities and jurisdictions that they're in, suggest that there is some good stuff to do at a couple or 3 of these shopping centers. And Plaza del Mercado was the first one that I mentioned to you. I expect there will others. Give Mooallem and his team a little bit of time to run through this and in the next couple of quarters, we'll have a far better roadmap for you, if you will, as to how it relates with the rest -- to the rest of the product we have.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one last question. I'm curious, why do Federal's renewal PIs run so much higher than peers. I guess one would expect the majority of your tenants, it's a costless proposition to renew. There's a little incentive or disincentive for them to leave the p
componenttext: And one last question. I'm curious, why do Federal's renewal PIs run so much higher than peers. I guess one would expect the majority of your tenants, it's a costless proposition to renew. There's a little incentive or disincentive for them to leave the property, and yet, your renewal PIs tend to be $8 to $9 a square-foot versus sometimes less than $1 for a lot of your peers. I'm just curious what you think drives that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I have an answer. I'm not sure if Chris will. The one thing I would posit here is, these shopping centers are better shopping centers in areas that -- where effectively the economics of the deal on a net basis make a whole lot of sense. And I
componenttext: I'm not sure I have an answer. I'm not sure if Chris will. The one thing I would posit here is, these shopping centers are better shopping centers in areas that -- where effectively the economics of the deal on a net basis make a whole lot of sense. And I suspect, in return for some of that higher rent, there is an expectation for certain small shop tenants to want more done to the space, can we get a redone bathroom, can we effectively refresh, et cetera, the space. I suspect that's it, but I don't know for sure. Chris, do you have anything to add to that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I -- all I would add is, I think it shows [indiscernible] I think this period as Don mentioned, we did have a transaction up in Melville, where we do have an in-place tenant, where there is going to be a downsizing of GOA in one area of the store to
componenttext: Yes. I -- all I would add is, I think it shows [indiscernible] I think this period as Don mentioned, we did have a transaction up in Melville, where we do have an in-place tenant, where there is going to be a downsizing of GOA in one area of the store to bring another one of their brands in. So that is the Dicks deal that was mentioned. And so a lot of it has to do with our making sure we're maximizing the opportunity within the space, whether that's an expansion, a shrinking and/or it really is an improvement to some of the infrastructure that we see going beyond just the tenant. And so we are very proactive in analyzing every single step available to make sure that we're getting the best out of each space. When you think about the amount of our portfolio of 100-plus assets, we've got to squeeze every bit of juice out of each one of them. And so we do analyze them. And that's how I think you will see the variation, but I think we could get into defining why on each deal we've made those decisions, as Don mentioned, in our investment committee. And we do analyze them thoroughly, I hope that helps, Don.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Christy McElroy with Citi.

componenttext: Certainly some of that, but much more. This is a much more efficient building. The outside of the building that we were building is no different. And accordingly, being able to refine and tweak mix and efficiency of the building, is what that's -- is what that's all about. It's a better answer in terms of economics. And we would not have done that, did we not feel that the market would absorb that and be able to handle it, 17 more properties -- or condos.

componenttext: Just a quick question on the lines of -- with some executive positions floating around out there that are open, how do you look at your talent and your bench, and in terms of keeping those bodies and maybe succession planning, if you do happen to get somebody stolen away?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Frankly, I couldn't feel better. I mean, there's -- we've spent a whole lot of time over the last two years working exactly what you're talking about, Jason, putting comp arrangements into place to make sure that we're doing the best we can to retain. The
componenttext: Frankly, I couldn't feel better. I mean, there's -- we've spent a whole lot of time over the last two years working exactly what you're talking about, Jason, putting comp arrangements into place to make sure that we're doing the best we can to retain. The key with Federal has always been, from our perspective, you can get the best and the brightest, if you give them the autonomy and you give them the leash to be able to run their businesses. That's effectively what it is that -- how we are set up. You can have a couple of cocktails with any one of them to get their point of view that way. But I feel real good about not only choices that we'll have for succession down the road, but also the ability to execute our -- this business plan that we've been pretty articulate about.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question for me. If you could, maybe just contrast tenant health from 3 or 4 years ago versus today. It's obviously a Darwinian business, and you're always replacing weak tenants with stronger tenants. But just overall, kind of state o
componenttext: Okay. And then last question for me. If you could, maybe just contrast tenant health from 3 or 4 years ago versus today. It's obviously a Darwinian business, and you're always replacing weak tenants with stronger tenants. But just overall, kind of state of the retailer space, do you feel better today than you did 3 or 4 years ago, relative to your tenants? Or is it -- there's a little softness that's developing with some of these bankruptcies.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason, I do have a very specific point of view with respect to this. I mean 3 or 4 years ago, just coming out of the recession, you're nervous. You're nervous with respect to what the -- what those tenants' business plans are going to be? How they're
componenttext: Yes, Jason, I do have a very specific point of view with respect to this. I mean 3 or 4 years ago, just coming out of the recession, you're nervous. You're nervous with respect to what the -- what those tenants' business plans are going to be? How they're going to work in the new world? Did the cuts that they made in their staffing, gut their organizations with respect to being able to do all that? And what has happened, and it's predictable, if you kind of take a look at it, is if you could be in every boardroom of all those major retailers and smaller retailers along the way, you would, some of them, with respect to what they changed and where they are moving, into a new economy, became extremely good at it and got stronger. A lot of them kind of found mediocrity. And success in certain areas, not in other areas, but with an improving economy, they held on, they held on, they held on. There's only so long you can hold on, if your business plan is not effectively resonating. And I do think that what we saw, and we felt it in '15, not long before what we're talking about for '16, was that those tenants that simply did not have business plans that resonated with consumers going forward were not going to be able to hold on indefinitely. We started to see that in the second half of '15, we decided then to specifically aggressively target them. We don't turn that on and off and there's a continuation of that into '16. But the better tenants, there are better tenants, and those better tenants are doing very well. There's more of a bifurcation, is what I am saying, between good and not so good, today, than there was 3 or 4 years ago. That's the distinction. And that's why, I guess, I'm talking my own book here, but it's what I believe. That's why the bifurcation between desirable real estate and not desirable real estate is wider than it certainly was 3 or 4 years ago. Those things work in tandem. And that's why we're probably a bit more optimistic, with respect to our leasing and this strategy in '16 and '17, than some others are.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So with your long-lived leases, do you feel like there is a number of years of kind of pain to come from a retailer standpoint, are we, are you working through the lion's share of that in the last couple of years?
componenttext: So with your long-lived leases, do you feel like there is a number of years of kind of pain to come from a retailer standpoint, are we, are you working through the lion's share of that in the last couple of years?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, I do believe that. But I believe that for only the better portfolios. I don't believe that across the board, 3 years ago or 4 years ago, that's across-the-board. Didn't matter. Today it matters.
componenttext: Jason, I do believe that. But I believe that for only the better portfolios. I don't believe that across the board, 3 years ago or 4 years ago, that's across-the-board. Didn't matter. Today it matters.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz with UBS.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a question for Chris Weilminster, but you mentioned the broad strength you're seeing on the leasing front, both from anchors and in line, and you talked at length early about being still optimistic about the retail environment. So I'm just wondering
componenttext: Maybe a question for Chris Weilminster, but you mentioned the broad strength you're seeing on the leasing front, both from anchors and in line, and you talked at length early about being still optimistic about the retail environment. So I'm just wondering if you could give us some more specifics or color on where demand is coming from, on both the shop and the box side?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, sure. I can, I'll say that the soft goods retailers, Nordstrom Rack, has made announcements about their growth plans. So there is lot of demand out from the boxes in that category, Rack, TJX, you talk what's going on with HPC in their growth expecta
componenttext: Well, sure. I can, I'll say that the soft goods retailers, Nordstrom Rack, has made announcements about their growth plans. So there is lot of demand out from the boxes in that category, Rack, TJX, you talk what's going on with HPC in their growth expectations. I think for Saks, be it Saks OFF 5TH brand, I think they're rolling out or talking about some brands as it relates to Lord & Taylor. I think that clearly is a box component that is looking for opportunity. We see the grocery category looking to get more nimble, and do more urban oriented stores, so smaller. I think there's a new concept out by Ahold called bfresh, which is taking some of what they've learned over in the European market about providing more deliverables on home meal replacement and a more convenient environment. That clearly provides opportunity. And then the QSR business, as we've been talking about for a long time on the smaller shop side, really continues to just amaze at how they're kind of gutting out the mid-tier casual dining category, and providing as quite -- as high a quality product, more curated by the consumer in a faster environment. That's the just the low-hanging fruit, but that energy, certainly, in those types of retailers, are the ones that we clearly see taking advantage of as we re-lease opportunities within our portfolio.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeremy, the other thing you got to keep your eye on, which I think is a real positive for the open air space is, there is -- there are certainly more women's apparel tenants that are considering open air versus -- or developing new concepts for open air v
componenttext: Jeremy, the other thing you got to keep your eye on, which I think is a real positive for the open air space is, there is -- there are certainly more women's apparel tenants that are considering open air versus -- or developing new concepts for open air versus just malls. I mean, we did a couple of LemonPop deals over the past few quarters. One in Melville Mall, that, I just love how it's performing, one in Ellisburg, that was good. And so, kind of -- those retailers' open-mindedness to where, with respect to their business plans, they can create value, I think is a real positive to the type of product that we have.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that color. And then, Don, in terms of the Sports Authority. I know it's little early here, and hard to put a probability on, but assuming you could get those back, do any of those have the potential to lead to some bigger redevelopments here,
componenttext: Appreciate that color. And then, Don, in terms of the Sports Authority. I know it's little early here, and hard to put a probability on, but assuming you could get those back, do any of those have the potential to lead to some bigger redevelopments here, given that they're in some of your better centers?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's funny, I mean, Brick is a good one, right? We are working hard at Brick Plaza to redefine that shopping center. And one of the Sports stores is at Brick Plaza. It opened -- it's a box -- a big box that opens up another set of opportunities. You
componenttext: Yes. It's funny, I mean, Brick is a good one, right? We are working hard at Brick Plaza to redefine that shopping center. And one of the Sports stores is at Brick Plaza. It opened -- it's a box -- a big box that opens up another set of opportunities. You know what we've been doing with respect to re-merchandising the East Bay Bridge. We would love, love to get that back, to be able to be re-merchandise it. And then, one at Assembly Square. Assembly Square, that power center is now adjacent to a pretty darn successful mixed-use project. So even though it pays a lot of rent, wouldn't mind that either. So there's -- there, when I look down through them, they can turn into -- to some real positives from a value perspective but again, short term hits.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: Okay, and then, just one last quick one for Jim here. I was just wondering if you can talk about the free rent you're giving at the office space at Assembly and Pike & Rose, and with those tenants taking occupancy here over the next few quarters. Should we really be thinking about stabilized yield for those -- the office components of those projects, not hitting until kind of a mid-or late 2017?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's going to be coming in, in mid-'17, that's correct Jeremy. When you factor in those periods and timing, as we get those tenants moved in. Again, all the space is committed, now it's just a question of getting the tenants in the space.
componenttext: It's going to be coming in, in mid-'17, that's correct Jeremy. When you factor in those periods and timing, as we get those tenants moved in. Again, all the space is committed, now it's just a question of getting the tenants in the space.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I think about what you guys have said during this call, it seems like no real slow down and not slowing down on taking space back and re-leasing it. But how about for bigger items, like a -- I'm not sure if there is a phase 3 for some of your larger
componenttext: So if I think about what you guys have said during this call, it seems like no real slow down and not slowing down on taking space back and re-leasing it. But how about for bigger items, like a -- I'm not sure if there is a phase 3 for some of your larger projects, but given what's going on in the road, does it at all impact your decisions to embark on just larger, more heavy capital-ed projects?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are not at a point where we're at a go or no-go, with respect to the third phase of Pike & Rose, the third phase of Assembly. I can tell you, there's a lot of things we're working on. Some of which could be pretty darn cool, but when we are at that poi
componenttext: We are not at a point where we're at a go or no-go, with respect to the third phase of Pike & Rose, the third phase of Assembly. I can tell you, there's a lot of things we're working on. Some of which could be pretty darn cool, but when we are at that point, the investment committee decisions, the capital allocation decisions will certainly, decisions, will certainly take into account where we are at that time in the economy, what we believe in terms of the future, and what use we're comfortable of doing and how much risk we'd like to take or offload, which we could do. So as of today, I have -- you should assume nothing different with respect to third phases or fourth phases of those projects or anything else we're looking at. As the year plays out, as '17 plays out, and we're getting to investment committee stage, you can bet that we'll have more say about it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick one on CocoWalk. When you look at that project, we thought, I think we talked about it before, it just seems like a bigger scope potentially, with kind of empty, small shops around that asset. Any progress update on what you're tryi
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick one on CocoWalk. When you look at that project, we thought, I think we talked about it before, it just seems like a bigger scope potentially, with kind of empty, small shops around that asset. Any progress update on what you're trying to do with that asset overall?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I am so going to jump in here before Weilminster starts telling you about all the great ideas he's got. There is an awful lot of stuff that we are kicking about and working through. Ki Bin, I don't want to push you off here, but I'm not going to say anyth
componenttext: I am so going to jump in here before Weilminster starts telling you about all the great ideas he's got. There is an awful lot of stuff that we are kicking about and working through. Ki Bin, I don't want to push you off here, but I'm not going to say anything further about either Coco or Sunset until we've got something to say on it. Because I don't want to take you up and then down and then up and then down. And that's the process that we go through, with respect to a true redevelopment analysis. There are a number of ways we could go there. Some of them have a larger scope, some of them are more simplistic. The overall IRRs and the risk-adjusted nature of each of those opportunities is what we're going to consider. I'm just not ready here, on February 10, to go further.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: Ki Bin, I would just comment that if you're spending any time in that market, you're seeing some very good things happen there. So we're pleased with the momentum that we see in the market. But again, as Don said, not ready to talk about any particular plan.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: This is the good part. I guess, the projects that you expect to be in larger redevelopments, how significant of a capital investment could it be?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so if you were working here and we were looking at these 10 assets and spending time within the cities, in the communities that they're in, doing market studies of what's missing, not only on a retail, but potentially on an excuse [ph] basis in each
componenttext: Yes, so if you were working here and we were looking at these 10 assets and spending time within the cities, in the communities that they're in, doing market studies of what's missing, not only on a retail, but potentially on an excuse [ph] basis in each of these places, you know that, you would know takes it takes a little bit of time. And the idea of figuring out what should each of these be, is where we start. We then put on the overall hat of, okay, how likely is it to get it done? Where's the balance in our business plan. If I were a betting man, and I am, I would suggest to you that half of these would be re-leasing, a couple of them would be minor redevelopments, and a couple of them would be larger redevelopments. I can't give you a capital number, because I'm just guessing at what I'm saying. But that's the point. What I'm trying to do for you is to give you the process that we're going to go through to make sure that this, I don't want to say once-in-a-lifetime, but once in a decade opportunity of having encumbered sections of real estate, gets viewed very thoroughly, and that we don't just slap in an inferior tenant in order to get optimally [ph] your same-store growth back.

componenttext: I think that's right. And if -- in the case of redevelopment, when you look at redevelopment at times, there are certain things that are just really clear, that pretty quickly, that you can't create economic value because of other things on the property. In those cases, I think in almost all of ours -- us here, we've got demand for space. So you may see a couple of quick re-leasing opportunities that may even provide some small level in '16. But by and large, you'll see it in '17 forwards.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, and last one for me. Jim, any comments on, where I guess -- can you remind us how much common equity is implied in the guidance range? And I guess, just given some of the uncertainty in the world and your funding needs in the current pipel
componenttext: That's helpful, and last one for me. Jim, any comments on, where I guess -- can you remind us how much common equity is implied in the guidance range? And I guess, just given some of the uncertainty in the world and your funding needs in the current pipeline, any thoughts on kind of an overnight vis--vis the ATM issuance?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Part of the reason we have the balance sheet we do, is to always have maximum flexibility towards never being in a position to have to raise a particular type of capital at a particular point in time. And that's something that we really work hard to prote
componenttext: Part of the reason we have the balance sheet we do, is to always have maximum flexibility towards never being in a position to have to raise a particular type of capital at a particular point in time. And that's something that we really work hard to protect and preserve. As we look at overall equity needs for the year, probably in the neighborhood of 200 to 250. But again,we'd have the flexibility to do it through our ATM, potentially an overnight, but I, it's all about making sure that we have the flexibility. And as we've been working really hard, as you can see, to make sure that as we're working through all this value creation that we've actually been prefunding a great deal of it. And you can see that when you look at our debt to EBITDA metric, which has remained low despite the fact that we have a lot of development that's not producing EBITDA yet. So that gives us a lot more flexibility if bad stuff comes on. And importantly, puts us in a position where we can fund the growth that we have underway, multiple ways.

componenttext: I know everyone's probably winding down. So a quick question, when you guys look at expanding into a new market or increasing your investment in a new market, how much of that is opportunistic versus strategic, i.e., you've just expanded significantly in Miami, how much of that was opportunity based, or how much of that was strategic based?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Floris, that's a strategic decision. Clearly, a strategic decision. The one thing that we got comfortable with over the years a little bit, is what it is, where were the places in this country that were logical extensions for us, that we felt very, very g
componenttext: Floris, that's a strategic decision. Clearly, a strategic decision. The one thing that we got comfortable with over the years a little bit, is what it is, where were the places in this country that were logical extensions for us, that we felt very, very good about the positive changes on a macro level over the next decade or two. The more we looked at, not Florida, but Miami in particular, within Florida, the more we felt that all the investment that's happening downtown, all the investment that's happening in that market place, was not -- was what it is, but it wasn't the same as what was happening where the full-time population lived. The more we looked into those areas, which included Coral Gables and included Coconut Grove, the more we got really excited about the possibilities of those being underserved places that were on a real upswing. Frankly, 6 months later or 12 months later from when we did it, and 2 years later from when we started thinking about it, we're actually more optimistic in terms of what's happening. If you look -- go look hard at the press and some of the deals that have been done in and around Coconut Grove over the past, 12 to 15 months, and I think you'll say, "Oh man, maybe these guys are on to something." So that was very much a strategic decision.

componenttext: Don, just maybe to summarize the conversation about where the tenant conversations are. Is it more about their feeling the pain of rents higher, than it is about their caution about store openings, is that kind of where we are with this?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a combination. I think it's a combination, Chris. When you're sitting in your -- I always try to take it to the boardrooms of any company. And in those boardrooms are conversations about earnings growth and longer-term plans. And it's like an
componenttext: I think it's a combination. I think it's a combination, Chris. When you're sitting in your -- I always try to take it to the boardrooms of any company. And in those boardrooms are conversations about earnings growth and longer-term plans. And it's like anything else. You don't just turn things on and off unless you have crazy times like 2008. And again, there's no sign that we see of anything like that. So instead, you start tweaking all of your pieces: the number of store openings, your cost structure, your product lines and store size, all of that stuff. So on a combined basis, there is not one thing that -- I love it when we say retailers, applying that there's this one thing out there. There are very many different business plans. And all we try to do as a company and as a business, is to be attractive to as many of them as possible. And not be tied to any one retailer, any one category within those retailers or any one geography. So when you look at it from that perspective, and you truly get back to demand versus supply on your particular real estate, that's why we're probably more optimistic than you're hearing elsewhere.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then my last question. If we circle back to sort of the very of the Q&A, and talk about the acquisition of the Clarion interest. When I think historically about how you guys have talked about the portfolio, I think, Don, you've always talked abo
componenttext: Okay, and then my last question. If we circle back to sort of the very of the Q&A, and talk about the acquisition of the Clarion interest. When I think historically about how you guys have talked about the portfolio, I think, Don, you've always talked about how proud you are of the fact that it's few assets, very highly valuable, large assets. When I look at the 6 assets that are in this portfolio, for the most part, they tend to be at the smaller end. And they're -- and several of them don't really fit what I would consider Federal markets or micro markets. So when I think about the answer to the question, you talked about having more bandwidth. So the question that I would ask you is, is that, because of the reorganization, which -- should we expect smaller core assets to necessarily be a bigger piece of this portfolio going forward, because you have more bandwidth or how should we be thinking about this transaction?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very fair question, Chris. The answer is no, you should not be thinking that. And that this is a discrete investment decision. And when you said you specifically think about this discrete investment decision, know that we have 11 years of actual experienc
componenttext: Very fair question, Chris. The answer is no, you should not be thinking that. And that this is a discrete investment decision. And when you said you specifically think about this discrete investment decision, know that we have 11 years of actual experience in knowing how these particular assets act and not act. And all 6 of them aren't great. No question about it, from the standpoint of are they -- does one size fit all here? Not at all. But as a portfolio, with an opportunity to either sell the 30% that we did own or buy the 70% that we did not own. In this discrete transaction, we think we can make some money and add some value here. Don't take that and expand that to the company's overall business plan the way you just described it, because that wouldn't be the case.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Federal Realty Investment Trust First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Leah Andress. Ma'am, you may begin.
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Federal Realty Investment Trust First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Leah Andress. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today for Federal Realty's First Quarter 2016 Earnings conference call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Jim Taylor, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster, Jeff Malone and Melissa Solis. They will
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today for Federal Realty's First Quarter 2016 Earnings conference call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Jim Taylor, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster, Jeff Malone and Melissa Solis. They will be available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. 
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities and Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results. Also, Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions. Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations can be attained.  In the earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. These documents are available on our website at federalrealty.com.
And with that, I would like to turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of our first quarter 2016 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Leah and good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today. I look forward to seeing all or most of you in a few weeks at the NAREIT conference in New York where we can talk more about our company and the many changes affecting our indust
componenttext:
Thanks, Leah and good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today. I look forward to seeing all or most of you in a few weeks at the NAREIT conference in New York where we can talk more about our company and the many changes affecting our industry. 
As most of you are aware by now, this will be the last earnings call of my good friend and colleague, Jim Taylor, will be on as the CFO of Federal. His team is certainly going to miss him, but I, for one, am -- genuinely proud of him and the opportunities he's going to get . Their board made a great choice bit. I'm also personally grateful for his many contributions to the company, his wise counsel and most importantly, his friendship, however, fleeting that might have been. 
Well, enough about Jim for the moment. Onward to the quarterly results and to our prospects for the future.
Really good quarter all the way around for us: FFO per share of $1.38, highest quarterly result of all time and 9.5% better than last year's quarter. 
Same-center growth of 4.2%, again, validating how important our redevelopment program is to us, but we don't expect to maintain this level for the year given the significant investment for the future initiatives we have underway and lease termination fees that helped us this quarter by $600,000 or so. More on all that later. 
85 comparable deals done for nearly 400,000 feet of space at 33 53 per foot, 13% higher on a cash basis than the deals they replaced. That's up 23% on anchors, 10% on small shops. It's up 21% on new leases, 9% on renewals. It's up on all of those metrics in the core shopping center business, in the mixed-use division and on the West Coast. Strong consistent leasing progress throughout our operations is our trademark, and we don't expect that to falter.
Overall portfolio occupancy at 94.1% leased but only 92.7% occupied, those numbers are down by 130 and 180 basis points, respectively, from a year ago, much of that through the inclusion of our lower occupancy acquisitions in South Florida and from the Clarion acquisition. Together, that's 1.5 million square feet added with a combined occupancy in the mid-80s. And of course, it's also the planned A&P and other vacancies we talked about last quarter. 
Yet we still had a record quarter. Growing earnings with decreasing occupancy, whether planned or unplanned, speaks volumes of our business plan and our company. Speaking of that occupancy, we made strong progress as it relates to proactively taking advantage of sale tenants to improve the anchor merchandising assortment of our important shopping centers. That initiative took a big step forward this quarter with the signing of T.J. Maxx to take over the space on Pentagon Row; with the signing of Dick's Sporting Goods at Melville Mall which, along with last quarter's Field & Stream deal and some real good stuff to come I'm not ready to talk about yet, go a long way to returning Melville Mall on Long Island into something pretty special; and L.A. Fitness taking out a host of obsolete small shop space at Delmar Village in Boca Raton.  3 great deals all at far higher rents than they replaced, actually nearly 30% higher in total with far better retailers for our future is just the initial part of the redevelopment of these extremely well located shopping centers. Remember though, those are just signed leases, and the rent contributions won't start from them for some time as each particular center is being developed. All the evidence so far suggests that this proactive approach to creating vacancy is going to work out overall as we hoped in creating more relevant shopping centers, even though it will put pressure on same-store growth for the balance of '16 and '17.
I also want to report strong progress on the lease up and rent start of the Phase 1 completions of our 3 big and active development projects. Let's talk about them individually.
At Assembly Row, the first phase is basically finished now, with the last group of office tenants moving into our small office building and the retailers and restaurants solidifying their own success. We've really moved on to Phase 2 execution, the first sign of which begins next month as the first partners health care employees begin populating nearly complete 700,000-square-foot building. Assembly has been so thoroughly accepted by the community as the place to live, work and shop, and we expect long-term value creation here to exceed our expectations. 
At Pike & Rose, we've leased up a ton of apartments since the end of the year and now stand as a Phase 1 residential percentage leased at 73% heading into a strong summer leasing season. I couldn't be more pleased at the rate of lease that we are achieving. Pike & Rose is creating a lot of business and getting a lot of recognition in the community, and I'm optimistic that we'll have the building basically full by year-end or soon thereafter as we forecast. 
I'm not as optimistic that we'll hit our rent dollar forecast, given the rental rates we've been assuming for the higher floors in the Pallas building. So far we've enclosed our forecasted rents at $2.40, which are at a premium to the market. But because of construction, we basically have been leasing from the bottom up. So we're skeptical at this point that we'll be able to push rents on the higher floors to the extent we had hoped, given the significant supply in the market and the fact that we remain a major construction site. We'll see over the next 6 to 8 months, but our initial yield may be under pressure by 50 basis points or so. More on that with another quarter of leasing under our belt.
One thing that we're particularly confident about is the very real premium to market and we've been getting even during this initial lease up phase. Pallas average monthly rents to date of $2,500 a month or $2.40 a foot reflect a 20% premium over the north Rockville submarket. And 4 [ph] penthouses we've delivered over $6,000 a month are setting new high-water marks for this market. As I said earlier, the pace of leasing is outpacing at competitive product, too. 
While excess supply in the market caused us to miss our initial rent projections, and that is no doubt disappointing, it's also causing us to protect more conservatively in Phase 2 as you'll not in our K. The premium to the market, clearly obtainable because of the environment we are creating at Pike & Rose and the level of service we are providing, is both validating and encouraging. We are building the right products for the future. Pike & Rose is going to be around for a long time and gets more and more integral for community shopping, living and working habits every day. We'll have many opportunities to increase the residential income stream in the years ahead on these mostly 12-month leases.
And at the point in El Segundo California, we're done in the last few leases and last half-dozen rent starts in a shopping center that has so clearly hit the bull's eye of what was missing in the market. This property will do nothing but get better and better over the years. 
And at 500 Santana Row, actually known here as the [indiscernible] building, we've talked of the $112 million project and remain on time and on budget.
So as I look back at the quarter and execution in the business plan that we're also passionate about around here, I couldn't be more encouraged that we're on the right track to double our income in the next decade, but also realistic about the investment, people and real estate necessary to do it right and protect our downside in cyclical business. 
The latest curveball lies in the uncertain future of Sports Authority. As you know, we have 5 locations, and none of them are in the closure list in the first round. We reserved most of our prepetition [ph] bankruptcy receivables of $400,000 in the first quarter and have been fully paid for April's rent. Now the latest conjecture of liquidation is a different story, of course. And depending on how it plays out and the specifics of each location, a short-term hit is likely and might affect our existing guidance if leases were immediately rejected as opposed to be assumed by retail. Having said that, we're quite confident that we would more than replace the cumulative rent, which totals $3.4 million annually triple-net basis, about $17.65 a foot and $4.8 million gross. The average market rent for a triple-net box lease in these location exceeds $25. We're already in conversations with replacement tenants just in case.
The other thing evolving changes, of course, is the changing shopping, living, working entertainment habits of today's consumer. As we're all well aware, we have been, are and will continue to invest heavily in the best people, real estate and type of product that we believe puts us in the best position to capitalize on those changes. The downside is that in doing so, making investments that have and will continue to dilute current earnings. 
And a couple of things on that front. First, the decentralization effort that our company is in the middle of is progressing quite well. [indiscernible] settling into his role and is in the process of building 4 quasi-independent geographic teams to grow our core shopping center business. Investment in incremental talent and IT systems infrastructure is now underway, and we would expect an incremental $1.5 million to $2 million annual investment to support this effort. 
Secondly, plans for new Miami acquisitions, Sunset Place and CocoWalk, are progressing well and are being vetted by our senior team and partners. Decisions as to the direction of initial phases should go to investment committee later this year, at which point we'll lay out what we have in mind. In the meantime, we're heavily focused on grassroots engagement with the local communities and are increasingly optimistic that we'll be able to put forth viable and value creative changes in both location. At Sunset, we'll need zoning changes to permit more height to come up with a viable plan. Fingers crossed.
And finally, the search for a Senior business partner that carries a CFO title for Federal is in full swing. I'm grateful for the very robust interest in joining our team that has followed Jim's announcement, and I've met with a number of terrific prospects who will be awesome partners to me and our senior team. I just don't want to rush that important decision, and I'm giving the process the attention and serious consideration it deserves. I'd hoped to be prepared to make an announcement in this regard in the next 30 to 45 days. 
In the meantime, Melissa Solis is our Principal Accounting Officer. And as those of you who know Melissa know, we remain in very good hands from an accounting and overall financial point of view.
Separately, I know that many on this call are friends and colleagues of James Miles, portfolio analyst at APG. We hadn't put out a separate press release, but James will be joining us next month in the role of Vice President, Director of Finance for the mixed-use division and will be relocating our headquarters in Rockville, Maryland. We're thrilled to have him.
Now let me turn it over to Jim before answering your questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don and Leah, and good morning, everyone. As Don highlighted, our team delivered yet another record for the trust in terms of FFO per share, which was $1.38 representing 9.5% growth over the prior year quarter. In a quarter where we continue to
componenttext:
Thank you, Don and Leah, and good morning, everyone. As Don highlighted, our team delivered yet another record for the trust in terms of FFO per share, which was $1.38 representing 9.5% growth over the prior year quarter. In a quarter where we continue to invest in the future through commencing future development phases, adding to our team, taking down box vacancy, et cetera, we are particularly pleased with the bottom line results driven by our operations leasing, acquisition and development team.
Turning to the numbers. Overall property operating income grew at 7.9% over the prior year even with the decline of 130 basis points of occupancy reflecting the higher anchor rollovers we've discussed, our core portfolio continued to be a significant driver of our COI growth. That core grew 4.2% on a same-store basis including redevelopment. This quarter, the downtime associated with anchor rollover produced about 130 basis points drag. We highlighted this trend the last 2 quarters. And as I will discuss further in guidance we expect this rollover drag to continue this year. 
Our first phases of Assembly Row and Pike & Rose contributed approximately $4.5 million of COI in the quarter, up on a sequential basis, as the Pallas high-rise opening approached breakeven occupancy and office spaces continue to rent commence. Finally, our acquisitions of Coco and Sunset Place, which are performing very well against our acquisition underwriting also contributed significantly to overall COI growth. 
G&A remains flat on a sequential basis at $8 million for the quarter and down year-over-year principally to higher transaction costs in 2015 with respect to our San Antonio Center acquisition. We do expect our G&A line item to grow as we continue to invest in our platform.
Interest expense declined $400,000, reflecting lower average rate achieved through our refinancings during the year, offset by lower capitalized interest during the quarter as we continue to place development in service. 
Again, bottom line, FFO grew at 9.5% for the quarter, which is above our long-term plan. an absolute bottom line performance while we continue to invest in the future, it's something we take great pride in. 
From a balance sheet perspective, we raised approximately $182 million of equity through an overnight [ph] as well as issuances under our ATM during the quarter at a weighted average price of $149.18. This represents over half of the equity we planned to raise this year. 
We ended the quarter with $53 million drawn under our $600 million revolver, which we upsized after the quarter to $800 million and extended into 2020 while reducing our borrowing costs by 10 basis points. Our net debt to EBITDA was 5.3x, and our weighted average tenor was almost 10 years versus the pure average closer to 5, providing us maximum flexibility and liquidity to fund all of the value creation that we have underway.
Turning to 2016, we affirm the previously given range of FFO per share of $5.65 to $5.71, a range of growth of approximately 6% to 7% or slightly below our long-term plan. As we discussed last quarter, this is a true range that will be impacted by several variables during the year. Again, the targeted box recapture and rollover vacancy drives a significant amount of drag in the year. That drag was offset this quarter by some positive timing items, which included marketing expense recoveries as well as higher year-over-year term fees of $600,00, as Don mentioned. Given that, we do expect same-store NOI will moderate in the second and third quarters of this year.
As Don discussed in his remarks, we are pleased to announce the signing of TJ Maxx, Pentagon, Dick's Sporting Goods lease at Melville and the L.A. Fitness lease at Delmar, all of which, as Don stated, will unlock significant value at these centers. Overall, our leasing team is making great progress under captured box phases, which we will continue to report on over the coming quarters. 
In addition to this rollovers, as discussed in prior quarters, there are several other investments in growth to consider from a timing perspective as you look at the year. First, leasing pace at Pallas continues to do well with occupancy in the building alone at just over 60% and expected stabilization occurring in the fourth quarter. The office space of Pike & Rose and Assembly, which represents approximately $80 million of investments, is fully committed and leased. And we'll start seeing the rent commencing throughout this year and early next as tenants take occupancy. 500 Santana Row, the building which represents approximately $115 million of investment, is of course 100% preleased and will deliver in the first quarter and rent commence in 2017. The Point redevelopment continues to perform exceptionally well and is expected to stabilize in the fourth quarter of this year. 
Our acquisition of our joint venture partner's 70% interest in 6 core assets is expected to be neutral this year after transaction costs in the sale of courtyard shops. We expect this acquisition to contribute approximately $0.02 to $0.03 in 2017.
We are well underway to the second phases of Pike & Rose and Assembly that represent another $600 million of investment and expect those phases to begin delivering in the latter part of '17 and early '18. 
From a capital standpoint, again, we expect to fund approximately $300 million of development and redevelopment with a mix of funds from operations, long-term debt and equity and our ATM, much of which we have taken care of the first quarter.  Finally, consistent with our practice, our guidance does not factor in any further acquisitions or dispositions that we may execute during the year. 
When you consider all that the company has going on, you will understand why we continue to emphasize that our guidance this year is a true range. factors that may drive us towards low end of that range include the timing of the anchor boxes to rent commencement; the potential for additional rent concessions at Pallas as lease the penthouses in the upper floor; the opportunistic capital raise that we completed the first quarter, front-ended a significant capital needs for the year. The ultimate resolution of the Sports Authority, as Don discussed, while none of our location made the initial closure list, we believe it is unlikely that The Sports Authority will continue to have this and that we may have the opportunity to get some of those locations back.
We continue to invest in our platform, as Don mentioned, both in systems and people as we drive decision-making closer to the real estate. These efforts may drive an additional $1 million to $2 million of annual G&A above our current run rate of $34 million to 35 million in annual basis. Even with that growth, it's still far below 5% of revenues.
And finally, the costs associated with back filling position have not been determined or forecast. Again, each one of these items that influence where we will come out in the range is a positive for the company and its long-term growth prospects, but they may impact where we land.
Before turning the call over to questions, I'd like to briefly thank Don. His friendship, counsel and support have meant a great deal to me over the last 18 years and now as I turn to the opportunity at Brixmore. Thank you, Don. 
I would also like to thank my partners at Federal, who are the best in the business: Chris Weilminster; Dawn Becker; Jeff Berkes; Jeff Malone; [indiscernible] Colson; John Pease, Deirdre Barry; and last, but certainty most, [ph] Melissa. Thanks to each you for inspiring me with your excellence and your commitment to the trust and its shareholders. 
With that, operator, I'd like to turn the call over to questions.

componenttextpreview: Congratulations, Jim, and hopefully you just didn't read off a list of the names of people you are going to target when you're at Brixmore. Question about Pike & Rose, I'm just curious what's driving the reduction in the stabilized yield. I got in late ad
componenttext: Congratulations, Jim, and hopefully you just didn't read off a list of the names of people you are going to target when you're at Brixmore. Question about Pike & Rose, I'm just curious what's driving the reduction in the stabilized yield. I got in late admittedly', so I'm not sure if you talked about it in your remarks.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, we did. It is really all about residential. As you know, that first phase and the second phase has a significant residential component to it. The bottom line is, we were too aggressive in thinking what we were going to be able to get for reside
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, we did. It is really all about residential. As you know, that first phase and the second phase has a significant residential component to it. The bottom line is, we were too aggressive in thinking what we were going to be able to get for residential rents. And the marketplace has an awful lot of supply on it, and the place is absolutely a construction zone and will be for some time. And so it's what I always worry about it with changing numbers like this is that there's a taint on the project itself, because there can't be. The project is going as well or better than we expected in terms of its acceptance, even in terms of its performance, rent performance on the residential side, compared to the marketplace. It's just that the marketplace is significantly lower than we had hoped and thought it would be when we underwrote this is. So it's all that. obviously the good side of that is we're not locking into 15-year deals or 20-year deals. These are 12-month leases, but it would be -- it just wouldn't be right for me to have the same expectations of being able to lease up the rest of the buildings we have on Phase 1 and the residential buildings in Phase 2 at rents that when I look at it right now with our team looks at it right now, we don't think we can hit. And that's what's causing that. I really don't want to see that as a failure of the project. It's market timing.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: and maybe to switch gears. I maybe wanted to circle back on decentralization plan. I think we even talked on the call maybe a year, 1.5 years ago about why it's very difficult for the industry, or seemingly difficult for the industry, to produce call it f
componenttext: and maybe to switch gears. I maybe wanted to circle back on decentralization plan. I think we even talked on the call maybe a year, 1.5 years ago about why it's very difficult for the industry, or seemingly difficult for the industry, to produce call it future leaders. And then you announced that plan. I guess I'm just curious what's -- what was the impetus for it? How -- or what do you think it accomplishes for Federal? And I guess not to bring it back to dollars and cents all the time, but how do you think we should be thinking about a ultimate effect on G&A if you sort of reorganize people?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's probably my favorite question, Jeff. The -- look, the bottom line is this company grew and has grown pretty darn consistently over the last 15 years in terms of its value, in terms of what it does for a living, in terms of its breadth and growth
componenttext: Yes, it's probably my favorite question, Jeff. The -- look, the bottom line is this company grew and has grown pretty darn consistently over the last 15 years in terms of its value, in terms of what it does for a living, in terms of its breadth and growth. The -- we had to effectively get management closer to the real estate because the real estate is so different. Managing a Pike and Rose and managing an Assembly Row and managing and having an opportunity like Sunset and Coco is just very different than the core shopping center business. So we needed to needed to align management more closely with the real estate business. That's our business. We are really not a portfolio manager. We look at it asset by asset. Now when you do that, there's obviously going to be incremental overhead to be able to set it up that way. And that overhead is incremental, not only on to use the hotel vernacular, front of the house stuff, but also back of the house systems and reporting, accounting all of that. We're in the middle of that transition, and that transition take some time. If you think about incremental few million a year, basically, we got to more than make up for that in incremental value. Well, where did that incremental value come from? It comes from every part of our business, first and foremost, by getting to things more quickly, by getting tenants to through the process of leasing to tenant coordination, to opening their doors to rent start. That's done a whole lot better if the leasing agent and the asset manager and the developer, tenant working together, there's a lot of that. Secondly, at that level, we'll know our markets better. We do know our markets better and closer so that -- and I'll give a couple of examples. We're talking about Brick Township now, Brick Plaza. Well, Brick is a bit shopping center in Brick New Jersey that we've owned for a long time. Part of the reason that we have been able to get to doing a better job at Brick Plaza's because of the A&P lease and we tell to that about that. But another part of the reason is because it's geographically further away. This helps us focus more on it. It helps us create business, and -- I could say that about at least 20 or 25 shopping centers. So this is truly an evolution of our business. It's an investment in the next decade where the combination of great products in terms of a mixed-use development that we're doing, with a more active and proactively managed core, together should make the few million dollars of incremental G&A nothing compared to the incremental value that we create. So that's what it is that we're trying to do.

componenttext: Okay, Jim, and maybe just one last question. Don, do you have any specific goals going into ICSC? I think typically, you guys go in there with really 1 or 2 things you really want to walk away with ...

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the goals are not -- it's so funny. We don't -- and I hope everybody on this call gets this. It's -- you don't go into ICSC thinking you're getting leases done. The goals you go into ICSC before is to make sure that you bring as many people to the crit
componenttext: On the goals are not -- it's so funny. We don't -- and I hope everybody on this call gets this. It's -- you don't go into ICSC thinking you're getting leases done. The goals you go into ICSC before is to make sure that you bring as many people to the critical parts of the company that you can. So for us, it is our redevelopment pipeline and in core, it's our Florida stuff that we are going to be one thing everybody to see and understand. Is the future basis of Pike and Rose and Assembly as well as our West Coast asset. It's a focus on those things. It's not we are going to get lease this leased and that lease done. It just doesn't happen that way. What normally happens is somewhere in the next 30, 60, 90, 120 days after ICSC, there is a lot more deals that get done because they were germinated and taken to the next level at ICSC. That's what we're doing there.
