componenttext: Yes, just jump in on him if I miss anything on a be but as a remember, Jason we have four ANPs. One of those was assumed and is underway in terms of being billed out on Long Island at Fremont, which leaves 3 more. Melville Mall also on the island and I did not mention -- when I talked about the good stuff that's happening at Melville Mall with the signing of Dicks, for example, the last we have Melville Mall is this announced box. And we're making real good progress, but we are not a place where I can tell you it's a signed deal yet. And you'll like everything about that. The next one is at Brick, and we are again in spite of a much beaver redevelopment and remerchandising of the entire is center. And we're not as close as Melville, but making real good progress over the next couple of quarters there, I think. the final one is Troy, which is in New Jersey. And we're hopeful -- I shouldn't say exactly this way yet. I don't know whether we're going to backfill it or whether it is going to be a bigger redevelopments possibility there, which would include some residential and a more densely populated shopping center. Obviously if it comes to something like that, which would add the most value inside the to the community and figuring out if something like that is viable. That's what we're working on there. So that would be the last one of the 3 that you'll hear anything about, I would think.  And Santana, let's go to Santana. oh Yes, Valley Fair does what they're doing. And Jeff's on the phone. absolutely impact. they're talking about adding hundreds of thousands of square feet in a great node at a great place that will perform a very different function than what we do. And I wouldn't think -- we're confident that it wouldn't have a long-term impact on the property. But if they are leasing up that much space for that period of time, that has to, I would think, impact us. I just don't know by how much yet, nothing in any significant way whether they actually haven't started construction yet, when they will, where they will, what the timing is, I still don't know the answer to that there. But there could be an impact. I just can't quantify for you today, again, a short-term impact.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'd add to that, Don, Jason, we've known this is coming for some time. They got the entitlement before the recession. So over the last 4 or 5 years, we've been doing the walking and tapping that we need to do it Santana to put the property
componenttext: The only thing I'd add to that, Don, Jason, we've known this is coming for some time. They got the entitlement before the recession. So over the last 4 or 5 years, we've been doing the walking and tapping that we need to do it Santana to put the property in the best position as possible, including a lot of remerchandising of the stores on the street, which I'm sure you're familiar with, and continuing to build on the property, not least to which is adding more parking and buildings like 500 Santana Row when [indiscernible] occupancy during the week, will be available to retail and restaurant customers nights and weekends. So again, it's something we've been thinking about for many years now and doing what we can do to put ourselves to the best position. And what happens, happens and we'll deal with that the best we can.

componenttext: George, let me start with that. And Jim if you got something you want to add, please do. I can  tell you that obviously nobody knows really what the impact's going to be in terms of supply and demand. That will be what it's going to be. It has not changed our approach, which has always been very broad-based in terms of who it is that we want to invest. I mean, we have taken pretty regular trips to Europe, for example, to talk to generalists there. We have done that in New York in a broader way. We've always try to do that. And we've had some pretty good luck, frankly in getting investors interested in our story. Whether that's helped it or not, we'll know at some point after September after it gets put in place. But that's pretty much what we're doing. We -- obviously is a change in your world more than it is in terms of what we do and just with respect to what we do, wealth all it really seeing is we've been brought for a long time in terms of what we aim for.

componenttextpreview: It's interesting question because when you look at our leased matured schedule, the truth is that we always get them more space than what would be otherwise indicated by that. And if you look at our trend, and it's important to look at this trend over the
componenttext: It's interesting question because when you look at our leased matured schedule, the truth is that we always get them more space than what would be otherwise indicated by that. And if you look at our trend, and it's important to look at this trend over the last several quarters, of where we're signing our new deals and you've seen that average continue to climb, that gives you a sense of what the mark to market is, if you will, what we have in place. It's not perfect, but if you go back far enough, you're going to capture enough of a subset of the portfolio to look at that. And again, we've owned these assets for a long period of time, so we have vintage leases rolling every year. There isn't, as far as I can tell, not a particular year in which we've got a lot of vintage closing coming to market, if you will. So best thing to do to get a sense of that is to look at our marginal rents that we're signing each quarter.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, just a couple of quick questions. On the TSA outcome, if you were to get the stores back, are there certain centers that would be helped as it relates to maybe future redevelopment timing?
componenttext: Don, just a couple of quick questions. On the TSA outcome, if you were to get the stores back, are there certain centers that would be helped as it relates to maybe future redevelopment timing?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there are. Let's go through them. So here are the 5 centers, Assembly Square in the marketplace, right? So you know what's happening to that marketplace. First is because of what we're doing in the mixed-use project adjacent to it, it's been a very
componenttext: Well, there are. Let's go through them. So here are the 5 centers, Assembly Square in the marketplace, right? So you know what's happening to that marketplace. First is because of what we're doing in the mixed-use project adjacent to it, it's been a very positive thing. And certainly, the interest in that power center that's adjacent is significantly higher than it was before we built the project. So if we got that back, that'd be okay, good thing there. Brick Plaza is the next one, again, in the middle of a complete redo. The timing of that would be great in terms of the future of Brick Plaza. Crow Canyon, which is out on the West Coast and that's a smaller store out there, and then the latest when we did we did some years back. But nonetheless, it the last one, smaller in a center that we had -- we've just redone, which is a good thing in terms of the demand characteristics that you would have. Montrose Crossing is the fourth. That's the one directly across from Pike and Rose. That's over 35 acres where the section of the shopping center where they are would be dramatically impacted to the extent we can better merchandise that. And the last one is East Bay Bridge out in Emeryville, which is the rent's in place there are extremely low, and the upside would be terrific. And that's another place that we just put into new -- we've really remerchandised the shopping center price. As I sit back and look at TSA, this is a good tenant to work through this portfolio, and it's a better thing in all of the location that we have. Well, it's a lot of rent in the meantime. And so again, can you look through the short-term pain for long-term gain?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. the final question. Silver Line and Tyson's has been disruptor, providing a boon and an opportunity for some property owners, but changing certain patterns to the detriment of others. My understanding is that sales at Pike 7 have been weaker. are th
componenttext: Okay. the final question. Silver Line and Tyson's has been disruptor, providing a boon and an opportunity for some property owners, but changing certain patterns to the detriment of others. My understanding is that sales at Pike 7 have been weaker. are there things you can do their that change the view there or -- Or is there some view to the timing of future redevelopment that you would look towards the.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't -- first of all, the premise, I'm not with you on in terms of the impact of sales at Pike 7. Pike 7 is an amazing shopping center. Frankly, if sales were hit significantly during Pike 7, w they would have happened during the construction of this S
componenttext: I don't -- first of all, the premise, I'm not with you on in terms of the impact of sales at Pike 7. Pike 7 is an amazing shopping center. Frankly, if sales were hit significantly during Pike 7, w they would have happened during the construction of this Silver Line when basically all and they did in any significant way. But if they were, then we have a lower hurdle to be able to do a larger mixed-use project at the site which would be great. Having said that, your point, bigger point, stopping right there, look Pike 7 is a great asset for us. What we do there long term will only be positive. And part of the issue is it's so successful for what it is right now. And therefore, the hurdle is so high to do something better, financially better there. So that's Pike 7. Now take bigger premise and this, I think, is really important in terms of the judgment that we should there. I think you're right, the way this Silver Line is working through Tyson's, there are winners and there are losers. The type of projects that are being built there, there are winners and there are losers. We did not jump in say, oh God, we got to the first one to market. We sat back. We renewed leases. We have pickup so that we were able to get space if we needed to. But we've created. We are disciplined. that particular asset has [indiscernible] to our benefit, that's only because we really ran it like a true real estate company would and real estate play, and not like a drunken sailor with respect to development, for Pete's sake, in terms of what it should be. Because I want -- I guess I want to get a little bit of credit for the discipline we showed in not jumping to the what the new Tyson's is going to be. Because as you just point out, it takes a long time with a major infrastructure change like this Silver Line is to figure out what Tyson should be. Thanks for giving me a choice by the way.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today for Federal Realty's First Quarter 2016 Earnings conference call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Jim Taylor, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster, Jeff Malone and Melissa Solis. They will
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today for Federal Realty's First Quarter 2016 Earnings conference call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Jim Taylor, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster, Jeff Malone and Melissa Solis. They will be available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. 
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities and Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results. Also, Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions. Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations can be attained.  In the earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. These documents are available on our website at federalrealty.com.
And with that, I would like to turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of our first quarter 2016 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Leah and good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today. I look forward to seeing all or most of you in a few weeks at the NAREIT conference in New York where we can talk more about our company and the many changes affecting our indust
componenttext:
Thanks, Leah and good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today. I look forward to seeing all or most of you in a few weeks at the NAREIT conference in New York where we can talk more about our company and the many changes affecting our industry. 
As most of you are aware by now, this will be the last earnings call of my good friend and colleague, Jim Taylor, will be on as the CFO of Federal. His team is certainly going to miss him, but I, for one, am -- genuinely proud of him and the opportunities he's going to get . Their board made a great choice bit. I'm also personally grateful for his many contributions to the company, his wise counsel and most importantly, his friendship, however, fleeting that might have been. 
Well, enough about Jim for the moment. Onward to the quarterly results and to our prospects for the future.
Really good quarter all the way around for us: FFO per share of $1.38, highest quarterly result of all time and 9.5% better than last year's quarter. 
Same-center growth of 4.2%, again, validating how important our redevelopment program is to us, but we don't expect to maintain this level for the year given the significant investment for the future initiatives we have underway and lease termination fees that helped us this quarter by $600,000 or so. More on all that later. 
85 comparable deals done for nearly 400,000 feet of space at 33 53 per foot, 13% higher on a cash basis than the deals they replaced. That's up 23% on anchors, 10% on small shops. It's up 21% on new leases, 9% on renewals. It's up on all of those metrics in the core shopping center business, in the mixed-use division and on the West Coast. Strong consistent leasing progress throughout our operations is our trademark, and we don't expect that to falter.
Overall portfolio occupancy at 94.1% leased but only 92.7% occupied, those numbers are down by 130 and 180 basis points, respectively, from a year ago, much of that through the inclusion of our lower occupancy acquisitions in South Florida and from the Clarion acquisition. Together, that's 1.5 million square feet added with a combined occupancy in the mid-80s. And of course, it's also the planned A&P and other vacancies we talked about last quarter. 
Yet we still had a record quarter. Growing earnings with decreasing occupancy, whether planned or unplanned, speaks volumes of our business plan and our company. Speaking of that occupancy, we made strong progress as it relates to proactively taking advantage of sale tenants to improve the anchor merchandising assortment of our important shopping centers. That initiative took a big step forward this quarter with the signing of T.J. Maxx to take over the space on Pentagon Row; with the signing of Dick's Sporting Goods at Melville Mall which, along with last quarter's Field & Stream deal and some real good stuff to come I'm not ready to talk about yet, go a long way to returning Melville Mall on Long Island into something pretty special; and L.A. Fitness taking out a host of obsolete small shop space at Delmar Village in Boca Raton.  3 great deals all at far higher rents than they replaced, actually nearly 30% higher in total with far better retailers for our future is just the initial part of the redevelopment of these extremely well located shopping centers. Remember though, those are just signed leases, and the rent contributions won't start from them for some time as each particular center is being developed. All the evidence so far suggests that this proactive approach to creating vacancy is going to work out overall as we hoped in creating more relevant shopping centers, even though it will put pressure on same-store growth for the balance of '16 and '17.
I also want to report strong progress on the lease up and rent start of the Phase 1 completions of our 3 big and active development projects. Let's talk about them individually.
At Assembly Row, the first phase is basically finished now, with the last group of office tenants moving into our small office building and the retailers and restaurants solidifying their own success. We've really moved on to Phase 2 execution, the first sign of which begins next month as the first partners health care employees begin populating nearly complete 700,000-square-foot building. Assembly has been so thoroughly accepted by the community as the place to live, work and shop, and we expect long-term value creation here to exceed our expectations. 
At Pike & Rose, we've leased up a ton of apartments since the end of the year and now stand as a Phase 1 residential percentage leased at 73% heading into a strong summer leasing season. I couldn't be more pleased at the rate of lease that we are achieving. Pike & Rose is creating a lot of business and getting a lot of recognition in the community, and I'm optimistic that we'll have the building basically full by year-end or soon thereafter as we forecast. 
I'm not as optimistic that we'll hit our rent dollar forecast, given the rental rates we've been assuming for the higher floors in the Pallas building. So far we've enclosed our forecasted rents at $2.40, which are at a premium to the market. But because of construction, we basically have been leasing from the bottom up. So we're skeptical at this point that we'll be able to push rents on the higher floors to the extent we had hoped, given the significant supply in the market and the fact that we remain a major construction site. We'll see over the next 6 to 8 months, but our initial yield may be under pressure by 50 basis points or so. More on that with another quarter of leasing under our belt.
One thing that we're particularly confident about is the very real premium to market and we've been getting even during this initial lease up phase. Pallas average monthly rents to date of $2,500 a month or $2.40 a foot reflect a 20% premium over the north Rockville submarket. And 4 [ph] penthouses we've delivered over $6,000 a month are setting new high-water marks for this market. As I said earlier, the pace of leasing is outpacing at competitive product, too. 
While excess supply in the market caused us to miss our initial rent projections, and that is no doubt disappointing, it's also causing us to protect more conservatively in Phase 2 as you'll not in our K. The premium to the market, clearly obtainable because of the environment we are creating at Pike & Rose and the level of service we are providing, is both validating and encouraging. We are building the right products for the future. Pike & Rose is going to be around for a long time and gets more and more integral for community shopping, living and working habits every day. We'll have many opportunities to increase the residential income stream in the years ahead on these mostly 12-month leases.
And at the point in El Segundo California, we're done in the last few leases and last half-dozen rent starts in a shopping center that has so clearly hit the bull's eye of what was missing in the market. This property will do nothing but get better and better over the years. 
And at 500 Santana Row, actually known here as the [indiscernible] building, we've talked of the $112 million project and remain on time and on budget.
So as I look back at the quarter and execution in the business plan that we're also passionate about around here, I couldn't be more encouraged that we're on the right track to double our income in the next decade, but also realistic about the investment, people and real estate necessary to do it right and protect our downside in cyclical business. 
The latest curveball lies in the uncertain future of Sports Authority. As you know, we have 5 locations, and none of them are in the closure list in the first round. We reserved most of our prepetition [ph] bankruptcy receivables of $400,000 in the first quarter and have been fully paid for April's rent. Now the latest conjecture of liquidation is a different story, of course. And depending on how it plays out and the specifics of each location, a short-term hit is likely and might affect our existing guidance if leases were immediately rejected as opposed to be assumed by retail. Having said that, we're quite confident that we would more than replace the cumulative rent, which totals $3.4 million annually triple-net basis, about $17.65 a foot and $4.8 million gross. The average market rent for a triple-net box lease in these location exceeds $25. We're already in conversations with replacement tenants just in case.
The other thing evolving changes, of course, is the changing shopping, living, working entertainment habits of today's consumer. As we're all well aware, we have been, are and will continue to invest heavily in the best people, real estate and type of product that we believe puts us in the best position to capitalize on those changes. The downside is that in doing so, making investments that have and will continue to dilute current earnings. 
And a couple of things on that front. First, the decentralization effort that our company is in the middle of is progressing quite well. [indiscernible] settling into his role and is in the process of building 4 quasi-independent geographic teams to grow our core shopping center business. Investment in incremental talent and IT systems infrastructure is now underway, and we would expect an incremental $1.5 million to $2 million annual investment to support this effort. 
Secondly, plans for new Miami acquisitions, Sunset Place and CocoWalk, are progressing well and are being vetted by our senior team and partners. Decisions as to the direction of initial phases should go to investment committee later this year, at which point we'll lay out what we have in mind. In the meantime, we're heavily focused on grassroots engagement with the local communities and are increasingly optimistic that we'll be able to put forth viable and value creative changes in both location. At Sunset, we'll need zoning changes to permit more height to come up with a viable plan. Fingers crossed.
And finally, the search for a Senior business partner that carries a CFO title for Federal is in full swing. I'm grateful for the very robust interest in joining our team that has followed Jim's announcement, and I've met with a number of terrific prospects who will be awesome partners to me and our senior team. I just don't want to rush that important decision, and I'm giving the process the attention and serious consideration it deserves. I'd hoped to be prepared to make an announcement in this regard in the next 30 to 45 days. 
In the meantime, Melissa Solis is our Principal Accounting Officer. And as those of you who know Melissa know, we remain in very good hands from an accounting and overall financial point of view.
Separately, I know that many on this call are friends and colleagues of James Miles, portfolio analyst at APG. We hadn't put out a separate press release, but James will be joining us next month in the role of Vice President, Director of Finance for the mixed-use division and will be relocating our headquarters in Rockville, Maryland. We're thrilled to have him.
Now let me turn it over to Jim before answering your questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don and Leah, and good morning, everyone. As Don highlighted, our team delivered yet another record for the trust in terms of FFO per share, which was $1.38 representing 9.5% growth over the prior year quarter. In a quarter where we continue to
componenttext:
Thank you, Don and Leah, and good morning, everyone. As Don highlighted, our team delivered yet another record for the trust in terms of FFO per share, which was $1.38 representing 9.5% growth over the prior year quarter. In a quarter where we continue to invest in the future through commencing future development phases, adding to our team, taking down box vacancy, et cetera, we are particularly pleased with the bottom line results driven by our operations leasing, acquisition and development team.
Turning to the numbers. Overall property operating income grew at 7.9% over the prior year even with the decline of 130 basis points of occupancy reflecting the higher anchor rollovers we've discussed, our core portfolio continued to be a significant driver of our COI growth. That core grew 4.2% on a same-store basis including redevelopment. This quarter, the downtime associated with anchor rollover produced about 130 basis points drag. We highlighted this trend the last 2 quarters. And as I will discuss further in guidance we expect this rollover drag to continue this year. 
Our first phases of Assembly Row and Pike & Rose contributed approximately $4.5 million of COI in the quarter, up on a sequential basis, as the Pallas high-rise opening approached breakeven occupancy and office spaces continue to rent commence. Finally, our acquisitions of Coco and Sunset Place, which are performing very well against our acquisition underwriting also contributed significantly to overall COI growth. 
G&A remains flat on a sequential basis at $8 million for the quarter and down year-over-year principally to higher transaction costs in 2015 with respect to our San Antonio Center acquisition. We do expect our G&A line item to grow as we continue to invest in our platform.
Interest expense declined $400,000, reflecting lower average rate achieved through our refinancings during the year, offset by lower capitalized interest during the quarter as we continue to place development in service. 
Again, bottom line, FFO grew at 9.5% for the quarter, which is above our long-term plan. an absolute bottom line performance while we continue to invest in the future, it's something we take great pride in. 
From a balance sheet perspective, we raised approximately $182 million of equity through an overnight [ph] as well as issuances under our ATM during the quarter at a weighted average price of $149.18. This represents over half of the equity we planned to raise this year. 
We ended the quarter with $53 million drawn under our $600 million revolver, which we upsized after the quarter to $800 million and extended into 2020 while reducing our borrowing costs by 10 basis points. Our net debt to EBITDA was 5.3x, and our weighted average tenor was almost 10 years versus the pure average closer to 5, providing us maximum flexibility and liquidity to fund all of the value creation that we have underway.
Turning to 2016, we affirm the previously given range of FFO per share of $5.65 to $5.71, a range of growth of approximately 6% to 7% or slightly below our long-term plan. As we discussed last quarter, this is a true range that will be impacted by several variables during the year. Again, the targeted box recapture and rollover vacancy drives a significant amount of drag in the year. That drag was offset this quarter by some positive timing items, which included marketing expense recoveries as well as higher year-over-year term fees of $600,00, as Don mentioned. Given that, we do expect same-store NOI will moderate in the second and third quarters of this year.
As Don discussed in his remarks, we are pleased to announce the signing of TJ Maxx, Pentagon, Dick's Sporting Goods lease at Melville and the L.A. Fitness lease at Delmar, all of which, as Don stated, will unlock significant value at these centers. Overall, our leasing team is making great progress under captured box phases, which we will continue to report on over the coming quarters. 
In addition to this rollovers, as discussed in prior quarters, there are several other investments in growth to consider from a timing perspective as you look at the year. First, leasing pace at Pallas continues to do well with occupancy in the building alone at just over 60% and expected stabilization occurring in the fourth quarter. The office space of Pike & Rose and Assembly, which represents approximately $80 million of investments, is fully committed and leased. And we'll start seeing the rent commencing throughout this year and early next as tenants take occupancy. 500 Santana Row, the building which represents approximately $115 million of investment, is of course 100% preleased and will deliver in the first quarter and rent commence in 2017. The Point redevelopment continues to perform exceptionally well and is expected to stabilize in the fourth quarter of this year. 
Our acquisition of our joint venture partner's 70% interest in 6 core assets is expected to be neutral this year after transaction costs in the sale of courtyard shops. We expect this acquisition to contribute approximately $0.02 to $0.03 in 2017.
We are well underway to the second phases of Pike & Rose and Assembly that represent another $600 million of investment and expect those phases to begin delivering in the latter part of '17 and early '18. 
From a capital standpoint, again, we expect to fund approximately $300 million of development and redevelopment with a mix of funds from operations, long-term debt and equity and our ATM, much of which we have taken care of the first quarter.  Finally, consistent with our practice, our guidance does not factor in any further acquisitions or dispositions that we may execute during the year. 
When you consider all that the company has going on, you will understand why we continue to emphasize that our guidance this year is a true range. factors that may drive us towards low end of that range include the timing of the anchor boxes to rent commencement; the potential for additional rent concessions at Pallas as lease the penthouses in the upper floor; the opportunistic capital raise that we completed the first quarter, front-ended a significant capital needs for the year. The ultimate resolution of the Sports Authority, as Don discussed, while none of our location made the initial closure list, we believe it is unlikely that The Sports Authority will continue to have this and that we may have the opportunity to get some of those locations back.
We continue to invest in our platform, as Don mentioned, both in systems and people as we drive decision-making closer to the real estate. These efforts may drive an additional $1 million to $2 million of annual G&A above our current run rate of $34 million to 35 million in annual basis. Even with that growth, it's still far below 5% of revenues.
And finally, the costs associated with back filling position have not been determined or forecast. Again, each one of these items that influence where we will come out in the range is a positive for the company and its long-term growth prospects, but they may impact where we land.
Before turning the call over to questions, I'd like to briefly thank Don. His friendship, counsel and support have meant a great deal to me over the last 18 years and now as I turn to the opportunity at Brixmore. Thank you, Don. 
I would also like to thank my partners at Federal, who are the best in the business: Chris Weilminster; Dawn Becker; Jeff Berkes; Jeff Malone; [indiscernible] Colson; John Pease, Deirdre Barry; and last, but certainty most, [ph] Melissa. Thanks to each you for inspiring me with your excellence and your commitment to the trust and its shareholders. 
With that, operator, I'd like to turn the call over to questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

componenttext: Congratulations, Jim, and hopefully you just didn't read off a list of the names of people you are going to target when you're at Brixmore. Question about Pike & Rose, I'm just curious what's driving the reduction in the stabilized yield. I got in late admittedly', so I'm not sure if you talked about it in your remarks.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, we did. It is really all about residential. As you know, that first phase and the second phase has a significant residential component to it. The bottom line is, we were too aggressive in thinking what we were going to be able to get for reside
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, we did. It is really all about residential. As you know, that first phase and the second phase has a significant residential component to it. The bottom line is, we were too aggressive in thinking what we were going to be able to get for residential rents. And the marketplace has an awful lot of supply on it, and the place is absolutely a construction zone and will be for some time. And so it's what I always worry about it with changing numbers like this is that there's a taint on the project itself, because there can't be. The project is going as well or better than we expected in terms of its acceptance, even in terms of its performance, rent performance on the residential side, compared to the marketplace. It's just that the marketplace is significantly lower than we had hoped and thought it would be when we underwrote this is. So it's all that. obviously the good side of that is we're not locking into 15-year deals or 20-year deals. These are 12-month leases, but it would be -- it just wouldn't be right for me to have the same expectations of being able to lease up the rest of the buildings we have on Phase 1 and the residential buildings in Phase 2 at rents that when I look at it right now with our team looks at it right now, we don't think we can hit. And that's what's causing that. I really don't want to see that as a failure of the project. It's market timing.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: and maybe to switch gears. I maybe wanted to circle back on decentralization plan. I think we even talked on the call maybe a year, 1.5 years ago about why it's very difficult for the industry, or seemingly difficult for the industry, to produce call it f
componenttext: and maybe to switch gears. I maybe wanted to circle back on decentralization plan. I think we even talked on the call maybe a year, 1.5 years ago about why it's very difficult for the industry, or seemingly difficult for the industry, to produce call it future leaders. And then you announced that plan. I guess I'm just curious what's -- what was the impetus for it? How -- or what do you think it accomplishes for Federal? And I guess not to bring it back to dollars and cents all the time, but how do you think we should be thinking about a ultimate effect on G&A if you sort of reorganize people?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's probably my favorite question, Jeff. The -- look, the bottom line is this company grew and has grown pretty darn consistently over the last 15 years in terms of its value, in terms of what it does for a living, in terms of its breadth and growth
componenttext: Yes, it's probably my favorite question, Jeff. The -- look, the bottom line is this company grew and has grown pretty darn consistently over the last 15 years in terms of its value, in terms of what it does for a living, in terms of its breadth and growth. The -- we had to effectively get management closer to the real estate because the real estate is so different. Managing a Pike and Rose and managing an Assembly Row and managing and having an opportunity like Sunset and Coco is just very different than the core shopping center business. So we needed to needed to align management more closely with the real estate business. That's our business. We are really not a portfolio manager. We look at it asset by asset. Now when you do that, there's obviously going to be incremental overhead to be able to set it up that way. And that overhead is incremental, not only on to use the hotel vernacular, front of the house stuff, but also back of the house systems and reporting, accounting all of that. We're in the middle of that transition, and that transition take some time. If you think about incremental few million a year, basically, we got to more than make up for that in incremental value. Well, where did that incremental value come from? It comes from every part of our business, first and foremost, by getting to things more quickly, by getting tenants to through the process of leasing to tenant coordination, to opening their doors to rent start. That's done a whole lot better if the leasing agent and the asset manager and the developer, tenant working together, there's a lot of that. Secondly, at that level, we'll know our markets better. We do know our markets better and closer so that -- and I'll give a couple of examples. We're talking about Brick Township now, Brick Plaza. Well, Brick is a bit shopping center in Brick New Jersey that we've owned for a long time. Part of the reason that we have been able to get to doing a better job at Brick Plaza's because of the A&P lease and we tell to that about that. But another part of the reason is because it's geographically further away. This helps us focus more on it. It helps us create business, and -- I could say that about at least 20 or 25 shopping centers. So this is truly an evolution of our business. It's an investment in the next decade where the combination of great products in terms of a mixed-use development that we're doing, with a more active and proactively managed core, together should make the few million dollars of incremental G&A nothing compared to the incremental value that we create. So that's what it is that we're trying to do.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Jim, and maybe just one last question. Don, do you have any specific goals going into ICSC? I think typically, you guys go in there with really 1 or 2 things you really want to walk away with ...
componenttext: Okay, Jim, and maybe just one last question. Don, do you have any specific goals going into ICSC? I think typically, you guys go in there with really 1 or 2 things you really want to walk away with ...

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the goals are not -- it's so funny. We don't -- and I hope everybody on this call gets this. It's -- you don't go into ICSC thinking you're getting leases done. The goals you go into ICSC before is to make sure that you bring as many people to the crit
componenttext: On the goals are not -- it's so funny. We don't -- and I hope everybody on this call gets this. It's -- you don't go into ICSC thinking you're getting leases done. The goals you go into ICSC before is to make sure that you bring as many people to the critical parts of the company that you can. So for us, it is our redevelopment pipeline and in core, it's our Florida stuff that we are going to be one thing everybody to see and understand. Is the future basis of Pike and Rose and Assembly as well as our West Coast asset. It's a focus on those things. It's not we are going to get lease this leased and that lease done. It just doesn't happen that way. What normally happens is somewhere in the next 30, 60, 90, 120 days after ICSC, there is a lot more deals that get done because they were germinated and taken to the next level at ICSC. That's what we're doing there.

componenttextpreview: Yes, just jump in on him if I miss anything on a be but as a remember, Jason we have four ANPs. One of those was assumed and is underway in terms of being billed out on Long Island at Fremont, which leaves 3 more. Melville Mall also on the island and I di
componenttext: Yes, just jump in on him if I miss anything on a be but as a remember, Jason we have four ANPs. One of those was assumed and is underway in terms of being billed out on Long Island at Fremont, which leaves 3 more. Melville Mall also on the island and I did not mention -- when I talked about the good stuff that's happening at Melville Mall with the signing of Dicks, for example, the last we have Melville Mall is this announced box. And we're making real good progress, but we are not a place where I can tell you it's a signed deal yet. And you'll like everything about that. The next one is at Brick, and we are again in spite of a much beaver redevelopment and remerchandising of the entire is center. And we're not as close as Melville, but making real good progress over the next couple of quarters there, I think. the final one is Troy, which is in New Jersey. And we're hopeful -- I shouldn't say exactly this way yet. I don't know whether we're going to backfill it or whether it is going to be a bigger redevelopments possibility there, which would include some residential and a more densely populated shopping center. Obviously if it comes to something like that, which would add the most value inside the to the community and figuring out if something like that is viable. That's what we're working on there. So that would be the last one of the 3 that you'll hear anything about, I would think.  And Santana, let's go to Santana. oh Yes, Valley Fair does what they're doing. And Jeff's on the phone. absolutely impact. they're talking about adding hundreds of thousands of square feet in a great node at a great place that will perform a very different function than what we do. And I wouldn't think -- we're confident that it wouldn't have a long-term impact on the property. But if they are leasing up that much space for that period of time, that has to, I would think, impact us. I just don't know by how much yet, nothing in any significant way whether they actually haven't started construction yet, when they will, where they will, what the timing is, I still don't know the answer to that there. But there could be an impact. I just can't quantify for you today, again, a short-term impact.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'd add to that, Don, Jason, we've known this is coming for some time. They got the entitlement before the recession. So over the last 4 or 5 years, we've been doing the walking and tapping that we need to do it Santana to put the property
componenttext: The only thing I'd add to that, Don, Jason, we've known this is coming for some time. They got the entitlement before the recession. So over the last 4 or 5 years, we've been doing the walking and tapping that we need to do it Santana to put the property in the best position as possible, including a lot of remerchandising of the stores on the street, which I'm sure you're familiar with, and continuing to build on the property, not least to which is adding more parking and buildings like 500 Santana Row when [indiscernible] occupancy during the week, will be available to retail and restaurant customers nights and weekends. So again, it's something we've been thinking about for many years now and doing what we can do to put ourselves to the best position. And what happens, happens and we'll deal with that the best we can.

componenttext: George, let me start with that. And Jim if you got something you want to add, please do. I can  tell you that obviously nobody knows really what the impact's going to be in terms of supply and demand. That will be what it's going to be. It has not changed our approach, which has always been very broad-based in terms of who it is that we want to invest. I mean, we have taken pretty regular trips to Europe, for example, to talk to generalists there. We have done that in New York in a broader way. We've always try to do that. And we've had some pretty good luck, frankly in getting investors interested in our story. Whether that's helped it or not, we'll know at some point after September after it gets put in place. But that's pretty much what we're doing. We -- obviously is a change in your world more than it is in terms of what we do and just with respect to what we do, wealth all it really seeing is we've been brought for a long time in terms of what we aim for.

componenttextpreview: It's interesting question because when you look at our leased matured schedule, the truth is that we always get them more space than what would be otherwise indicated by that. And if you look at our trend, and it's important to look at this trend over the
componenttext: It's interesting question because when you look at our leased matured schedule, the truth is that we always get them more space than what would be otherwise indicated by that. And if you look at our trend, and it's important to look at this trend over the last several quarters, of where we're signing our new deals and you've seen that average continue to climb, that gives you a sense of what the mark to market is, if you will, what we have in place. It's not perfect, but if you go back far enough, you're going to capture enough of a subset of the portfolio to look at that. And again, we've owned these assets for a long period of time, so we have vintage leases rolling every year. There isn't, as far as I can tell, not a particular year in which we've got a lot of vintage closing coming to market, if you will. So best thing to do to get a sense of that is to look at our marginal rents that we're signing each quarter.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Don, just a couple of quick questions. On the TSA outcome, if you were to get the stores back, are there certain centers that would be helped as it relates to maybe future redevelopment timing?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there are. Let's go through them. So here are the 5 centers, Assembly Square in the marketplace, right? So you know what's happening to that marketplace. First is because of what we're doing in the mixed-use project adjacent to it, it's been a very
componenttext: Well, there are. Let's go through them. So here are the 5 centers, Assembly Square in the marketplace, right? So you know what's happening to that marketplace. First is because of what we're doing in the mixed-use project adjacent to it, it's been a very positive thing. And certainly, the interest in that power center that's adjacent is significantly higher than it was before we built the project. So if we got that back, that'd be okay, good thing there. Brick Plaza is the next one, again, in the middle of a complete redo. The timing of that would be great in terms of the future of Brick Plaza. Crow Canyon, which is out on the West Coast and that's a smaller store out there, and then the latest when we did we did some years back. But nonetheless, it the last one, smaller in a center that we had -- we've just redone, which is a good thing in terms of the demand characteristics that you would have. Montrose Crossing is the fourth. That's the one directly across from Pike and Rose. That's over 35 acres where the section of the shopping center where they are would be dramatically impacted to the extent we can better merchandise that. And the last one is East Bay Bridge out in Emeryville, which is the rent's in place there are extremely low, and the upside would be terrific. And that's another place that we just put into new -- we've really remerchandised the shopping center price. As I sit back and look at TSA, this is a good tenant to work through this portfolio, and it's a better thing in all of the location that we have. Well, it's a lot of rent in the meantime. And so again, can you look through the short-term pain for long-term gain?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. the final question. Silver Line and Tyson's has been disruptor, providing a boon and an opportunity for some property owners, but changing certain patterns to the detriment of others. My understanding is that sales at Pike 7 have been weaker. are th
componenttext: Okay. the final question. Silver Line and Tyson's has been disruptor, providing a boon and an opportunity for some property owners, but changing certain patterns to the detriment of others. My understanding is that sales at Pike 7 have been weaker. are there things you can do their that change the view there or -- Or is there some view to the timing of future redevelopment that you would look towards the.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't -- first of all, the premise, I'm not with you on in terms of the impact of sales at Pike 7. Pike 7 is an amazing shopping center. Frankly, if sales were hit significantly during Pike 7, w they would have happened during the construction of this S
componenttext: I don't -- first of all, the premise, I'm not with you on in terms of the impact of sales at Pike 7. Pike 7 is an amazing shopping center. Frankly, if sales were hit significantly during Pike 7, w they would have happened during the construction of this Silver Line when basically all and they did in any significant way. But if they were, then we have a lower hurdle to be able to do a larger mixed-use project at the site which would be great. Having said that, your point, bigger point, stopping right there, look Pike 7 is a great asset for us. What we do there long term will only be positive. And part of the issue is it's so successful for what it is right now. And therefore, the hurdle is so high to do something better, financially better there. So that's Pike 7. Now take bigger premise and this, I think, is really important in terms of the judgment that we should there. I think you're right, the way this Silver Line is working through Tyson's, there are winners and there are losers. The type of projects that are being built there, there are winners and there are losers. We did not jump in say, oh God, we got to be the first one to market. We sat back. We renewed leases. We have pickup so that we were able to get space if we needed to. But we've created. We are disciplined. that particular asset has [indiscernible] to our benefit, that's only because we really ran it like a true real estate company would and real estate play, and not like a drunken sailor with respect to development, for Pete's sake, in terms of what it should be. Because I want -- I guess I want to get a little bit of credit for the discipline we showed in not jumping to the what the new Tyson's is going to be. Because as you just point out, it takes a long time with a major infrastructure change like this Silver Line is to figure out what Tyson should be. Thanks for giving me a choice by the way.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today for Federal Realty's first quarter 2016 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood; Jim Taylor; Dawn Becker; Jeff Berkes; Chris Weilminster, Jeff Mooallem; and Melissa Solis. They w
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today for Federal Realty's first quarter 2016 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood; Jim Taylor; Dawn Becker; Jeff Berkes; Chris Weilminster, Jeff Mooallem; and Melissa Solis. They will be available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. 
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results. Also, Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions. Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations can be attained. The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. These documents are available on our website at federalrealty.com.
And with that, I would like to turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of our first quarter 2016 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Leah, and good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today, and I look forward to seeing all or most of you in a few weeks at the NAREIT Conference in New York where we can talk more about our company and the many changes affecting our i
componenttext:
Thanks, Leah, and good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today, and I look forward to seeing all or most of you in a few weeks at the NAREIT Conference in New York where we can talk more about our company and the many changes affecting our industry. 
As most of you're aware by now, this will be the last earnings call of my good friend and colleague, Jim Taylor, will be on as the CFO of Federal. His team is certainly going to miss him, but I, for one, am generally -- genuinely proud of him and the opportunities he's going to get at Brixmor. Their board made a great choice. I'm also personally grateful for his many contributions to the company, his wise counsel and most importantly, his friendship; however, fleeting that [indiscernible]. 
Well, enough about Jim for the moment. Onward to the quarterly results and to our prospects for the future.
Really good quarter all the way around for us. FFO per share of $1.38, highest quarterly result of all time and 9.5% better than last year's quarter. 
Same-center growth of 4.2%, again, validating how important our redevelopment program is to us, but we don't expect to maintain this level for the year given the significant investment for the future initiatives that we have underway and lease termination fees that helped us this quarter by $600,000 or so. More on all that later. 
85 comparable deals done for nearly 400,000 feet of space at $33.53 per foot, 13% higher on a cash basis than the deals they replaced. That's up 23% on anchors, 10% on small shops. It's up 21% on new leases, 9% on renewals. It's up on all those metrics in the core shopping center business, in the mixed-use division and on the West Coast. Strong consistent leasing progress throughout our operations is our trademark, and we don't expect that to falter.
Overall portfolio occupancy at 94.1% leased, but only 92.7% occupied. Those numbers are down by 130 and 180 basis points, respectively, from a year ago, much of that through the inclusion of our lower occupancy acquisitions in South Florida and from the Clarion acquisition. Together, that's 1.5 million square feet added with a combined occupancy in the mid-80s. And of course, it's also the planned A&P and other vacancies that we talked about last quarter. 
Yet, we still had a record quarter. Growing earnings with decreasing occupancy, whether planned or unplanned, speaks volumes about our business plan and our company. Speaking of that occupancy, we made strong progress as it relates to proactively taking advantage of weak and failed tenants to improve the anchor merchandising assortment of our important shopping centers. That initiative took a big step forward this quarter, with the signing of T.J. Maxx to take over the failed Hudson Trail Outfitters space at Pentagon Row; with the signing of Dick's Sporting Goods at Melville Mall, which along with last quarter's Field & Stream deal and some real good stuff to come and not ready to talk about it yet, go a long way to returning Melville Mall on Long Island into something pretty special; and L.A. Fitness taking out a host of obsolete small shop space at Del Mar Village in Boca Raton. 3 great deals all at far higher rents than they replaced, actually nearly 30% higher in total, with far better retailers for our future and just the initial part of the redevelopment of these extremely well located shopping centers. Remember though, those are just signed leases, and the rent contributions won't start from them for some time as each particular center is being developed. All the evidence so far suggest that this proactive approach toward creating vacancy is going to work out overall as we'd hoped in creating far more relevant shopping centers, even though it will put pressure on same-store growth for the balance of '16 and '17.
I also want to report on strong progress on the lease up and rent start for the Phase 1 completions of our 3 big and active development projects. Let's talk about them individually.
At Assembly Row, the first phase is basically finished now, with the last group of office tenants moving into our small office building and the retailers and restaurants solidifying their only success. We've really moved on to Phase 2 execution, the first sign of which begins next month as the first Partners Healthcare employees begin populating the nearly complete 700,000 square foot building. Assembly has been so thoroughly accepted by the community as the place to live, work and shop. And we expect long-term value creation here to exceed our expectations. 
At Pike & Rose, we've leased up a ton of apartments since the end of the year and now stand at a Phase 1 residential percentage leased at 73%, heading into a strong summer leasing season. I couldn't be more pleased that the rate of lease up that we're achieving. Pike & Rose is creating a lot of buzz and getting a lot of recognition in the community, and I'm optimistic that we'll have the building basically full by year-end or soon thereafter as we forecasted. 
I'm not as optimistic that we'll hit our rent dollar forecast, given the rental rates we've been assuming for the higher floors in the Pallas Building. So far we've been close to our forecasted rents at $2.40, which are at a premium to the market. But because of construction, we basically have been leasing from the bottom up. But we're skeptical at this point that we'll be able to push rents on the higher floors to the extent we'd hoped, given the significant supply in the market and the fact that we remain a major construction site. We'll see over the next 6 to 8 months, but our initial yield may be under pressure by 50 basis points or so more on that with another quarter of leasing under our belt.
One thing that we're particularly confident about is the very real premium to market that we've been getting even during this initial phase -- lease up phase. Pallas average monthly rents to date of $2,500 a month or $2.40 a foot reflect a 20% premium over the North Bethesda, Rockville submarket. And for penthouses that we delivered at over $6,000 a month are setting new high watermarks for this market. As I said earlier, the pace of leasing is outpacing that competitive product, too. 
While excess supply in the market has caused us to miss our initial rent projections, and that is no doubt disappointing. It's also causing us to project more conservatively on Phase 2 as you'll know in our 8-K. The premium to that market clearly attainable because of the environment we're creating at Pike & Rose and the level of service we're providing is both validating and encouraging. We're building the right products for the future. Pike & Rose is going to be around for a long time and gets more and more integral for the community shopping, living and working habits every day. We'll have many opportunities to increase the residential income stream in the years ahead on these mostly 12-month leases.
And as a point in El Segundo, California, we're down in the last few leases and last half-dozen rent starts in a shopping center that was so clearly hit the bull's eye of what was missing in the market. This property will do nothing but get better and better over the years. 
And at 500 Santana Row, affectionately around here know as the Splunk Building, we've topped off that the $112 million project and remain on time and on budget.
So as I look back at the quarter and the execution in the business plan that we're also passionate about rent here and couldn't be more encouraged that we're on the right track to double our income in the next decade, but also realistic about the investment in people and real estate necessary to do it right and protect our downside in an inevitably cyclical business. 
The latest curveball lies in the uncertain future of Sports Authority. As you know, we have 5 locations, and none of them are in the closure list in the first round. We reserved most of our prepetition bankruptcy receivables of $400,000 in the first quarter and have been fully paid for April's rent. Now the latest conjecture of liquidation is a different story, of course. And depending on how it playdown and the specifics of each location, a short-term hit is likely and might affect our existing guidance if leases were immediately rejected as opposed to being assumed by another retailer. Having said that, we're quite confident that we would more than replace the cumulative rent, which totals $3.4 million annually triple-net basis, about $17.65 a foot and $4.8 million gross. The average market rent for a triple-net box lease in these locations exceeds $25, and we're already in conversations with replacement tenants just in case.
The other thing evolving change is, of course, changing shopping, living, working and entertainment habits of today's consumer. As you're all well aware, we have been, are and will continue to invest heavily in the best people, real estate and type of product that we believe puts us in the best position to capitalize on those changes. Downside is that in doing so we're making investments that have and will continue to dilute current earnings. 
And a couple of things on that front. First, the centralization effort that our company is in the middle of is progressing quite well with Jeff Mooallem settling into his role and in the process of building 4 quasi-independent geographic teams to grow our core shopping center business. Investment in incremental talent and IT systems infrastructure is now underway, and we would expect an incremental $1.5 million to $2 million annual investment to support this effort. 
Secondly, plans for our new Miami acquisitions, Sunset Place and CocoWalk, are progressing well and are being vetted by our senior team and partners. Decisions as to the direction and initial phases should go to investment committee later this year, at which point we'll lay out what we have in mind. In the meantime, we're heavily focused on grassroots engagement with the local communities and are increasingly optimistic that we'll be able to put forth viable and value creative changes at both locations. At Sunset, we'll need zoning changes that permit more height to come up with a viable plan. Fingers crossed.
And finally, the search for a senior business partner that carries CFO title for Federal is in full swing. I'm grateful for the very robust interest in joining our team that has followed Jim's announcement, and I've met with a number of terrific prospects who will be awesome partners to me and our senior team. I just don't want to rush that important decision, and I'm giving the process the attention and serious consideration it deserves. I'd hope to be prepared to make an announcement in this regard in the next 30 to 45 days. 
In the meantime, Melissa Solis is our Principal Accounting Officer. And as those of you who know Melissa know we remain in very good hands from an accounting and overall financial point of view.
Separately, I know that many on this call are friends and colleagues of James Milan, portfolio analyst at APG. We haven't put out a separate press release, but James will be joining us next month in the role of Vice President, Director of Finance, for the mixed-use division and will be relocating to our headquarters in Rockville, Maryland. We're thrilled to have him.
Now let me turn it over to Jim before answering your questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don and Leah, and good morning, everyone. As Don highlighted, our team delivered yet another record for the Trust in terms of FFO per share, which is $1.38, representing 9.5% growth over the prior year quarter. In a quarter where we continue to
componenttext:
Thank you, Don and Leah, and good morning, everyone. As Don highlighted, our team delivered yet another record for the Trust in terms of FFO per share, which is $1.38, representing 9.5% growth over the prior year quarter. In a quarter where we continue to invest in the future through commencing future development phases, adding to our team, taking down box vacancy, et cetera, we are particularly pleased with the bottom line results driven by our operations, leasing, acquisition and development teams.
Turning to the numbers. Overall property operating income grew at 7.9% over the prior year, even with the decline of 130 basis points of occupancy, reflecting the higher anchor rollovers we've discussed. Our core portfolio continued to be a significant driver of our COI growth. That core grew at 4.2% on a same-store basis, including redevelopment. This quarter, the downtime associated with anchor rollover produced about 130 basis points drag. We highlighted this trend the last 2 quarters. And as I will discuss further in guidance, we expect this rollover drag to continue this year. 
Our first phases of Assembly Row and Pike & Rose contributed approximately $4.5 million of POI in the quarter, up on a sequential basis, as the Pallas high-rise opening approached breakeven occupancy and office spaces continue to rent in that. Finally, our acquisitions of Coco and Sunset Place, which are performing very well against our acquisition underwriting, also contributed significantly to overall POI growth. 
G&A remains flat on a sequential basis at $8 million for the quarter and down year-over-year principally to higher transaction costs in 2015 with respect to our San Antonio Center acquisition. We do expect our G&A line item to grow as we continue to invest in our platform.
Interest expense declined $400,000, reflecting the lower average rate achieved through our refinancings during the year, offset by lower capitalized interest during the quarter as we continue to place development into service. 
Again, bottom line, FFO grew at 9.5% for the quarter, which is above our long-term plan. That absolute bottom line performance while we continue to invest in the future, it's something we take great pride in. 
From a balance sheet perspective, we raised approximately $182 million of equity through an overnight as well as issuances under our ATM during the quarter at a collective weighted average price of $149.18. This represents over half of equity we planned to raise this year. 
We ended the quarter with $53 million drawn under our $600 million revolver, which we upsized after the quarter to $800 million and extended to 2020 while reducing our borrowing costs by 10 basis points. Our net debt to EBITDA was 5.3x, and our weighted average tenor was almost 10 years versus the peer average closer to 5, providing us maximum flexibility and liquidity to fund all the value creation that we have underway.
Turning to 2016, we affirm the previously given range of FFO per share of $5.65 to $5.71, a range of growth of approximately 6% to 7% or slightly below our long-term plan. As we discussed last quarter, this is a true range that will be impacted by several variables during the year. Again, the targeted box recapture and rollover vacancy drives a significant amount of drag in the year. That drag was offset this quarter by some positive timing items, which included marketing expense recoveries as well as higher year-over-year term fees of $600,000, as Don mentioned. Given that, we do expect same-store NOI will moderate in the second and third quarters of this year.
As Don discussed in his remarks, we're pleased to announce the signing of T.J. Maxx at Pentagon, The Dick's Sporting Goods lease at Melville and the L.A. Fitness lease at Del Mar, all of which, as he stated, will unlock significant value at these centers. Overall, our leasing team is making great progress under a captured box basis, which we will continue to report on over the coming quarters. 
In addition to this rollover, as discussed in prior quarters, there are several other investments in growth to consider from a timing perspective as you look at the year. First, our leasing pace at Pallas continues to go well with current occupancy for the building alone at just over 60% and expected stabilization occurring in the fourth quarter. The office space at Pike & Rose and Assembly, which represents approximately $80 million of investments, is fully committed and leased. And we'll start seeing the rent commencing throughout this year and early next as tenants take occupancy. 500 Santana Row, the Splunk Building, which represents approximately $115 million of investment, is of course 100% preleased and will deliver in the first quarter and rent commence in 2017. The Point redevelopment at Plaza El Segundo continues to perform exceptionally well and is expected to stabilize in the fourth quarter of this year. 
Our acquisition of our joint venture partner's 70% interest in 6 core assets is expected to be neutral this year after transaction costs in the sale of Courtyard Shops. We expect this acquisition to contribute approximately $0.02 to $0.03 in 2017.
We are well underway of the second phases of Pike & Rose and Assembly that represent another $600 million of investment and expect those phases to begin delivering in the latter part of '17 and early '18. 
From a capital standpoint, again, we expect to fund approximately $300 million of development and redevelopment with a mix of funds from operations, long-term debt and equity under our ATM, much of which we have taken care of in the first quarter. Finally, consistent with our practice, our guidance does not factor in any further acquisitions or dispositions that we may execute during the year. 
When you consider all that the company has going on, you will understand why I continue to emphasize that our guidance this year is a true range. In fact, factors that may drive us towards the low end of that range include: The timing of the anchor box backfill to rent commencement; the potential for additional rent concessions at Pallas as lease penthouses in the upper floor; the opportunistic capital raise that we completed in the first quarter front ended a significant part of our capital needs for the year. The ultimate resolution of the Sports Authority, as Don discussed, while none of our locations have been on the initial closure list, we believe it is unlikely that The Sports Authority will continue as is and that we may have the opportunity to get some of those locations back.
We continue to invest in our platform, as Don mentioned, both in systems and people as we drive decision-making closer to the real estate. These efforts may drive an additional $1 million to $2 million of annual G&A above our current assumed run rate of $34 million to $35 million on an annual basis. Even with that growth, it's still far below 5% of revenues.
And finally, the costs associated with backfilling my position have not been determined or forecast. Again, each one of these items that influence where we will come out in the range is a positive for the company and its long-term growth prospects, but they may impact where we land.
Before turning the call over to questions, I'd like to briefly thank Don for his friendship, counsel and support have meant a great deal to me over the last 18 years and now as I turn to the opportunity at Brixmore. Thank you, Don. 
I would also like to thank my partners at Federal, who are the best in the business: Chris Weilminster; Dawn Becker; Jeff Berkes; Don Briggs; Jeff Mooallem; Wendy Seher; Debbie Colson; John T.; Deirdre; Barry; and last, but certainty most, Melissa. Thanks to each of you for inspiring me with your excellence and your commitment to the Trust and its shareholders. 
With that, operator, I'd like to turn the call over to questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.
