headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today for Federal Realty's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood; Jim Taylor; Dawn Becker; Jeff Berkes; Chris Weilminster, Jeff Mooallem; and Melissa Solis. They w
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today for Federal Realty's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood; Jim Taylor; Dawn Becker; Jeff Berkes; Chris Weilminster, Jeff Mooallem; and Melissa Solis. They will be available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. 
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results. Also, Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations can be attained. The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. These documents are available on our website at federalrealty.com.
And with that, I would like to turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of our first quarter 2016 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Leah, and good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today, and I look forward to seeing all or most of you in a few weeks at the NAREIT Conference in New York where we can talk more about our company and the many changes affecting our i
componenttext:
Thanks, Leah, and good morning, everyone. Thank you all for joining us today, and I look forward to seeing all or most of you in a few weeks at the NAREIT Conference in New York where we can talk more about our company and the many changes affecting our industry. 
As most of you are aware by now, this will be the last earnings call that my good friend and colleague, Jim Taylor, will be on as the CFO of Federal. His team is certainly going to miss him, but I, for one, am  genuinely proud of him and the opportunities he's going to get at Brixmor. Their board made a great choice. I'm also personally grateful for his many contributions to the company, his wise counsel and most importantly, his friendship; however, fleeting that might have been.
Well, enough about Jim for the moment. Onward to the quarterly results and to our prospects for the future.
Really good quarter all the way around for us. FFO per share of $1.38, highest quarterly result of all time and 9.5% better than last year's quarter. 
Same-center growth of 4.2%, again, validating how important our redevelopment program is to us, but we don't expect to maintain this level for the year given the significant investment for the future initiatives that we have underway and lease termination fees that helped us this quarter by $600,000 or so. More on all that later. 
85 comparable deals done for nearly 400,000 feet of space at $33.53 per foot, 13% higher on a cash basis than the deals they replaced. That's up 23% on anchors, 10% on small shops. It's up 21% on new leases, 9% on renewals. It's up on all those metrics in the core shopping center business, in the mixed-use division and on the West Coast. Strong consistent leasing progress throughout our operations is our trademark, and we don't expect that to falter.
Overall portfolio occupancy at 94.1% leased, but only 92.7% occupied. Those numbers are down by 130 and 180 basis points, respectively, from a year ago, much of that through the inclusion of our lower occupancy acquisitions in South Florida and from the Clarion acquisition. Together, that's 1.5 million square feet added with a combined occupancy in the mid-80s. And of course, it's also the planned A&P and other vacancies that we talked about last quarter. 
Yet, we still had a record quarter. Growing earnings with decreasing occupancy, whether planned or unplanned, speaks volumes about our business plan and our company. Speaking of that occupancy, we made strong progress as it relates to proactively taking advantage of weak and failed tenants to improve the anchor merchandising at certain of our important shopping centers. That initiative took a big step forward this quarter, with the signing of T.J. Maxx to take over the failed Hudson Trail Outfitters space at Pentagon Row; with the signing of Dick's Sporting Goods at Melville Mall, which along with last quarter's Field & Stream deal and some real good stuff to come, I'm not ready to talk about it yet, go a long way to returning Melville Mall on Long Island into something pretty special; and L.A. Fitness taking out a host of obsolete small shop space at Del Mar Village in Boca Raton. Three great deals all at far higher rents than they replaced, actually nearly 30% higher in total, with far better retailers for our future as just the initial part of the redevelopment of these extremely well located shopping centers. Remember though, those are just signed leases, and the rent contributions won't start from them for some time as each particular center is being developed. All the evidence so far suggests that this proactive approach toward creating vacancy is going to work out overall as we'd hoped in creating far more relevant shopping centers, even though it will put pressure on same-store growth for the balance of '16 and '17.
I also want to report on strong progress on the lease up and rent start for the Phase 1 completions of our 3 big and active development projects. Let's talk about them individually.
At Assembly Row, the first phase is basically finished now, with the last group of office tenants moving into our small office building and the retailers and restaurants solidifying their only success. We've really moved on to Phase 2 execution, the first sign of which begins next month as the first Partners Healthcare employees begin populating the nearly complete 700,000 square foot building. Assembly has been so thoroughly accepted by the community as the place to live, work and shop, that we expect long-term value creation here to exceed our expectations. 
At Pike & Rose, we've leased up a ton of apartments since the end of the year and now stand at a Phase 1 residential percentage leased at 73%, heading into a strong summer leasing season. I couldn't be more pleased that the rate of lease up that we're achieving. Pike & Rose is creating a lot of buzz and getting a lot of recognition in the community, and I'm optimistic that we'll have the building basically full by year-end or soon thereafter as we forecasted. 
I'm not as optimistic that we'll hit our rent dollar forecast, given the rental rates we've been assuming for the higher floors in the Pallas Building. So far we've been close to our forecasted rents at $2.40, which are at a premium to the market. But because of construction, we basically have been leasing from the bottom up. But we're skeptical at this point that we'll be able to push rents on the higher floors to the extent we'd hoped, given the significant supply in the market and the fact that we remain a major construction site. We'll see over the next 6 to 8 months, but our initial yield may be under pressure by 50 basis points or so, more on that with another quarter of leasing under our belt.
One thing that we're particularly confident about is the very real premium to market that we've been getting even during this initial lease up phase. Pallas average monthly rents to date of $2,500 a month or $2.40 a foot reflect a 20% premium over the North Bethesda, Rockville submarket. And for penthouses that we delivered at over $6,000 a month are setting new high watermarks for this market. As I said earlier, the pace of leasing is outpacing that competitive product, too. 
While excess supply in the market has caused us to miss our initial rent projections, and that is no doubt disappointing. It's also causing us to project more conservatively on Phase 2 as you'll note in our 8-K. The premium to that market clearly attainable because of the environment we're creating at Pike & Rose and the level of service we're providing is both validating and encouraging. We're building the right products for the future. Pike & Rose is going to be around for a long time and gets more and more integral to the community shopping, living and working habits every day. We'll have many opportunities to increase the residential income stream in the years ahead on these mostly 12-month leases.
And as a point in El Segundo, California, we're down to the last few leases and last half-dozen rent starts in a shopping center that was so clearly hit the bull's eye of what was missing in the market. This property will do nothing but get better and better over the years. 
And at 500 Santana Row, affectionately around here know as the Splunk Building, we've topped off that $112 million project and remain on time and on budget.
So as I look back at the quarter and the execution in the business plan that we're also passionate about around here I couldn't be more encouraged that we're on the right track to double our income in the next decade, but also realistic about the investment in people and real estate necessary to do it right and protect our downside in an inevitably cyclical business. 
The latest curveball lies in the uncertain future of Sports Authority. As you know, we have 5 locations, and none of them are on the closure list in the first round. We reserved most of our prepetition bankruptcy receivables out $400,000 in the first quarter and have been fully paid for April's rent. Now the latest conjecture of liquidation is a different story, of course. And depending on how it plays out and the specifics of each location, a short-term hit is likely and might affect our existing guidance if leases were immediately rejected as opposed to being assumed by another retailer. Having said that, we're quite confident that we would more than replace the cumulative rent, which totals $3.4 million annually triple-net basis, about $17.65 a foot and $4.8 million gross. The average market rent for a triple-net box lease in these locations exceeds $25, and we're already in conversations with replacement tenants just in case.
The other thing evolving change is, of course, changing shopping, living, working and entertainment habits of today's consumer. As you're all well aware, we have been, are and will continue to invest heavily in the best people, real estate and type of product that we believe puts us in the best position to capitalize on those changes. Downside is that in doing so we're making investments that have and will continue to dilute current earnings. 
And a couple of things on that front. First, the decentralization effort that our company is in the middle of is progressing quite well with Jeff Mooallem settling into his role and in the process of building 4 quasi-independent geographic teams to grow our core shopping center business. Investment in incremental talent and IT systems infrastructure is now underway, and we would expect an incremental $1.5 million to $2 million annual investment to support this effort. 
Secondly, plans for our new Miami acquisitions, Sunset Place and CocoWalk, are progressing well and are being vetted by our senior team and partners. Decisions as to the direction and initial phases should go to investment committee later this year, at which point we'll lay out what we have in mind. In the meantime, we're heavily focused on grassroots engagement with the local communities and are increasingly optimistic that we'll be able to put forth viable and value creative changes at both locations. At Sunset, we'll need zoning changes that permit more height to come up with a viable plan. Fingers crossed.
And finally, the search for a senior business partner that carries the CFO title for Federal is in full swing. I'm grateful for the very robust interest in joining our team that has followed Jim's announcement, and I've met with a number of terrific prospects who would be awesome partners to me and our senior team. I just don't want to rush that important decision, and I'm giving the process the attention and serious consideration it deserves. I'd hope to be prepared to make an announcement in this regard in the next 30 to 45 days. 
In the meantime, Melissa Solis is our Principal Accounting Officer. And as those of you who know Melissa know we remain in very good hands from an accounting and overall financial point of view.
Separately, I know that many on this call are friends and colleagues of James Milam, portfolio analyst at APG. We haven't put out a separate press release, but James will be joining us next month in the role of Vice President, Director of Finance, for the mixed-use division and will be relocating to our headquarters here in Rockville, Maryland. We're thrilled to have him.
Now let me turn it over to Jim before answering your questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don and Leah, and good morning, everyone. As Don highlighted, our team delivered yet another record for the Trust in terms of FFO per share, which at $1.38, represented 9.5% growth over the prior year quarter. In a quarter where we continue to
componenttext:
Thank you, Don and Leah, and good morning, everyone. As Don highlighted, our team delivered yet another record for the Trust in terms of FFO per share, which at $1.38, represented 9.5% growth over the prior year quarter. In a quarter where we continue to invest in the future through commencing future development phases, adding to our team, taking down box vacancy, et cetera, we are particularly pleased with the bottom line results driven by our operations, leasing, acquisition and development teams.
Turning to the numbers. Overall property operating income grew at 7.9% over the prior year, even with the decline of 130 basis points of occupancy, reflecting the higher anchor rollovers we've discussed. Our core portfolio continued to be a significant driver of our COI growth. That core grew at 4.2% on a same-store basis, including redevelopment. This quarter, the downtime associated with anchor rollover produced about 130 basis points drag. We highlighted this trend the last 2 quarters. And as I will discuss further in guidance, we expect this rollover drag to continue this year. 
Our first phases of Assembly Row and Pike & Rose contributed approximately $4.5 million of POI in the quarter, up on a sequential basis, as the Pallas high-rise opening approached breakeven occupancy and office spaces continue to rent commence. Finally, our acquisitions of Coco and Sunset Place, which are performing very well against our acquisition underwriting, also contributed significantly to overall POI growth. 
G&A remains flat on a sequential basis at $8 million for the quarter and down year-over-year principally to higher transaction costs in 2015 with respect to our San Antonio Center acquisition. We do expect our G&A line item to grow as we continue to invest in our platform.
Interest expense declined $400,000, reflecting the lower average rate achieved through our refinancings during the year, offset by lower capitalized interest during the quarter as we continue to place development into service. 
Again, bottom line, FFO grew at 9.5% for the quarter, which is above our long-term plan. That absolute bottom line performance while we continue to invest in the future, is something we take great pride in. 
From a balance sheet perspective, we raised approximately $182 million of equity through an overnight as well as issuances under our ATM during the quarter at a collective weighted average price of $149.18. This represents over half of equity we planned to raise this year. 
We ended the quarter with $53 million drawn under our $600 million revolver, which we upsized after the quarter to $800 million and extended to 2020 while reducing our borrowing costs by 10 basis points. Our net debt to EBITDA was 5.3x, and our weighted average tenor was almost 10 years versus the peer average closer to 5, providing us maximum flexibility and liquidity to fund all the value creation that we have underway.
Turning to 2016, we affirm the previously given range of FFO per share of $5.65 to $5.71, a range of growth of approximately 6% to 7% or slightly below our long-term plan. As we discussed last quarter, this is a true range that will be impacted by several variables during the year. Again, the targeted box recapture and rollover vacancy drives a significant amount of drag in the year. That drag was offset this quarter by some positive timing items, which included marketing expense recoveries as well as higher year-over-year term fees of $600,000, as Don mentioned. Given that, we do expect same-store NOI will moderate in the second and third quarters of this year.
As Don discussed in his remarks, we're pleased to announce the signing of T.J. Maxx at Pentagon, The Dick's Sporting Goods lease at Melville and the L.A. Fitness lease at Del Mar, all of which, as he stated, will unlock significant value at these centers. Overall, our leasing team is making great progress under a captured box basis, which we will continue to report on over the coming quarters. 
In addition to this rollover, as discussed in prior quarters, there are several other investments in growth to consider from a timing perspective as you look at the year. First, our leasing pace at Pallas continues to go well with current occupancy for that building alone at just over 60% and expected stabilization occurring in the fourth quarter. The office space at Pike & Rose and Assembly, which represents approximately $80 million of investments, is fully committed and leased. And we'll start seeing the rent commencing throughout this year and early next as tenants take occupancy. 500 Santana Row, the Splunk Building, which represents approximately $115 million of investment, is of course 100% preleased and will deliver in the fourth quarter and rent commence in 2017. The Point redevelopment at Plaza El Segundo continues to perform exceptionally well and is expected to stabilize in the fourth quarter of this year. 
Our acquisition of our joint venture partner's 70% interest in 6 core assets is expected to be neutral this year after transaction costs in the sale of Courtyard Shops. We expect this acquisition to contribute approximately $0.02 to $0.03 in 2017.
We are well underway of the second phases of Pike & Rose and Assembly that represent another $600 million of investment and expect those phases to begin delivering in the latter part of '17 and early '18. 
From a capital standpoint, again, we expect to fund approximately $300 million of development and redevelopment with a mix of funds from operations, long-term debt and equity under our ATM, much of which we have taken care of in the first quarter. Finally, consistent with our practice, our guidance does not factor in any further acquisitions or dispositions that we may execute during the year. 
When you consider all that the company has going on, you will understand why I continue to emphasize that our guidance this year is a true range. In fact, factors that may drive us towards the low end of that range include: The timing of the anchor box backfill to rent commencement; the potential for additional rent concessions at Pallas as we lease penthouses in the upper floor; the opportunistic capital raise that we completed in the first quarter front ended a significant part of our capital needs for the year. The ultimate resolution of the Sports Authority, as Don discussed, while none of our locations have been on the initial closure list, we believe it is unlikely that The Sports Authority will continue as is and that we may have the opportunity to get some of those locations back.
We continue to invest in our platform, as Don mentioned, both in systems and people as we drive decision-making closer to the real estate. These efforts may drive an additional $1 million to $2 million of annual G&A above our current assumed run rate of $34 million to $35 million on an annual basis. Even with that growth, it's still far below 5% of revenues.
And finally, the costs associated with backfilling my position have not been determined or forecast. Again, each one of these items that influence where we will come out in the range is a positive for the company and its long-term growth prospects, but they may impact where we land.
Before turning the call over to questions, I'd like to briefly thank Don for his friendship, counsel and support, they have meant a great deal to me over the last 18 years and now as I turn to the opportunity at Brixmor. Thank you, Don. 
I would also like to thank my partners at Federal, who are the best in the business: Chris Weilminster; Dawn Becker; Jeff Berkes; Don Briggs; Jeff Mooallem; Wendy Seher; Debbie Colson; John T.; Deirdre [ph] ; Barry; and last, but certainty most, Melissa. Thanks to each of you for inspiring me with your excellence and your commitment to the Trust and its shareholders. 
With that, operator, I'd like to turn the call over to questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations, Jim, and hopefully you didn't just read off a list of the names of people you are going to target when you're at Brixmor. Question about Pike & Rose, I'm just curious what's driving the reduction in the stabilized yield. I got on a minute
componenttext: Congratulations, Jim, and hopefully you didn't just read off a list of the names of people you are going to target when you're at Brixmor. Question about Pike & Rose, I'm just curious what's driving the reduction in the stabilized yield. I got on a minute late so I'm not sure if you guys talked about that in your remarks.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, we did. It is really all about residential. As you know, that first phase and the second phase has a significant residential component to it. The bottom line is, we were too aggressive in thinking what we were going to be able to get for reside
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, we did. It is really all about residential. As you know, that first phase and the second phase has a significant residential component to it. The bottom line is, we were too aggressive in thinking what we were going to be able to get for residential rents. And the marketplace has an awful lot of supply on it, and the place is absolutely a construction zone and will be for some time. And so it's what I always worry about with -- when changing numbers like this is that there's a taint on the project itself, because there can't be. The project is going as well or better than we expected in terms of its acceptance, even in terms of its performance -- rent performance on the residential side, compared to the marketplace. It's just that the marketplace is significantly lower than we had hoped and thought it would be when we underwrote this. So it's all that. Now obviously, the good side of that is we're not locking into 15-year deals or 20-year deals. These are 12-month leases, but it would be -- it just wouldn't be right for me to have the same expectations of being able to lease up the rest of the buildings we have in Phase 1 and the residential building in Phase 2 at rents that when I look at it right now, when our team looks at it right now, we don't think we can hit. And that's what's causing that. I really don't want you to see that as a failure of the project. It's market timing.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe to switch gears. I wanted to maybe circle back on decentralization plan. I think we've even talked on the call maybe a year, 1.5 year ago about why it sort of difficult for the industry, or seemingly difficult for the industry, to produce -- cal
componenttext: And maybe to switch gears. I wanted to maybe circle back on decentralization plan. I think we've even talked on the call maybe a year, 1.5 year ago about why it sort of difficult for the industry, or seemingly difficult for the industry, to produce -- call it future leaders. And then you announced that plan. I guess I'm just curious what's the -- what was the impetus for it? How do you -- or what do you think it accomplishes for Federal? And I guess not to bring it back to dollars and cents all the time, but how do you think we should be thinking about the ultimate effect on G&A as you sort of reorganize people?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's probably my favorite question, Jeff. The -- look, the bottom line is this company grew and has grown pretty darn consistently over the last 15 years in terms of its value, in terms of what it does for a living, in terms of its breadth and growth
componenttext: Yes, it's probably my favorite question, Jeff. The -- look, the bottom line is this company grew and has grown pretty darn consistently over the last 15 years in terms of its value, in terms of what it does for a living, in terms of its breadth and growth. The -- we had to effectively get management closer to the real estate because the real estate is so different. Managing at Pike & Rose and managing at Assembly Row and managing and having an opportunity like Sunset and Coco is just very different than the core shopping center business. So we needed to do, we needed to align management more closely with the real estate business. That's our business. We are really not a portfolio manager. We look at it asset by asset. Now when you do that, there's obviously going to be incremental overhead to be able to set it up that way. And that overhead is incremental, not only on the -- to use the hotel vernacular, front of the house stuff, but also back of the house, systems and reporting, accounting all of that. We're in the middle of that transition, and that transition takes some time. If you think about an incremental few million a year, basically, we got to more than make up for that in incremental value. Well, where would that incremental value come from? It comes in every part of our business, first and foremost, by getting to things more quickly, by getting tenants to -- through the process of leasing, to tenant coordinations, opening their doors to rent start. That's done a whole lot better if the leasing agent and the asset manager and the developer, tenant coordinator are all working together. There's a lot of that. Secondly, down at that level, we'll know our markets better. We do know our markets better and closer so that -- and I'll give a couple of examples. We're talking about Brick Township right now, Brick Plaza. Well, Brick is a great shopping center in Brick, New Jersey, that we've owned for a long time. Part of the reason that we haven't been able to get to doing a better job at Brick Plaza is because of the A&P lease, and we talk to that -- about that. But another part of the reason is because it's geographically further away. This helps us focus more on it. It helps us create business, and then -- I could say that about at least 20 or 25 shopping centers. So this is truly an evolution of our business. It's an investment in the next decade, where the combination of great products in terms of mixed-use development that we're doing with a more active and proactively managed core, together should make the few million dollars of incremental G&A nothing compared to the incremental value that we create. So that's what it is that we're trying to do.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe just one last question. Don, do you have any specific goals going into ICSC? I think typically you guys go in there with really 1 or 2 things you really want to walk away with.
componenttext: And maybe just one last question. Don, do you have any specific goals going into ICSC? I think typically you guys go in there with really 1 or 2 things you really want to walk away with.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The goals are not -- it's so funny. We don't -- and I hope everybody on this call gets this. It's -- you don't go into ICSC thinking you're getting leases done. The goals you go into ICSC, before, is to make sure that you bring as many people to the criti
componenttext: The goals are not -- it's so funny. We don't -- and I hope everybody on this call gets this. It's -- you don't go into ICSC thinking you're getting leases done. The goals you go into ICSC, before, is to make sure that you bring as many people to the critical parts of the company that you can. So for us, it is our redevelopment pipeline and in core, it's our Florida stuff that we are going to be wanting everybody to see and understand. It's the future phases of Pike & Rose and Assembly as well as our West Coast assets. It's a focus on those things. It's not, "We're going to get lease this lease done and that lease done." Because it's just doesn't happen that way. What normally happens is somewhere in the next 30, 60, 90, or 120 days after ICSC, there is a lot more deals that get done because they were germinated and taken to the next level at ICSC. That's what we're doing there.

componenttext: In a -- here's where we are. So as you remember, you may remember at Darien we're talking about, Stop & Shop controls the corner of that shopping center until 2020-something, 2023, something like that. We have become far more encouraged though that there will be a way to work with Stop & Shop. So that long before that period of time, we'll be able to create a specialty shopping center and I am hopeful with residential as part of that plan over on top and around to be able to really create a great community shopping center there. As you know, lots of work to do with the community itself, with the entitlement process and certainly then with tenants like Stop & Shop and others in the center. So I'm not ready to put out -- it's not on the redevelopment schedule yet. I think it will be on the redevelopment schedule to the extent we can make headway with the community. And so far, so good.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones for me. I'll just ask them both at once because they will probably quick ones. A&P, I think you talked about on last call. I just wondered generically if you could kind of walk through the progress you're making and maybe just what you'r
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones for me. I'll just ask them both at once because they will probably quick ones. A&P, I think you talked about on last call. I just wondered generically if you could kind of walk through the progress you're making and maybe just what you're seeing from market rents versus where the rents were in place. And then just jumping over to Santana, Westfield, the mall is going to have a big redevelopment and I'm wondering how you see that impacting Santana and if that changes the way you merchandise?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff jump in if I miss anything on A&P. But as you remember, Jason, we have four A&Ps. One of those was assumed and is underway in terms of being built out on Long Island at Greenlawn, which leaves 3 more. Melville Mall also on the island and I did n
componenttext: Yes, Jeff jump in if I miss anything on A&P. But as you remember, Jason, we have four A&Ps. One of those was assumed and is underway in terms of being built out on Long Island at Greenlawn, which leaves 3 more. Melville Mall also on the island and I did not mention -- when I talk about the good stuff that's happening at Melville Mall today with the signing of Dick's, for example, the last space that we have at Melville Mall is the former Waldbaum's box. We're making real good progress, but we are not a place where I can tell you it's a signed deal yet. And you'll like everything about that. The next one is at Brick where again it's part of a much, much bigger redevelopment and remerchandising of the entire center. And we're not as close as Melville, but making real good progress. We'll have something to say over the next couple of quarters there, I think. And the final one is Troy, which is in New Jersey. And we're hopeful -- I shouldn't say it exactly this way yet. I don't know whether we're going to backfill it or whether this is going to be a bigger redevelopment possibility there, which would include some residential and a more densely populated shopping center. Obviously, if it comes to something like that, which would add the most value, which I would love. There's a lot of work to do with respect to the community and figuring out if something like that is viable. That's what we're working on there. So that would be the last one of the 3 that you'll hear anything about I would think. Oh and then Santana, let's go to Santana. Oh yes, if Valley Fair does what they're doing and Jeff's on the phone, there'll absolutely be an impact. They're talking about adding hundreds of thousands of square feet in a great node at a great place that will perform a very different function than what we do. And I wouldn't think -- we're confident that it wouldn't have a long-term impact on the property. But if they are leasing up that much space for that period of time, that has to, I would think, impact us. I just don't know by how much yet, nothing in any significant way whether they actually -- they haven't started construction yet, where they will, when they will, what the timing is that still I just don't know the answer to that. But there would be an impact. I just can't quantify it for you today; again, a short-term impact.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only thing I'd add to that, Don, Jason, we've known this is coming for some time. They got the entitlement before the recession. So over the last 4 or 5 years, we've been doing the blocking and tackling that we need to do at Santana to put the pro
componenttext: And the only thing I'd add to that, Don, Jason, we've known this is coming for some time. They got the entitlement before the recession. So over the last 4 or 5 years, we've been doing the blocking and tackling that we need to do at Santana to put the property in the best position as possible, including a lot of remerchandising of the stores on the street, which I'm sure you're familiar with, and continuing to build out the property not the least of which is adding more parking in buildings like 500 Santana Row that when Splunk is not in occupancy during the week we'll be available to retail to restaurant customers nights and weekends. So again, it's something we've been thinking about for many years now and doing what we can do to put ourselves in the best position. And when it happens, it happens and we'll deal with it as best we can.

componenttext: George Hoglund on for Tayo. Just one question in terms of REITs getting their own GIC sector later this year. Have you been getting more inquiries from generalist investors? And have you been doing anything sort of planning to market the company differently or preparing for those inquiries?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, let me start with that. And Jim if you got something you want to add, please do. I can tell you that -- obviously, nobody knows really what the impact is going to be in terms of supply and demand. And that will be what it's going to be. It has not
componenttext: George, let me start with that. And Jim if you got something you want to add, please do. I can tell you that -- obviously, nobody knows really what the impact is going to be in terms of supply and demand. And that will be what it's going to be. It has not changed our approach, which has always been very broad-based in terms of who it is that we want to invest. I mean, we have taken pretty regular trips to Europe, for example, to talk to generalists there. We have done that in New York in a broader way. We've always tried to do that. And we've had some pretty good luck frankly in getting generalists, investors interested in our story. Whether this helps it or not, we'll know at some point after September, after it gets put in place. But that's pretty much what we're doing. We -- obviously it's a change in your world more than it is in terms of what we do and just with respect to what we do; all I'm really saying is we've been broad for a long time in terms of who we aim for.

componenttext: Okay. And when you look at your lease expiration schedule, what percentage of your expiring leases is considered as vintage leases? And over the next few years, how much of an impact do you think this is going to have on the blended rent spread?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's an interesting question because when you look at our lease maturity schedule, the truth is that we always get to more space than what would be otherwise indicated by that. And if you look at our trend, and it's important to look at this trend over th
componenttext: It's an interesting question because when you look at our lease maturity schedule, the truth is that we always get to more space than what would be otherwise indicated by that. And if you look at our trend, and it's important to look at this trend over the last several quarters, of where we're signing our new deals and you've seen that average continue to climb. That gives you a sense of what the mark-to-market is, if you will, over we have in place. It's not perfect, but if you go back far enough, you're going to capture enough of a subset of the portfolio to look at that. And again, we've owned these assets for a long period of time. So we have vintage leases rolling every year. There isn't, as far as I can tell, not a particular year in which we've got a lot of vintage closing coming to market, if you will. So best thing to do to get a sense of that though again is to look at our marginal rents that we're signing each quarter.

componenttext: I think, I think everyone would be wise to consider this is a range and to think about the lower end of the range. It's hard at this point to handicap everything. But all the items that I referred to again represent investments in the future, but certainly would be a drag on where we end up for the year.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from Chris Lucas with Capital One Securities.
componenttext: And our last question comes from Chris Lucas with Capital One Securities.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, just a couple of quick questions. On the TSA outcome, if you were to get the stores back, are there certain centers that would be helped as it relates to maybe future redevelopment timing?
componenttext: Don, just a couple of quick questions. On the TSA outcome, if you were to get the stores back, are there certain centers that would be helped as it relates to maybe future redevelopment timing?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there are. Let's go through them. So here are the five centers, Assembly Square, in the marketplace, right? So you know what's happening to that marketplace versus -- because of what we're doing in the mixed-use project adjacent to it. It's been a v
componenttext: Well, there are. Let's go through them. So here are the five centers, Assembly Square, in the marketplace, right? So you know what's happening to that marketplace versus -- because of what we're doing in the mixed-use project adjacent to it. It's been a very positive thing. And certainly, the interest in that power center that's adjacent is significantly higher than it was before we built the project. So if we got that back, that would be okay, a good thing there. Brick Plaza is the next one, again, in the middle of a complete redo. The timing of that would be great in terms of the future of Brick Plaza. Crow Canyon, which is out on the West Coast and that's a smaller store out there. And the latest one that we did -- we did that some years back. But nonetheless, that was the last one, smaller in a center that we'd just redone, which is a good thing in terms of the demand characteristics that you would have. Montrose Crossing is the fourth. That's the one directly across from Pike & Rose. That's over 35 acres where the section of the shopping center where they are would be dramatically impacted to the extent we can better merchandise that. And the last one is East Bay Bridge out in Emeryville, which is -- which the rents in place there are extremely low, and the upside would be terrific. And that's another place that we just put in 2 new -- we've really remerchandised the shopping center. So as I sit back and I look at TSA, this is a good tenant to work through this portfolio, and it's a better thing in all of the locations that we have. But it's a lot of rent in the meantime. And so again, can you look through the short-term pain for the long-term gain.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the final question. The Silver Line in Tysons has been disruptor providing a boon and an opportunity for some property owners, but changing certain patterns to the detriment of others. My understanding is that sales at Pike 7 have been weaker. A
componenttext: Okay. And the final question. The Silver Line in Tysons has been disruptor providing a boon and an opportunity for some property owners, but changing certain patterns to the detriment of others. My understanding is that sales at Pike 7 have been weaker. Are there things you can do there that change the view there? Or is there some view to the timing of future redevelopment that you would look towards?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't -- first of all, the premise, I'm not with you, on in terms of the impact of sales at Pike 7. Pike 7 is an amazing shopping center. Frankly, if sales were hit significantly during Pike 7, first of all, they would have happened during the construct
componenttext: I don't -- first of all, the premise, I'm not with you, on in terms of the impact of sales at Pike 7. Pike 7 is an amazing shopping center. Frankly, if sales were hit significantly during Pike 7, first of all, they would have happened during the construction of the Silver Line when basically all the entrances were closed and they didn't in any significant way. But if they were, then we'd had a lower hurdle to be able to do a larger mixed-use project at the site, which would be great. Having said that, your point, your bigger point, so stopping right there, look, Pike 7 is a great asset for us. What we do there long term will only be positive. And part of the issue is it's so successful for what it is right now. And therefore, the hurdle is so high to do something better, financially better there. So that's Pike 7. Now take the bigger premise and this, I think, is really important in terms of the judgment that we showed there. I think you're right. The way the Silver Line is working through Tysons, there are winners and there are losers. The type of projects that are being built there, there are winners, there are losers. We did not jump and say, oh God, we got to be the first one to market. We sat back. We renewed leases -- we have kick outs so that we were able to get the space if we needed to -- but we've created, with our discipline that, that particular asset has so inured to our benefit, that's only because we really ran it like a true real estate company would and real estate play and not like a drunken sailor with respect to development for Pete's sake, in terms of what it should be. So I want a little -- I guess I really want a little bit of credit for the discipline that we showed in not jumping to what the new Tysons is going to be. Because as you just point out, it takes a long time with a major infrastructure change like the Silver Line is to figure out what Tysons should be. Thanks so much. Thanks for giving me a chance on the soap box by the way.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Federal Realty Investment Trust Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference may be recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Federal Realty Investment Trust Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference may be recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Leah Andress. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster and Melissa Solis. They will be av
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster and Melissa Solis. They will be available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results.
Also, Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations can be attained.
The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and the results of operations. These documents are available on our website at federalrealty.com.
And with that, I would like to turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of our second quarter 2016 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Leah, and good morning, everybody. I want to be the first to publicly welcome new CFO, Dan Guglielmone. just to call him Dan G to the Federal Realty senior team. As most of you know, Dan joined us from Vornado where he served as Senior Vice
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Leah, and good morning, everybody. I want to be the first to publicly welcome new CFO, Dan Guglielmone. just to call him Dan G to the Federal Realty senior team. As most of you know, Dan joined us from Vornado where he served as Senior Vice President, Capital Markets and Acquisitions. He will have those roles here, too, in addition to oversight of accounting reporting and investor relations. He's going to do great here and play an important partnership role on the investment community and day-to-day interaction. Dan came in for the board meeting earlier this weekend and is here with us today on the call. We'll even make him available to answer your questions. He will be on full-time later this month and can be reached at Rockville extension 8232. Welcome, Dan.
Now the quarter. This is a really good one. Better than we expected of improved occupancy and strong collections effort and a ton leasing more than 100 deals and 467,000 feet of total square footage, all of which resulted in FFO per share of $1.42, nearly 7% [ph] better than last year's quarter and the highest quarterly result we've ever recorded. Remember, this is happening a time in our company when it were operations organization and adding a changing staff positions when we're building and stabilizing 2 major development initiatives that are in the throes of disruptive construction and a weak apartment rental market in D.C., when there's over $0.5 billion sitting on our balance sheet construction in progress that is not producing an income stream yet but certainly will be in some of the most sought after compelling product types in the country and some of the most sought-after real estate locations in the country. I'm really pleased with how our team is responding and the solid progress we're making. Our heads are down, and we're executing, and the long term looks as good as ever. And when you break down the components of that FFO quarter-over-quarter results, you'll see that it's broad-based. Top line revenue increase of over 9% and a property operating income increase of nearly 7.5% that had contributions from everywhere. Our contributions from the Sunset CocoWalk and Clarion joint venture acquisitions in for the full quarter, contributions from same-center growth beat our internal expectations at 3.5%, contributions from strong redevelopment results from The Point, from Bridge from Westgate, from Willow Lawn among others income contributions from Pike & Rose and Assembly Row of nearly $5 million up significantly over last year's quarter. lower interest expense despite higher borrowings continue to drive portfolio rate down and G&A that's well under control. Top to bottom, every piece of the business is contributing. And last month, as I'm sure you've heard, we've opportunistically access the 30-year unsecured by market at a spread of only 160 basis points over the 30-year treasury for a REIT record 3 5/8% coupon for 8.75% effective yield of $250 million. In effect, world economic dislocation and the quality both in real estate and credits like ours made the timing of that move really compelling. Now that money paid down the line completely with some leftover sitting for a few months so that yield is dilutive to earnings for the balance of the year by $0.03 to $0.04 per share, and we've adjusted our guidance by the low side of that amount in order to be prudent. But with current construction underway expected to return 300-plus basis points in excess of that money over the next couple of years, 30-year debt shortfall [indiscernible] 
Okay. A little more detail in the quarter and then off to the outlook. On a sequential quarter basis, the percentage of the entire portfolio that is leased ticked up to 94.5% at June 30 compared with 94.1% March 31. Melissa will talk about the Sports Authority in a few minutes but for purposes of occupancy and absent offsetting leasing, we would expect the 50 basis point hit by the end of the third quarter. As I mentioned earlier, leasing results for the quarter were strong. 91 comparable deals done for 373,000 feet of space at $38.21 a foot, 12% higher on a cash basis from the deals they replaced. That's up 17% on anchors, 10% on small shops. it's up 23% on new leases, 7% on renewals. A couple of the most consequential deals include an important merchandising upgrade at the power center portion of Assembly Square where Trader Joe's will replace more significantly higher rent beginning late in 2017 and should also help create even more tenant demand when the adjacent Sports Authority vacates later this year. Also, in the first couple of days in July, we were thrilled to complete the last piece of the puzzle for the leasing of the power center portion of Melville Mall in Long Island with an extremely well-regarded Italian specialty grocer called taking the former Melville Mall Fox at the higher rent. It's not a grocer that he would rather have been the deal with and these guys at this location on Long Island. Check out the website. I will set this along with the new Field & Stream deals and fixed deals in the last couple of quarters dis as transforming and with A&P out there, we're now actively working on adding additional for shops and restaurants, assuming we can get the entitlements. And so that's what we're working on. So stay tuned. By the way, I'm fresh off the trip to review the completion of 2 of our latest shopping center redevelopments, Tower Shops in Florida and Mercer Mall in New Jersey. I left thoroughly impressed with a real sense of pride in the transformation. Not only did they look great with full parking lots but consider this, total combined investment before redevelopment of those 2 shopping centers with $175 million producing property operating income of $14 million. Total combined investment after redevelopment was $215 million, $40 million more producing operating income of $21 million, $7 million more. Value creation at a simple 5 cap, both before and after redevelopment, so no assumed benefit from obvious cap rates and traction of $100 million over 4 years. Our ability to transform big profits like this, tower shop is 370,000 square feet, Mercer Mall 0.5 million square feet so one of the most important components of our business plan and one we are extremely proud. It's a good real estate and have a creative team that can also execute. On the big development side, no surprises, just continued execution at Assembly, Pike & Rose and Building 11 at building at Santana Row. A couple of points on each to consider.
At Assembly, Phase 1 done stabilized with every building at least 95% leased and occupied. Because of some free rent in the office tenants you have to burn off, income will continue to increase next year. Nearly 2,000 employees going to work each day at Healthcare as of today. Double that next year. Have already created higher shopping and restaurant traffic. Dust and noise are the players of the day is roughly 40% of the Phase 2 spend has been incurred and we remain on time and on budget. The office occupation that usage the Trader Joe's deals and the adjacent power center I talked about before, all these really show just how important this community has become through the north side of the city. By the way, check out the video featuring Assembly on reit.com. And as you would expect, it's also available on their website.
Good things happening at Pike & Rose to the pressure on residential rents throughout the market surely is Leasing pace, however, progressed as well with the big Pallas luxury tower now 84% leased and per se, the other residential building there remaining in the mid-80s. But our current pace of leasing, we expect to be stabilized occupancy by year-end as planned. Nike opens in the old City Sports base in a couple of weeks. And like at Assembly, nice and dust continue as about 1/3 of the Phase 2 construction budget has been spent. More than half of the retail spaces spoken for and the new Phase 2 at this point with tenants like Pinstripes, Porsche, H&M, Lucky, REI, Red Door Spots, Taylor Gourmet. The environment is shaping up as well or better than we what we had hoped. What we really could use here is a bit of firming on the price of the residential market, which is down 0.5 [ph] in [indiscernible] 
And on the West Coast, Splunk is expected to occupy the building by January, and the execution of this construction and buildout has been nearly flawless. We continue to see strength in Santana not only in terms of its desirability as an office location but also with respect to residential rents that continue to grow above our expectations. The tale of 2 cities by comparing Silicon Valley and Washington, D.C. on the residential side.
In Florida, plans for our new Miami acquisitions, Sunset and CocoWalk, continue to progress well and are being vetted by our senior team partners. Decisions as a direction committee later this year at which point we'll what we have in mind. It is likely that will want to add office and residential components with some variation of these properties. In the meantime, we'll heavily focus on grassroots for the local communities and increasingly optimistic that we'll be able to the viable and value creative changes at both locations. At Sunset, we'll need zoning changes that permit more hype to come up with a viable plan, yet we would hope to start out of the retail renovation of the existing important sections of the project first.
On the acquisition front, we're working through a number of important deals and the pricing remains on We're not afraid to step up our play in the rate real estate. Nothing to report on this call but we're working hard and hope to have more talk in the next couple of calls. Jeff Berkes and I will be brief and engage Dan as one of his first orders of business.
I've asked Melissa to talk about The Sports Authority impact, our balance sheet activity, including yesterday's announced dividend hike for the record-setting 49th consecutive year. Big celebration for the [indiscernible] As well as our full year earnings expectations. And I am going to ask Dan G to introduce himself before we open up the line to your questions afterwards. But right now, Melissa.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. We'll start with an update on Sports Authority. First, all 5 of our spaces were occupied and rent-paying for June 30. But we said Montrose Crossing here in Rockville by value city furniture who have no downtime or
componenttext:
Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. We'll start with an update on Sports Authority. First, all 5 of our spaces were occupied and rent-paying for June 30. But we said Montrose Crossing here in Rockville by value city furniture who have no downtime or lost rental at this one. With respect to the lease at Bridge and Emeryville California, Dick's Sporting Goods obtained designation rights for the lease, and we are currently in negotiations with this to take over the space. We'll know more on the next [ph] 60 days. The Crow Canyon was rejected as of July 1 and Assembly square marketplace vacant as of August 1. All outstanding ARs for these spaces was 100% reserved as of June 30. In total, we are losing 103,000 square feet of leased space, which results in a 50 basis point decline in occupancy that we will see in Q3. The spaces have a total base rent of $2.1 million or $20.50 per square foot, and we expect to be able to release these spaces at rents 10% to 20% higher. While we are in discussions with tenants for each of the spaces, final leases will, of course, take time. Typically a full year before new rent starts. For the rest of 2016, we expect these phases will impact FFO by approximately $0.02 and of course, be a drag to our Q3 and Q4 same-center metric. Enough about Sports Authority. Yesterday, we announced an increase to our quarterly dividend of $0.04 per share to a quarterly rate of $0.98 and an annual indicative rate of $3.92 per share. This is our 49th year consecutive increases the longest in the REIT sector and one of the longest for all public companies. While we talked a lot about it, this is something we couldn't be more proud of to be able to pay our shareholders more every year for almost half a century is pretty awesome.
Now turning to the balance sheet. During the quarter, we issued $59 million of equity on our ATM at a weighted average price of $156.24 per share, bringing our year-to-date ATM issuances to $92 million. In July, we opportunistically issued $250 million of 30-year senior unsecured debt at a coupon of 3.625% at an effective rate of 3.75%. We ended the quarter with 18% debt to market cap, net debt to EBITDA of 5.2x and a weighted average tenor of our debt of over 11 years after reflecting the July offering. This week lots of flexibility with respect to the balance sheet and locking in these historically low rates will benefit our company for a long time to come. From a capital standpoint, we expect to incur about $250 million in development and redevelopment spend in the second half of 2016 as both Phase 2s at Assembly Row and Pike & Rose are fully under construction. The cost will be funded with the remaining proceeds from the July bond offering, equity under our ATM and a line of credit, all with an eye towards maintaining net debt to EBITDA in the low to mid-5 range. significant acquisitions, we do not plan to issue additional long-term debt in 2016.
Now turning to guidance. We have adjusted our guidance range to reflect the incremental interest expense from the July bond offering. We have not anticipated accessing the long-term debt market until late in 2016 or early 2017 and consequently, had assumed funding on our line of credit. The impact is $0.03 to $0.04, and our updated FFO per diluted share guidance range adjusted the low end of that to a range of 5 62 to 5 68. A few additional items to note about our guidance range as well as items having an outside impact in the second half of '16 compared to the first half. First, consistent with our past practice, our guidance range does not include any future acquisition or disposition. The range includes the loss of the 3 Sports Authority spaces I discussed earlier, which is a drag of approximately $0.02 per share. We will have additional compensation cost associated with our new CFO of approximately a $0.015 in the second half of 2016. We still expect statements including the development for the year to be in the 3% area. Given our year-to-date metric as of 6/30 with 3.8%, we do expect some deceleration in the second half of the year as we feel the impact of the Sports Authority vacancies and rollover timing and expected more normalized levels of bad debt expense. We expect this to be concentrated more in Q3 as we will see additional rent starts late in the year for anchor tenants like Congressional, TJ Maxx at Pentagon Row and Golden Stream at Melville 
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Dan to introduce himself before we open up the call to your questions. Dan?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

componenttext: Thank you Melissa. Just want to say a few quick remarks. First, let me say how thrilled I am to be here at Federal and starting in little over a week. Federal is a company whose management team business strategy and balance sheet philosophy I truly admired from afar over the past several years and I'm really looking forward to joining and becoming evaluated partners with Don, Melissa and the entire senior management team here at Federal. And second, let me just say how much a look forward to getting to know everyone that's here on the phone today over the next several months as I settle into my new role. And like I said, I could not be more excited to be here. Operator, I think we can now turn it over for questions.

componenttext: If I could, I want to go to the California markets Jeff on the phone just wanted to get your developing thoughts on the competitive landscape for Santana now and in the future just Stanford completing a big renovation and Westfield obviously embarking on one. Related has approvals for city place. Just curious how you think not just about incremental retail space but also how that impacts your sort of leasing options. Do you think you guys could maybe lose the high end, if you will, the place may be diminished the uniqueness of Santana?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff. Those are all good questions and we've been think about for a long time and I think I mentioned this in the prior call Valley Fair was fielded those entitlements since prerecession. So this is something that's been out there for a while, and we
componenttext: Yes, Jeff. Those are all good questions and we've been think about for a long time and I think I mentioned this in the prior call Valley Fair was fielded those entitlements since prerecession. So this is something that's been out there for a while, and we think ultimately going to come to bear over the next few years. And from our perspective, we're doing what we do, which is being very aggressive about merchandising the street, making Santana a great place to come, the addition of the Splunk building with 670 more parking spaces, redoing some of the common areas, all that kind of stuff year and then thinking about the other parcels we have left to develop and how those are going to be developed out, and all of that is being rolled into our thinking. And maintaining Santana's uniqueness in the marketplace is a great place to come and spend time and meet friends and ease out and shop and live and work. And all that kind of stuff and so far everything has gone very, very well. we do expect some headwind, of course, 1 Valley Fair starts the expansion. That's going to be a little bit of a dogfight for a few years. But long term, we're not concerned about it. As it relates to city place, I don't know. There's still a lot to be written on that development. I would never bet against related, but they've got a long ways to go there. And geographically, it's a little bit difficult to figure out how that intercepts a lot of our primary shopping traffic. So more space in the market always affects everybody, and they're putting a lot of space into the market. But again long term, we're not overly concerned about that. Sanford has a huge benefit.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Why do you say it's a benefit? And I guess when the dust settles, I know it's 3 years from now, do you think your retail positioning changes at all? Maybe you grow more restaurants and away from fashion. I guess maybe another question is are there any cri
componenttext: Why do you say it's a benefit? And I guess when the dust settles, I know it's 3 years from now, do you think your retail positioning changes at all? Maybe you grow more restaurants and away from fashion. I guess maybe another question is are there any critical tenants for you or anchor-type tenants there at Santana that expire in the next few years?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know Santana pretty well. And you know since it opened 14 years ago that the mix of tenancy has changed and a lot of luxury shifted out already and that happens a long long time ago and really really doesn't affect us here at all in terms of our shopp
componenttext: You know Santana pretty well. And you know since it opened 14 years ago that the mix of tenancy has changed and a lot of luxury shifted out already and that happens a long long time ago and really really doesn't affect us here at all in terms of our shopper traffic and the property. So the high-end going across The Street to Valley Fair and continuing to do so I don't think matters. Our whole strategy and gross relates to not only the experience we provide people to come here to shop and also tenants say, same look, if it's your 400th store, you should probably be at Valley Fair. If it's your 10th, 20th or 50th story, you're very sensitive about the image you project your customer base, Santana's been very successful over the last 2 years bringing in some really great mergers like Kate Spade and Madewell and and the list goes on and on. And that's continuing to happen in spite of the fact that everybody knows that the Valley Fair expansion is going to happen. So like I said and like said in his comments, our heads are down and we're doing with me to do in a day-to-day basis, and maintain our position in the marketplace.

componenttext: And just sticking in that area and with County but San Mateo recently put that topic of rent control on the ballot out there just wondering local I'm curious what your action is to that and do you think it has the risk of flopping over, if you will, to Santa Clara or not a concern?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean all the communities up and down the peninsula are considering that right now. If it's not in the ballot in November, it's already happened or it's going to happen, all right? I mean the cost to housing here is a big issue, and everybody knows
componenttext: Well, I mean all the communities up and down the peninsula are considering that right now. If it's not in the ballot in November, it's already happened or it's going to happen, all right? I mean the cost to housing here is a big issue, and everybody knows that. San Jose has for a very long time and they recently tweaked some of the rules around how that rent control works. Now primarily affects owners of much, much older product that we have. And even when you work through it, rent control in and of itself is, in my mind, not a good thing but it doesn't really have any adverse impact in the normal market. So yes. I think you're going to continue to see that and how the river meets the road is still TBD. But generally speaking, most control laws are doing with much lower product.

componenttextpreview: Surely. So the recent lease-up is the restoration deal that is taking long vacant space for what will be a short-term deal for them. It may turn out to be a long-term deal but a short-term deal. And they simply the location of the real estate and said, we
componenttext: Surely. So the recent lease-up is the restoration deal that is taking long vacant space for what will be a short-term deal for them. It may turn out to be a long-term deal but a short-term deal. And they simply the location of the real estate and said, we don't know what you guys are going to do long-term, but this is a place that we need to be right now. We think we can do a lot of business out of there so that's what that was about. I want to talk about it in terms of longer-term keep in and basically, here's the situation. As you know, the functional property that has not been good for a long time. What we're doing right now, Don cited our business, the operating side of the business doing everything it can to keep it building to do new deals like that and to keep it in place. The development side of our business is saying, "This needs to be fixed," It will be fixed if we can get the entitlement to do so in 2 stages. One will be part of that property that is the best functioning part of the property today needs to be fixed up. There will be effectively a innovation to create a good shopping center there. The second part of the property will -- in order to do what the real estate needs, needs to go vertical. We'll need entitlement changes to do that. The question will be due we do the first part without the entitlement for the second part. That, we're not sure about yet. In fact, we're leaning towards no until we know that we can get the entitlement to make the whole thing makes sense. That's why there's been -- I've been less forthcoming with respect to our plans. We know we're trying to get to but it really is going to depend upon the ability to get the entitlements to do so and that should happen over the next year, and we will have an economic plan before that time to the extent we get them.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: A little bit. We've come down a little bit in terms of what when we are willing to be more aggressive on acquisitions for the right property, and a lot of that, frankly, has -- is around where we're able to do 30-year money. And that's changed things for
componenttext: A little bit. We've come down a little bit in terms of what when we are willing to be more aggressive on acquisitions for the right property, and a lot of that, frankly, has -- is around where we're able to do 30-year money. And that's changed things for us. The ability to do that, not everybody can do 30-year I do believe we've got to match the left side of the right-sided I don't think 10 years is long enough, frankly so that has popped us an awful lot and taking that through but I have to say it's not about can you do acquisitions or not do acquisitions, in my view. It's about where do you allocate capital and how allocate capital? As you know and Melissa just said, at least [ph] $0.25 billion to spend on the balance of this year on development projects that are expected to yield 300 basis points plus over what we're borrowing at. And so when you think about capital allocation it's not so much about is there an acquisition to do? It's about is there a way to grow? I mean we publicly has to continue to grow. We just feel fortunate that we have some opportunities to be able to do that, and there's certainly will be a case in acquisition and we'll certainly stretch to step up to what we need to step up to do for that occasional acquisition, but I stress occasional.

componenttext: Yes. I think things have gone a little more sensitive over the last 3 to 6 months. So cap rates, I think, and IRRs are a little bit lower than they were 3 to 6 months ago. So we continue to see in the markets where we do business, particularly out here in California, cap rates being in the 4 range, the low 4 range and IRRs looking aggressive exit cap rate assumption in the 5s and low to mid-5s. And I think that's somewhat consistent depending on the market and the asset over the last year or, so but I think things have strengthened in the last half year.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions here. First, actually for Jeff. Just on California, maybe just more general. If you could just give an update on what you're seeing on the health of Northern California as far as the apartment guys are talking about you're obviously overs
componenttext: Just 2 questions here. First, actually for Jeff. Just on California, maybe just more general. If you could just give an update on what you're seeing on the health of Northern California as far as the apartment guys are talking about you're obviously oversupplied but also softness on the job side and on the tech and then you listen to the office guys, and it seems like office is pretty good. So can you just give us your sense of what's going on in Northern California as far as the economy and your expectations as you look out to next year?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Alex. And I think [indiscernible] painted with a broad brush, which I think everybody understands and probably expects, but I think things are a little bit different may be in San Francisco than they are in Silicon Valley right now particularly
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Alex. And I think [indiscernible] painted with a broad brush, which I think everybody understands and probably expects, but I think things are a little bit different may be in San Francisco than they are in Silicon Valley right now particularly on the apartment side where there's a lot of product coming online in San Francisco. And when you think about what it costs to build a condo or an apartment in San Francisco, you got to get a pretty high sales price or pretty high rent some of those the stuff that's coming online is targeting the same customer, and there's definitely some softness up there from what we've seen and heard, both in condo sales prices and apartment rents, some concessions creeping back into the market. Down in the valley, I think it's probably a little bit different. Like in Don's comments, we're doing better on our rental increases that are apartment in Santana Row than we expected to be doing this time of the year as part of the cycle. And I think that goes to a couple of things, of course. One is supply and there's a little bit of the supply at the moment we'll see how long that continues but also job growth. And I think that's different between San Francisco and the valley as well. Things might be a little bit more choppy in San Francisco as it relates to that. Down here in Silicon Valley, they're very, very healthy. We look at job growth closely, and we're still seeing not only a lot of jobs being added, but the big Q of unskilled jobs at most of the major players. Now you're at subfrictional unemployment rates right now in both San Francisco and Silicon Valley, and there's a lot of competition still from the big firms to hire the right people. And the big firms here are still very, very profitable and they have a ton of cash on their balance sheets, and they're growing. And while that may not be at the same pace that it was a year or so ago, it still extremely strong from a historical perspective. So we're really bullish in Silicon Valley right now. Always cautious, as you know, but very bullish I think what you're hearing is more broadbrush effective than what we're seeing in our product.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So bottom line, San Francisco might be a little soft, but Silicon Valley is still very strong it sounds like in your view.
componenttext: Okay. So bottom line, San Francisco might be a little soft, but Silicon Valley is still very strong it sounds like in your view.
