headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Federal  Realty Investment Trust Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator  Instructions] As a reminder, this conference may be recorded.I would like to introduce your host for today's con
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Federal  
Realty Investment Trust Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator  
Instructions] As a reminder, this conference may be recorded.
I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Leah Andress. Ma'am, you may  
begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. I'd like to thank, everyone, for joining us today for Federal  Realty's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don  Wood, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster and Melissa Solis. They wi
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. I'd like to thank, everyone, for joining us today for Federal  
Realty's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don  
Wood, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster and Melissa Solis. They will be  
available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements  
within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward- 
looking statements include any annualized or projected information as well as statements  
referring to expected or anticipated events or results.
Although Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking  
statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its  
actual performance may differ materially from the information in our forward-looking  
statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations can be attained.
The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our  
annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents, provide a  
more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and the  
results of operations. These documents are available on our website at federalrealty.com.
And with that, I would like to turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of  
our second quarter 2016 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Leah, and good morning, everybody. I want to be the first to publicly  welcome new CFO, Dan Guglielmone, best to just call him Dan G, to the Federal Realty  senior team. As most of you know, Dan joined us from Vornado where he served as
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Leah, and good morning, everybody. I want to be the first to publicly  
welcome new CFO, Dan Guglielmone, best to just call him Dan G, to the Federal Realty  
senior team. As most of you know, Dan joined us from Vornado where he served as Senior  
Vice President, Capital Markets and Acquisitions. He will have those roles here, too, in  
addition to oversight of accounting reporting and investor relations. He's going to do  
great here and play an important partnership role on executive committee, on investment  
committee and day-to-day interactions. Dan came in for the board meeting earlier this week  
and is here with us today on the call. We'll even make him available to answer your  
questions. He will be on full-time later this month and can be reached in Rockville at  
extension 8232. Welcome, Dan.
Now the quarter. It was a really good one. Better than we expected with improved  
occupancy, a strong collections effort and a ton of leasing more than 100 deals and  
467,000 feet of total square footage, all of which resulted in FFO per share of $1.42,  
nearly 7% better than last year's quarter and the highest quarterly result we've ever  
recorded. Remember, this is happening at a transitional time in our company when we're  
realigning our operations organization and adding and changing staff positions. When we're  
building and stabilizing 2 major development initiatives that are in the throes of  
disruptive construction and a weak apartment rental market in D.C. When there's over $0.5  
billion sitting on our balance sheet, construction in progress, that is not producing an  
income stream yet but certainly will be. And some of the most sought after compelling  
product types in the country. And some of the most sought-after real estate locations in  
the country. I'm really pleased with how our team is responding and the solid progress  
we're making. Our heads are down, and we're executing, and the long term looks as good as  
ever. And when you break down the components of that FFO quarter-over-quarter results,  
you'll see that it's broad-based. Top line revenue increase of over 9% and a property  
operating income increase of nearly 7.5% that had contributions from everywhere. It had  
contributions from the Sunset CocoWalk and Clarion joint venture acquisitions in for the  
full quarter, contributions from same-center growth that beat our internal expectations at  
3.5%. Contributions from strong redevelopment results from The Point, from East Bay  
Bridge, from Westgate, from Willow Lawn among others. Income contributions from Pike &  
Rose and Assembly Row of nearly $5 million, up significantly over last year's quarter.  
Marginally lower interest expense despite higher borrowings as we continue to drive  
portfolio rate down. And G&A that's well under control. Top to bottom, every piece of the  
business is contributing. And last month, as I'm sure you've heard, we've  
opportunistically accessed the 30-year unsecured bond market at a spread of only 160 basis  
points over the 30-year treasury for a REIT record setting 3 5/8% coupon, 3.75% effective  
yield on $250 million. In effect, world economic dislocation and a flight-to-quality, both  
in real estate and to credits like ours made the timing of that move really compelling.  
Now that money paid down the line completely with some leftover and sitting in the bank  
for few months. So that yield is dilutive to earnings for the balance of the year by $0.03  
to $0.04 per share. And we've adjusted our guidance by the low side of that amount in  
order to be prudent. But with current construction underway expected to return 300-plus  
basis points in excess of that money over the next couple of years, 30-year debt sure felt  
like a good call.
Okay. A little more detail on the quarter and now on to the outlook. On a sequential  
quarter basis, the percentage of the entire portfolio that is leased ticked up to 94.5% at  
June 30 compared with 94.1% at March 31. Melissa will talk about Sports Authority in a few  
minutes, but for purposes of occupancy and absent offsetting leasing, we would expect a 50  
basis point hit by the end of the third quarter.
As I mentioned earlier, leasing results for the quarter were strong. 91 comparable deals  
done for 373,000 feet of space at $38.21 a foot, 12% higher on a cash basis from the deals  
they replaced. That's up 17% on anchors, 10% on small shops. it's up 23% on new leases, 7%  
on renewals. A couple of the most consequential deals include an important merchandising  
upgrade at the power center portion of Assembly Square where Trader Joe's will replace  
A.C. Moore at significantly higher rent beginning late in 2017 and should also help create  
even more tenant demand when the adjacent Sports Authority vacates later this year. 
Also, in the first couple of days in July, we were thrilled to complete the last piece of  
the puzzle for the leasing of the power center portion of Melville Mall on Long Island  
with an extremely well-regarded Italian specialty grocer called Uncle Giuseppe's, taking  
the former Waldbaums box at a higher rent. There's not a grocer that he would rather have  
done a deal with than these guys at this location on Long Island. Check out their website.
Uncle Giuseppe's along with the new Field & Stream deals and Dick's deals over the past  
couple of quarters is transforming this property. And with A&P out of there, we're now  
actively working on adding additional GLA for shops and restaurants, assuming we can get  
the entitlements. That's what we're working on, so stay tuned. By the way, I'm fresh off a  
trip to review the completion of 2 of our latest shopping center redevelopments, Tower  
Shops in Florida and Mercer Mall in New Jersey. I left thoroughly impressed with a real  
sense of pride in the transformation. Not only did they look great with full parking lots  
but consider this, total combined investment before redevelopment of those 2 shopping  
centers with $175 million producing property operating income of $14 million. Total  
combined investment after redevelopment was $215 million, $40 million more, producing  
operating income of $21 million, $7 million more. Value creation at a simple 5 cap, both  
before and after redevelopment, so no assumed benefit from obvious cap rate contraction of  
$100 million over 4 years. Our ability to transform big properties like this -- Tower  
Shops is 370,000 square feet, Mercer Mall 0.5 million square feet -- is one of the most  
important components of our business plan and one we are extremely proud of. It's good to  
own great real estate and have a creative team that can also execute. On the big  
development side, no surprises, just continued execution at Assembly, Pike & Rose and  
building 11, that's the Splunk building at Santana Row. A couple of points on each for you  
to consider.
At Assembly, Phase 1 done, stabilized with every building at least 95% leased and  
occupied. Because of some free rent in the office tenants you have to burn off, income  
will continue to increase next year. Nearly 2,000 employees going to work each day at  
Partners HealthCare as of today -- double that next year -- have already created higher  
shopping and restaurant traffic. Dust and noise are the players of the day as roughly 40%  
of the Phase 2 spend has been incurred, and we remain on time and on budget. The office  
occupation, the T-stop usage, the Trader Joe's deals in the adjacent power center I talked  
about before, all these really show just how important this community has become for the  
north side of the city. By the way, check out the video that NAREIT did featuring Assembly  
on reit.com, and, as you would expect, it's also available on our website.
Good things happening at Pike & Rose, too, though the pressure on residential rents  
throughout the market surely isn't subsiding. Leasing pace, however, progressed as well  
with the big Pallas luxury tower now 84% leased and per se, the other residential building  
there, remaining in the mid-90s. With our current pace of leasing, we expect to be at  
stabilized occupancy by year-end as planned. Nike opens in the old City Sports space in a  
couple of weeks. And like at Assembly, noise and dust continue as about 1/3 of the Phase 2  
construction budget has been spent. More than half of the retail spaces spoken for in the  
new Phase 2 at this point with tenants like Pinstripes, Porsche, H&M, Lucky, REI, Red Door  
Spa, [indiscernible], Taylor Gourmet. The environment is shaping up as well or better than  
we what we had hoped. What we really could use here is a bit of firming on the pricing in  
the residential market, which is bound to happen sooner or later.
And on the West Coast, Splunk is expected to occupy the building by January, and the  
execution of this construction and build-out has been nearly flawless. We continue to see  
strength in Santana not only in terms of its desirability as an office location but also  
with respect to residential rents that continue to grow above our expectations. It's a  
tale of two cities when comparing Silicon Valley and Washington, D.C. on the residential  
side.
In Florida, plans for our new Miami acquisitions, Sunset Place and CocoWalk, continue to  
progress well and are being vetted by our senior team and partners. Decisions as a to  
direction in initial phases should go on to our investment committee later this year, at  
which point we'll layout what we have in mind. It is likely that we want to add office and  
residential components in some variation at these properties. In the meantime, we're  
heavily focused on grassroots engagement with the local communities and are increasingly  
optimistic that we'll be able to work toward viable and value creative changes at both  
locations. At Sunset, we'll need zoning changes that permit more height to come up with a  
viable plan, yet we would hope to start out with a retail renovation of the existing  
important sections of the project first. Fingers crossed, we'll see.
On the acquisition front, we're working through a number of important deals and though  
pricing remains uncomfortably rich, we're not afraid to step up the play for the right  
real estate. Nothing to report on this call, but we're working hard and hope to have more  
talk over the next couple of calls. Jeff Berkes and I will be brief and engage Dan as one  
of his first orders of business.
I've asked Melissa to talk about the Sports Authority impact, our balance sheet activity,  
including yesterday's announced dividend hike for the record-setting 49th consecutive year  
(big celebration for 50th next) as well as our full year earnings expectations. And I am  
going to ask Dan G. to introduce himself before we open up the line to your questions  
afterwards. But right now, Melissa.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. We'll start with an update on Sports Authority.  First, all 5 of our spaces were occupied and rent-paying through June 30. The lease at  Montrose Crossing here in Rockville, Maryland, was assumed by Value City
componenttext:
Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. We'll start with an update on Sports Authority.  
First, all 5 of our spaces were occupied and rent-paying through June 30. The lease at  
Montrose Crossing here in Rockville, Maryland, was assumed by Value City Furniture --  
we'll have no downtime or lost rent on this one.
With respect to the lease at East Bay Bridge in Emeryville, California, Dick's Sporting  
Goods obtained designation rights for the lease. And we are currently in negotiations with  
Dick's to take over the space. We'll know more on this one in the next 60 days. The  
lease at Crow Canyon was rejected effective July 1 with Brick Plaza and Assembly Square  
marketplace vacant as of August 1.
All outstanding AR for these spaces was 100% reserved as of June 30. In total, we are  
losing 103,000 square feet of leased space, which results in a 50 basis point decline in  
occupancy that we will see in Q3. The spaces have a total base rent of $2.1 million or  
$20.50 per square foot. And we expect to be able to re-lease these spaces at rents 10% to  
20% higher. Though we are in discussions with tenants for each of the spaces, final leases  
will, of course, take time. Typically a full year before new rent starts. For the rest of  
2016, we expect these 3 spaces will impact FFO by approximately $0.02 and of course, be a  
drag to our Q3 and Q4 same-center metrics.
Enough about Sports Authority. Yesterday, we announced an increase to our quarterly  
dividend of $0.04 per share to a quarterly rate of $0.98 and an annual indicative rate of  
$3.92 per share. This is our 49th year of consecutive increases, the longest in the REIT  
sector and one of the longest for all public companies. While we talk a lot about it, this  
is something we couldn't be more proud of to be able to pay our shareholders more every  
year for almost half a century is pretty awesome.
Now turning to the balance sheet. During the quarter, we issued $59 million of equity on  
our ATM at a weighted average price of $156.24 per share, bringing our year-to-date ATM  
issuances to 92 million. In July, we opportunistically issued $250 million of 30-year  
senior unsecured debt at a coupon of 3.625% at an effective rate of 3.75%. We ended the  
quarter with 18% debt to market cap, net debt to EBITDA of 5.2x and a weighted average  
tenor of our debt of over 11 years after reflecting the July offering. This leaves us lots  
of flexibility with respect to the balance sheet and locking in these historically low  
rates will benefit our company for a long time to come. 
From a capital standpoint, we expect to incur about $250 million in development and  
redevelopment spend in the second half of 2016 as both Phase 2s at Assembly Row and Pike &  
Rose are fully under construction. The cost will be funded with the remaining proceeds  
from the July bond offering, equity under our ATM and a line of credit, all with an eye  
towards maintaining net debt to EBITDA in the low to mid-5 range. Absent a significant  
acquisition, we do not plan to issue additional long-term debt in 2016.
Now turning to guidance. We have adjusted our guidance range to reflect the incremental  
interest expense from the July bond offering. We have not anticipated accessing the long- 
term debt market until late in 2016 or early 2017 and consequently, had assumed funding on  
our line of credit. The impact is $0.03 to $0.04, and our updated FFO per diluted share  
guidance range adjusted the low end of that to a range of $5.62 to $5.68. A few additional  
items to note about our guidance range as well as items having an outsized impact in the  
second half of '16 compared to the first half. First, consistent with our past practice,  
our guidance range does not include any future acquisitions or dispositions. The range  
includes the loss of the 3 Sports Authority spaces I discussed earlier, which is a drag of  
approximately $0.02 per share. We will have additional compensation cost associated with  
our new CFO of approximately $0.015 in the second half of 2016. We still expect same- 
center, including redevelopment, for the year to be in the 3% area. Given our year-to-date  
metric as of 6/30 was 3.8%, we do expect some deceleration in the second half of the year  
as we feel the impact of the Sports Authority vacancies, anchor rollover timing and  
expected more normalized levels of bad debt expense. We expect this to be concentrated  
more in Q3 as we will see additional rent starts late in the year for anchor tenants like  
Saks at Congressional, TJ Maxx at Pentagon Row and Field & Stream at Melville.
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Dan to introduce himself before we open up  
the call to your questions. Dan?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you Melissa. Just want to say a few quick remarks. First, let me say how thrilled I  am to be here at Federal and starting in little over a week. Federal is a company whose  management team, business strategy and balance sheet philosophy I truly
componenttext:
Thank you Melissa. Just want to say a few quick remarks. First, let me say how thrilled I  
am to be here at Federal and starting in little over a week. Federal is a company whose  
management team, business strategy and balance sheet philosophy I truly admired from afar  
over the past several years, and I'm really looking forward to joining and becoming a  
valued partner to Don, Melissa and the entire senior management team here at Federal. And  
second, let me just say how much I look forward to getting to know everyone that's here on  
the phone today over the next several months as I settle into my new role. And like I  
said, I could not be more excited to be here. Operator, I think we can now turn the call  
over for questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes the line of Jeff Donnelly with Wells  Fargo.
componenttext:
[Operator Instructions] Our first question comes the line of Jeff Donnelly with Wells  
Fargo.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could, I want to go to the California markets. Jeff on the phone. I just wanted to  get your sort of developing thoughts on just the competitive landscape for Santana now and  into the future just with Stanford completing a big renovation, Westfi
componenttext:
If I could, I want to go to the California markets. Jeff on the phone. I just wanted to  
get your sort of developing thoughts on just the competitive landscape for Santana now and  
into the future just with Stanford completing a big renovation, Westfield obviously  
embarking on one, and now Related has approvals for City Place. Just curious how you think  
not just about the incremental retail space but also how that impacts your sort of leasing  
options. Do you think you guys can maybe lose the high end, if you will, and that City  
Place may diminish the uniqueness of Santana?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, those are all good questions and clearly stuff we've been thinking about for a long  time. And I think I've mentioned this on a prior call. Valley Fair at Westfield has had  those entitlements since prerecession. So this is something that's been
componenttext:
Jeff, those are all good questions and clearly stuff we've been thinking about for a long  
time. And I think I've mentioned this on a prior call. Valley Fair at Westfield has had  
those entitlements since prerecession. So this is something that's been out there for a  
while, and we think ultimately going to come to bear over the next few years. And from our  
perspective, we're doing what we can do, which is being very aggressive about  
merchandising the street, making Santana a great place to come, the addition of the Splunk  
building with 670 more parking spaces, redoing some of the common areas, all that kind of  
stuff there. And then thinking about the other parcels we have left to develop and how  
those are going to get developed out, all of that is being rolled into our thinking. And  
maintaining Santana's uniqueness in the marketplace as a great place to come and spend  
time and meet friends and eat out and shop and live and work and all that kind of stuff.  
And so far, everything has gone very, very well. We do expect some headwinds, of course,  
when Valley Fair starts the expansion. That's going to be a little bit of a dogfight for a  
few years. But long term, we're not concerned about it. As it relates to City Place, I  
don't know. There's still a lot to be written on that development. I would never bet  
against Related, but they've got a long ways to go there. And geographically, it's a  
little bit difficult to figure out how that intercepts a lot of our primary shopping  
traffic. So more space in the market always affects everybody, and they're putting a lot  
of space into the market. But again long term, we're not overly concerned about that.  
Stanford's redo is a huge benefit.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Why do you say it's a benefit? And I  guess when the dust settles, I know it's a few years from now, do you think your retail  positioning changes at all? Maybe you go more restaurants and away from fashion. I guess  maybe another question is, are t
componenttext:
Why do you say it's a benefit? And I  
guess when the dust settles, I know it's a few years from now, do you think your retail  
positioning changes at all? Maybe you go more restaurants and away from fashion. I guess  
maybe another question is, are there any sort of, call it, critical tenants for you or  
anchor-type tenants there at Santana that expire in the next few years?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, you know Santana pretty well. And you know since it opened up 14 years ago, the mix  of the tenancy here has changed and a lot of the luxury shifted out already, and that  happened a long, long time ago, and really, really didn't affect us here
componenttext:
Jeff, you know Santana pretty well. And you know since it opened up 14 years ago, the mix  
of the tenancy here has changed and a lot of the luxury shifted out already, and that  
happened a long, long time ago, and really, really didn't affect us here at all in terms  
of our shopper traffic and sales of the property. So the high-end going across the street  
to Valley Fair and continuing to do so I don't think matters. Our whole strategy with  
Santana Row as it relates to not only the experience we provide people that come here to  
shop but also tenants is to say look, if it's your 400th store, you should probably be at  
Valley Fair. If it's your 10th, 20th or 50th store, you're very sensitive about the image  
you project to your customer base, Santana is where you should be. And we've been very  
successful over the last few years bringing in some really great merchants like Kate Spade  
and Madewell and the Bonobos and Warby Parker and the list goes on and on. And that's  
continuing to happen in spite of the fact that everybody knows that the Valley Fair  
expansion is going to happen. So like I said and like Don said in his comments, our heads  
are down and we're doing what we need to do on a day-to-day basis to continue to maintain  
our position in the marketplace.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just sticking to that area. I know this is a different county and sort of a different  property type and -- but San Mateo recently put the topic of rent control on the ballot  out there just as someone who's local, I'm curious what your reaction i
componenttext:
And just sticking to that area. I know this is a different county and sort of a different  
property type and -- but San Mateo recently put the topic of rent control on the ballot  
out there just as someone who's local, I'm curious what your reaction is to that, and do  
you think it has legs, it has the risk of flopping over, if you will, to Santa Clara or  
not a concern when you think about it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I mean all the communities up and down the peninsula are considering that right  now. And if it's not on the ballot in November, it's already happened or it's going to  happen, right? I mean the cost of housing here is a big issue, and ever
componenttext:
Well, yes, I mean all the communities up and down the peninsula are considering that right  
now. And if it's not on the ballot in November, it's already happened or it's going to  
happen, right? I mean the cost of housing here is a big issue, and everybody knows that.  
San Jose has had rent control for a very long time, and they recently tweaked some of the  
rules around how that rent control works that primarily affects owners of much, much older  
product than we have. And even when you work through it, rent control in and of itself is,  
in my mind, not a good thing but it doesn't really have any adverse impact in a normal  
market. So yes, I think you're going to continue to see that and how the rubber meets the  
road is still TBD. But generally speaking, most rent control laws are dealing with much  
older product.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a last one, quick one for Melissa, do you have an estimate of when, I guess, the  decentralization plan will be sort of fully implemented and be in the new run rate for  G&A?
componenttext:
And just a last one, quick one for Melissa, do you have an estimate of when, I guess, the  
decentralization plan will be sort of fully implemented and be in the new run rate for  
G&A?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just provide a quick update on Sunset Place and the recent  lease-up that you've shown?
componenttext:
I was wondering if you could just provide a quick update on Sunset Place and the recent  
lease-up that you've shown?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Surely. So the recent lease-up is the Restoration Hardware deal that is taking long vacant  space for what will be a short-term deal for them. It may turn out to be a long-term deal  but a short-term deal. And they simply looked at the location of the
componenttext:
Surely. So the recent lease-up is the Restoration Hardware deal that is taking long vacant  
space for what will be a short-term deal for them. It may turn out to be a long-term deal  
but a short-term deal. And they simply looked at the location of the real estate and said,  
we don't know what you guys are going to do long-term, but this is a place that we need to  
be right now. And we think we can do a lot of business out of there, so that's what that  
was about. I want to talk about it in terms of longer-term, Ki Bin. And basically, here's  
the situation, as you know, that dysfunctional property that has not been good for a long  
time. What we're doing right now, Don's side of our business, the operating side of the  
business, is doing everything it can to keep it moving, to do new deals like that and to  
keep it in place. The development side of our business is saying, "This needs to be  
fixed." It will be fixed if it's -- if we can get the entitlement to do so in 2 stages.  
One will be part of that property is that -- is the best-functioning part of the property  
today, needs to be fixed up. There will be effectively a renovation to create a good  
shopping center there. The second part of the property will -- in order to do what that --  
what the real estate needs, needs to go vertical. We'll need entitlement changes to do  
that. The question will be do we do the first part without the entitlements for the second  
part. That we're not sure about yet. In fact, we're leaning towards no until we know that  
we can get the entitlements to make the whole thing makes sense. That's why there's been  
-- I've been less forthcoming with respect to our plans. We know we're trying to get to,  
but it really is going to depend upon the ability to get the entitlements to do so. And  
that should happen over the next year, and we will have an economic plan before that time  
to the extent we get that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a general question. Have you guys adjusted your return hurdles at all or  thinking about it just given the interest rate environment and the equity market  environment we're in right now?
componenttext:
Okay. And just a general question. Have you guys adjusted your return hurdles at all or  
thinking about it just given the interest rate environment and the equity market  
environment we're in right now?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, a little bit. We've come down a little bit in terms of what -- when we are willing  to be more aggressive on acquisitions for the right property, and a lot of that, frankly,  has -- is around where we're able to do 30-year money. That's changed
componenttext:
Well, a little bit. We've come down a little bit in terms of what -- when we are willing  
to be more aggressive on acquisitions for the right property, and a lot of that, frankly,  
has -- is around where we're able to do 30-year money. That's changed things for us. I  
mean your ability to do that, not everybody can do 30-year. But I do believe you got to  
match the left side with the right side, and I don't think 10 years is long enough,  
frankly. So that has helped us an awful lot in thinking that through. But I have to say,  
it's not about can you do acquisitions or not do acquisitions, in my view. It's about  
where could -- where do you allocate capital and how do you allocate capital? As you know  
and Melissa just said, we've got a $0.25 billion to spend in the balance of this year on  
development projects that are expected to yield 300 basis points plus over what we're  
borrowing at. And so when you sit and you think about capital allocation, it's not so much  
about is there an acquisition to do. It's about, is there a way to grow? I mean, we -- any  
public REIT has to continue to grow. We just feel fortunate that we have development  
opportunities to be able to do that. And there certainly will be an occasional acquisition  
and we'll certainly stretch to do -- to step-up to do what we need to step up to do for  
that occasional acquisition, but I stress occasional.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

componenttext:
Do you think private market cap rate, in general, for a good quality real estate has moved  
at all just in the recent half year or so? Or is that pretty much as always as  
[indiscernible]?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's pretty darn consistent. Jeff, anything to add to that?
componenttext: I think that's pretty darn consistent. Jeff, anything to add to that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think things have gotten a little bit more expensive over the last 3 to 6 months.  So cap rates, I think, and IRRs are a little bit lower than they were 3 to 6 months ago.  So we continue to see in the markets where we do business, particularly
componenttext:
Yes. I think things have gotten a little bit more expensive over the last 3 to 6 months.  
So cap rates, I think, and IRRs are a little bit lower than they were 3 to 6 months ago.  
So we continue to see in the markets where we do business, particularly out here in  
California, cap rates being in the 4 range, and usually the low-4 range and IRRs with an  
aggressive, exit cap rate assumption in the 5s and low to mid-5s. And I think that's  
somewhat consistent depending on the market and the asset over the last year or so, but I  
think things have strengthened in the last half year.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions here. First, actually for Jeff. Just on California, maybe just more  general. If you could just give an update on what you're seeing on the health of northern  California as far as the apartment guys are talking about, obviously, over
componenttext:
Just 2 questions here. First, actually for Jeff. Just on California, maybe just more  
general. If you could just give an update on what you're seeing on the health of northern  
California as far as the apartment guys are talking about, obviously, oversupply but also  
softness on the job side and on the tech and then you listen to the office guys, and it  
seems like office is pretty good. So can you just give us your sense of what's going on in  
northern California as far as the economy and your expectations as you look out to next  
year?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Alex. And I think the Bay Area gets painted with a broad brush, which I think  everybody understands and probably expects, but I think things are a little bit different  may be in San Francisco than they are in Silicon Valley right now, par
componenttext:
Yes. Sure, Alex. And I think the Bay Area gets painted with a broad brush, which I think  
everybody understands and probably expects, but I think things are a little bit different  
may be in San Francisco than they are in Silicon Valley right now, particularly on the  
apartment side where there's a lot of product coming online in San Francisco. And when you  
think about what it costs to build a condo or an apartment in San Francisco, you got to  
get a pretty high sales price or pretty high rent. So most of the stuff is coming online  
is targeting the same customer, and there's definitely some softness up there from what  
we've seen and heard, both in condo sales prices and in apartment rents, some concessions  
creeping back into the market. Down in the valley, I think it's probably a little bit  
different. I mean, like Don said in his comments, we're doing better on our rental  
increases at our apartments here in Santana Row than we expected to be doing this time of  
the year, this part of the cycle. And I think that goes to a couple of things, of course.  
One is supply, and there's a little bit of a supply lull at the moment, we'll see how long  
that continues. But also job growth. And I think that's different between San Francisco  
and the valley as well. Things might be a little bit more choppy in San Francisco as it  
relates to that. Down here in Silicon Valley, they're very, very healthy. We look at job  
growth closely, and we're still seeing not only a lot of jobs being added, but a big queue  
of unfilled jobs at most of the major employers. Now you're at sub-frictional unemployment  
rates right now in both San Francisco and Silicon Valley, and there's a lot of competition  
still from the big firms to hire the right people. And the big firms here are still very,  
very profitable and they have a ton of cash on their balance sheets, and they're growing.  
And while that may not be at the same pace that it was a year or so ago, it still  
extremely strong from a historical perspective. So we're really bullish on Silicon Valley  
right now. Always cautious, as you know, but very bullish. And I think what you're hearing  
is more broadbrush effect than what we're seeing in our product.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So bottom line, San Francisco may be a little soft, but Silicon Valley is still very  strong it sounds like in your view.
componenttext:
Okay. So bottom line, San Francisco may be a little soft, but Silicon Valley is still very  
strong it sounds like in your view.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is.
componenttext: It is.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Second question...

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me say something about Santana Row a little bit and Donnelly asked about it before.  And I want to get this thought out of my head. The reality is, similar to what you've seen  on the East Coast, there is various -- the supply, that's around, part
componenttext:
Let me say something about Santana Row a little bit and Donnelly asked about it before.  
And I want to get this thought out of my head. The reality is, similar to what you've seen  
on the East Coast, there is various -- the supply, that's around, particularly on the  
office side, is not necessarily what employers are looking for. So you see vacancy, you  
see "softness" in product that is in some respects not leasable. And what has happened at  
Santana, while there is no question in my mind that we will be under pressure in terms of  
the rents that we'll get on retail because of the Valley Fair expansion, because of any  
kind of expansion when you have that much space over the next few years. The place itself  
is so solidified and is so good at what it is, that we do benefit big time on both the  
residential and on the office. Now at the end of that street, we're going to have to  
finish out one of these days, and we're working through an office plan for the end of that  
street with the retail on the ground floor and we are obviously boosted by the success  
that we've had with respect to Splunk. Now I'm not ready to announce that or to talk about  
that. But given the environment, all the comments you just heard from Jeff, we're going to  
have -- there's going to be support around here to add incremental office and retail space  
to (small amount of retail, restaurant primarily) space to Santana Row that captures what  
it is that we've done. And I think that type of environment, that amenity base, that place  
that we've created will serve us real well on the office and continue on the residential  
side. You've got to get specific on the specific -- on the questions you're analyzing.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. I appreciate that. Second question is maybe for Dan or Melissa. You guys  issued debt earlier than you thought. Rates only seem to go one way for the past almost  decade. A year out from now, you've got Plaza El Segundo mortgage that com
componenttext:
Okay. Got it. I appreciate that. Second question is maybe for Dan or Melissa. You guys  
issued debt earlier than you thought. Rates only seem to go one way for the past almost  
decade. A year out from now, you've got Plaza El Segundo mortgage that comes due pretty  
high coupon. As you guys think about your capital needs over the next year, is your view  
more, hey, let's get stuff early, like you did with the 30-year. Let's tap the market  
early, maybe prepay. Or your view is now look, rates just only seem to stay low any time  
people try to hedge early or do anything early, it ends up costing because rates keep  
coming down. Given your balance sheet, it's not so bad. You can certainly support it to  
wait longer until that mortgage naturally matures or you think about maybe attacking that  
early?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, what you just said, Alex, is exactly right. Where we look at the future is very  much determined by what we've done in the past. And now we've got an awful lot of  flexibility. So with respect to the particular loan that you're talking about a
componenttext:
Listen, what you just said, Alex, is exactly right. Where we look at the future is very  
much determined by what we've done in the past. And now we've got an awful lot of  
flexibility. So with respect to the particular loan that you're talking about at Plaza El  
Segundo there is a requirement in our partnership agreement that we have some level of  
debt on that asset. And that asset -- that particular loan is not prepayable until 3  
months -- May of next year. So the likelihood is we'll wait till May to effectively do  
something there. And again, we will wind up putting probably some level of debt back on  
that property on a secured basis because we need to give tax protection to our partners.  
In almost any scenario we see, it will be a benefit. It will be cheaper than the debt  
that's there.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Christy McElroy with Citi.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Christy McElroy with Citi.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the cost of capital discussion. As you mentioned earlier, you just  issued the 30-year debt in the mid-3s. Your shares trade at what we're calculating around  the 3 done implied cap rate basis. You might have the lowest weighted av
componenttext:
Just a follow-up on the cost of capital discussion. As you mentioned earlier, you just  
issued the 30-year debt in the mid-3s. Your shares trade at what we're calculating around  
the 3 done implied cap rate basis. You might have the lowest weighted average cost of  
long-term capital of any REIT. You talked about being more aggressive on acquisitions for  
the right deals. I know we've always maintained a list of properties in the U.S. that  
you'd want to own someday, but with your cost of capital where it is today who knows how  
long that will last. Are you being more proactive in going out to some of those owners to  
try to create your own supply of new deals?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know, Christy, that we're being more proactive. We are certainly being  proactive. You may be seeing parts of that in the next few months. And now I'll talk about  that when I can. But again, I really need you to -- I really need you to
componenttext:
Well, I don't know, Christy, that we're being more proactive. We are certainly being  
proactive. You may be seeing parts of that in the next few months. And now I'll talk about  
that when I can. But again, I really need you to -- I really need you to understand on the  
capital allocation side what we are putting to work in development and it is -- it's  
aggressive. I mean, we are aggressively putting money to work in a way that is far more  
value creative than with any acquisition no matter what's available at the -- on the  
marketplace today. So it's not only about -- I only want to use this great cost of capital  
not to create 1 or 2 years worth of FFO but to add value. And right now, it's pretty darn  
clear that the development alternatives over the acquisitional alternatives are a slam  
dunk. Now if we didn't have the developmental alternatives, you would see a whole -- we  
got to grow, right? You've got to keep going -- that's the deal. But we do, and we do for  
years to come. So that's really all I can say about that at this point.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just, Melissa, just following up on the guidance. So I just want to  understand sort of the [indiscernible]. Lowered guidance by $0.03. I understand the debt  issue causes about a $0.03 to $0.04 drag. You've got Sports Authority in the
componenttext:
Okay. And then just, Melissa, just following up on the guidance. So I just want to  
understand sort of the [indiscernible]. Lowered guidance by $0.03. I understand the debt  
issue causes about a $0.03 to $0.04 drag. You've got Sports Authority in the back half of  
the year that's another $0.02. The additional comp is a $0.015. What -- I know you talked  
about this a little bit in opening remarks but what are sort of the offsets to that? It  
seems like that all adds up to more than $0.03.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We did have better than expected during Q2. So I think there was some additional  benefit from Q2 that was able to offset that -- those negatives throughout the rest of the  year.
componenttext:
Yes. We did have better than expected during Q2. So I think there was some additional  
benefit from Q2 that was able to offset that -- those negatives throughout the rest of the  
year.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what that really is, Christie? It's our general sandbagging. It's general reality  that we wind up in running this portfolio with good things happening that we could not  predict. That's what happens. So we don't take every negative thing and
componenttext:
You know what that really is, Christie? It's our general sandbagging. It's general reality  
that we wind up in running this portfolio with good things happening that we could not  
predict. That's what happens. So we don't take every negative thing and reduce guidance  
for it and not consider the base of this property -- the base of this real estate allows  
us to have things happen that are not predictable, whether that's a lease termination fee,  
whether that's collections. And in the second quarter we were incredibly successful with  
collections of some old stuff. And that is -- that's not -- nothing happened by itself but  
happened with aggressive running. That was not something we could have predicted, so  
that's when I think sandbagging. That's what I need. It's not intentional sandbagging.  
It's a benefit of a great portfolio that good things happen. So -- I mean we're  
conservative people. We do the best we can and make sure we're not surprising you guys to  
the negative, but good things happen in this portfolio so we did take it all the way down.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

componenttext:
Okay. And then just in terms of a Sports Authority lease at Assembly market place, sorry  
if I missed this. But do you have control of that box and then with the Trader Joe's  
already slated to come in. Who's the target? who is on the target for that space?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We do have control of the box. I don't want to give you the names of those two  tenants that we're talking to, nothing to it, because we're having them compete with one  another and trying to create the best deal, Jeremy, you understand that. But
componenttext:
Yes. We do have control of the box. I don't want to give you the names of those two  
tenants that we're talking to, nothing to it, because we're having them compete with one  
another and trying to create the best deal, Jeremy, you understand that. But I will say if  
you take a look at the merchandising in that shopping center, particularly with the Trader  
Joe's announcement that they're coming in and the success of the Row, the [indiscernible]  
project adjacent to it, I mean that's pretty much ground zero for boxes. So we would very  
much anticipate a competition for space to that box.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The only thing that I would just add is how really thrilled we are with our partner  for Trader Joe's as they are coming in with the construction we have going on and all the  residential being added. It is a great co-tenant for those residents a
componenttext:
Yes. The only thing that I would just add is how really thrilled we are with our partner  
for Trader Joe's as they are coming in with the construction we have going on and all the  
residential being added. It is a great co-tenant for those residents and there's already  
excitement and benefits that we're seeing.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back to the cost of capital kind of discussion and you mentioned that  the attractiveness of 30-year yields today, obviously did a record-setting deal. But just  curious, I mean, your cost of equity looks pretty much equally attrac
componenttext:
I just wanted to go back to the cost of capital kind of discussion and you mentioned that  
the attractiveness of 30-year yields today, obviously did a record-setting deal. But just  
curious, I mean, your cost of equity looks pretty much equally attractive there and not  
that you need to de-lever further but just wondering how you're thinking about equity  
versus 30-year when your FFO yields are pretty similar.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, absolutely. And it's a balance. And we'll do, we'll try to do about $50 million a  quarter on the ATM for the next 2 quarters through the balance of the year. We've done a  little bit more than 100 or just 90...
componenttext:
Yes, no, absolutely. And it's a balance. And we'll do, we'll try to do about $50 million a  
quarter on the ATM for the next 2 quarters through the balance of the year. We've done a  
little bit more than 100 or just 90...

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've done $92 million in the first half of the year off of the ATM. And as you know, we  did an overnight that way. So it's a balance. We're not trying specifically to de-lever.  We're trying, as you know, to wind up after -- we're working a 10-year
componenttext:
We've done $92 million in the first half of the year off of the ATM. And as you know, we  
did an overnight that way. So it's a balance. We're not trying specifically to de-lever.  
We're trying, as you know, to wind up after -- we're working a 10-year business plan here.  
We're trying to double the earnings of the company from a few years ago. And in doing  
that, we said we'd do that and we're trying hard to do that on a leverage-neutral basis.  
So that means when we lay out these development opportunities, when we consider new  
development opportunities through or new acquisition opportunities, that does -- we look  
opportunistically at both markets, and we're accessing both markets. You'll never find us  
going wholly one way or wholly another way, the beauty of the -- of this business plan is  
its balance.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. What would be the downside of going more equity if the cost of that is similar?
componenttext: Got it. What would be the downside of going more equity if the cost of that is similar?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got money going out in a big way to produce development returns. The -- we're trying  to do that in a way that results in 6%, 7%, 8% FFO per share growth a year as one  component of the plan and you are right, does that matter for equity over de
componenttext:
We've got money going out in a big way to produce development returns. The -- we're trying  
to do that in a way that results in 6%, 7%, 8% FFO per share growth a year as one  
component of the plan and you are right, does that matter for equity over debt? No. But we  
firmly believe that in not overly diluting shareholders in any one period of time to  
balance that with cost of debt that is 30 years, it's pretty close to equity, frankly.  
Over -- in balance if that makes sense. That means we couldn't do more equity? No, it  
doesn't mean we couldn't. But we don't think we need to because all of these markets have  
been -- are pretty even in terms of their value to us.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Vineet Khanna with Capital One Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Vineet Khanna with Capital One Securities.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Of course, as Melissa mentioned, 2 of them are not really ours to manage. The couple  that we have -- the 2 that we have here on the East Coast are at Brick. There are active  negotiations going on with multiple tenants as part of the redevelopm
componenttext:
Sure. Of course, as Melissa mentioned, 2 of them are not really ours to manage. The couple  
that we have -- the 2 that we have here on the East Coast are at Brick. There are active  
negotiations going on with multiple tenants as part of the redevelopment of that property  
where we also had the A&P box that we got back. So I would hope that in the next year or  
two, Don is going to talk about Brick Plaza and division [indiscernible] like you  
mentioned early on  [indiscernible] Tower. I feel very confident about that. And as it  
relates to Assembly, as we said earlier on the call, there's a lot of active interest.  
It's important from a merchandising standpoint to nail that with the right type of tenancy  
and take advantage of it being a complement to the Row property next door in the outlook  
mix [indiscernible] that we have a lot of interest as soon as able we're able to provide  
you more guidance on exactly what those terms are, we will.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me add one thing to the bigger picture, if I can, on the vacancies in the boxes that  we have. As you know, we work hard to get vacancies from and A&P and Sports Authority is  giving us vacancies that we didn't necessarily count on, but we got the
componenttext:
Let me add one thing to the bigger picture, if I can, on the vacancies in the boxes that  
we have. As you know, we work hard to get vacancies from and A&P and Sports Authority is  
giving us vacancies that we didn't necessarily count on, but we got them anyway along with  
L.A. Fitness and some of the other stuff we talked about in the past. You should know that  
since we started talking about that, we've done 5 key deals Uncle Giuseppe's at Melville,  
Field & Stream at Melville, Saks OFF 5TH at Congressional, Trader Joe's at Assembly, L.A.  
Fitness at Delmar. That's 200,000 square feet of deals where the old rent was about $18 a  
foot and the new rent is about $27. So the notion of what it is that we're doing does not  
guarantee that the remaining ones are going to be like that? Of course not. But it does  
say that this idea of creating better shopping centers for the next 10 years is what our  
focus is and demand on the East Coast [indiscernible] on the 2 on the West Coast, you will  
see that this real estate will not have a problem releasing and really changing completely  
the shopping centers that they're in, that those Sports Authorities are in, particularly  
Brick.

componenttext:

we have back and like Chris said, we've got multiple interest from retailers on that as  
well and the rent will be higher than the rent that Sports Authority was paying. And then  
at East Bay Bridge, Dick's acquired the designation rights to that lease. So we don't know  
exactly how that's going to turn out. But I will tell you the lease rent is the low -- the  
lease rate is a low double-digit rent. And we have interest from multiple tenants to take  
that should we get it back, but we don't control that at this point.

componenttext:
No, we really haven't. It's been, from the last quarter to this quarter, consistent.  
Including pace, pace has been consistently good and the rents have been -- I frankly, have  
been looking for more, I've been looking for a change in the supply-demand characteristics  
of the rent that would allow us to push rent, and we have not seen that at all. So it's  
been consistent with what I've been talking about.

componenttext:
It's really 18 months. We'll be sitting there in 2018. The first tenant that's in it --  
this is the way the stuff kind of works. REI will be the first tenant in the next phase  
open, and that will be open by the middle of next year. Then the numbers kind of follow  
after that, Pinstripes follows after that, those are in smaller buildings. But the bigger  
buildings, particularly the tower that has condos on top, a hotel in the middle, retail on  
the ground floor and the adjacent building on the other side, we're going to be in 2018 as  
that is being turned over. So it's really that period of time, James. So when those 2  
things are done, you will see -- you will feel what we've been talking about. If I could  
get you onto the parking garage today at Pike & Rose and look out over it, you would get  
this completely. It's exactly what I'm talking about. So really it's like anybody who's  
going to be on the West -- on the East Coast anytime over the next 30, 60, 90 days I'll be  
happy to walk up there with you.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my question is concerning the experiential retailers, and I'd like to use LEGOLAND  at Assembly Row as an example. One of the pushbacks I get when I talk about these type of  retailers is they say well once you visit, are you done? Do you ever
componenttext:
I guess my question is concerning the experiential retailers, and I'd like to use LEGOLAND  
at Assembly Row as an example. One of the pushbacks I get when I talk about these type of  
retailers is they say well once you visit, are you done? Do you ever go back? And so I  
guess what I'm asking you, one, do you know anything about repeat visitors to like a  
LEGOLAND? Or is it just a matter of that draw so much broader that they continue to see  
good attendance regardless of a no-repeat.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Craig, let me give you my point of view and Chris is going to jump in as soon as I'm  finished. There is no doubt and I agree with the basic concept with experiential tenants,  particularly, that, first of all, you know as soon as they open wheth
componenttext:
Yes, Craig, let me give you my point of view and Chris is going to jump in as soon as I'm  
finished. There is no doubt and I agree with the basic concept with experiential tenants,  
particularly, that, first of all, you know as soon as they open whether there is something  
that resonates or it doesn't. And LEGOLAND resonated in a big way. But the challenge then  
is to say, "Well, okay. Is that the level of business that they're going to maintain  
throughout their lease life?" You can't assume it is. It's not like a restaurant. And at  
least we found and as much as LEGOLAND is, this kind of notion. It's not like a restaurant  
that gains in popularity all the way through. And it's a lot of small visits that  
continues to happen. The question is does it settle into a place with -- because if of its  
big draw from a large area, where it is always something that people continue to go to  
once a month or -- at first, they'll go a lot. And then over time, they go less. What  
we've seen there is, first of all, it was a huge opening, and that was so validating to  
the property that it was critical. And they have settled. And they've settled down at a  
number from the beginning in a place though that still works really, really well. Now what  
will be interesting to see is from this point, do they grow slowly like other retailers  
from here? Do they reprogram the space with different attractions and things like that?  
How does that work out? That's what we expect to happen. But the level that they're doing  
today is pretty darn impressive albeit not what it was when it opened up.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would just add, I think Don answered the business side of it, from our  perspective on why we did LEGO there, and why this experiential use was really important,  was that it provided a daily draw to -- or provided a draw to the 18 million
componenttext:
Yes. And I would just add, I think Don answered the business side of it, from our  
perspective on why we did LEGO there, and why this experiential use was really important,  
was that it provided a daily draw to -- or provided a draw to the 18 million tourists that  
come into Boston every year. We got on the same program as the aquarium and the Duck Tours  
and the science museum so that those constituents coming in came to Assembly, to drive  
traffic to every other use we have there. So there is the business answer, and think that  
will drive growth, but there was also a very defined purpose as to why we did it, which  
was creating a use and a need that attracted a regional draw. There, if you talk to them  
they draw from about a 120-mile radius. We see field-trip buses there all the time. And  
I've got 3 kids, I remember when they were younger the same destination at the point in  
time Chuck E. Cheese local for birthday parties. I think I probably went there 30 times  
over a window of time. So I just think that LEGO is also serving that same purpose of  
families and bringing back that recognition. And -- so we're thrilled with LEGOLAND there.  
Which we just had a [indiscernible] at the white marsh, which is same kind of thing. So in  
the right places for the right draw, I think these are uses that make a lot of sense but  
you have to have a big picture as to what the end-use purpose is for us. And this was very  
disciplined in our decision making to bring them here.

componenttext:
Yes. It relates primarily to some of them are second floor spaces in our multistoried  
buildings. I mean a good example would be 301 Arizona, which a couple of years ago we had  
a 2-story retailer. And we found some upside in the building by converting the upper  
levels of the retail space to office, reducing the size of the retail space and making a  
ground floor only and, therefore, getting a lot more rent for it. So we have a couple of  
other buildings that fit into that, general configuration that's still have two-story  
tenants or 2 floors of retail in them as they come back to us, we'll think through that as  
well and...

componenttextpreview: And not only that, Mike. But because we are a landlord on the street, but we don't own it  all, we're always looking for adjacencies. So to the extent -- and the primary reason it's  on that schedule is for the second floor things that we got to do st
componenttext:
And not only that, Mike. But because we are a landlord on the street, but we don't own it  
all, we're always looking for adjacencies. So to the extent -- and the primary reason it's  
on that schedule is for the second floor things that we got to do stuff with. But taking  
that and moving it across to an adjacent building is why we're -- we maintain and try to  
build on great relationships with those owners and those are the other possibilities that  
we try to go for.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I've got it, Floris, you're coming in and out, so excuse me if I haven't  fully got your question. But I think what you're saying is if we don't see any improvement  there or further deterioration are our future yields at risk, and the an
componenttext:
Yes, I think I've got it, Floris, you're coming in and out, so excuse me if I haven't  
fully got your question. But I think what you're saying is if we don't see any improvement  
there or further deterioration are our future yields at risk, and the answer is sure, they  
are. Now where we are today -- and this is what is -- it's frustrating to me frankly -- we  
have absolutely even with the construction zone validated that this type of living is what  
people are willing to pay more for in terms of the marketplace. So we continue -- we've  
gotten continue to get premiums to the marketplace for the Pike & Rose apartments. The  
next phase will have more Pike & Rose apartments. And in fact, we still have more to do in  
Pallas this way. There will be a change in the supply and demand dynamics, in addition to  
a project that is getting a whole lot more, as we talked about before, stable in terms of  
what it's going to be. But to the extent it continues to soften, yes, there will be  
pressure on the yield. That's just, matter of fact, the way it is.
