headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Federal Realty Investment Trust Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Leah
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Federal Realty Investment Trust Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Leah Andress. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Dan G, John Becker, Jeff Marcus, Chris Weilminster, Melissa Solis and James The
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Dan G, John Becker, Jeff Marcus, Chris Weilminster, Melissa Solis and James They will be available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results.
Although Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations can be attained.
The earnings release and the supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. These documents are available on our website at federalrealty.com.
[Operator Instructions] Now I'd like to turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of our third quarter 2016 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Leah, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we reported third quarter 2016 FFO per share of $1.41, 3.7% better than last year's exceptionally strong quarter and above our internal expectations. Given these results, we're comfortable reaffirmi
componenttext:
Thank you, Leah, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we reported third quarter 2016 FFO per share of $1.41, 3.7% better than last year's exceptionally strong quarter and above our internal expectations. Given these results, we're comfortable reaffirming our previously issued guidance range for full year '16 [indiscernible] of 5 63 million to 5 67. [indiscernible] the third quarters reported results expectations for the balance of the year and most importantly, what this means for '17 since we released initial guidance last night that falls short of expectations, mostly for value-enhancing initiatives that have short-term cost. More of that in a few minutes [indiscernible] 
$1.41 a share [indiscernible] $1.38 in the first quarter, $1.42 on the second, we're happy with that result, given the fact that as anticipated and as we discussed previously, this is the quarter we really see the full effect of the big vacancies in the past few quarters. Sports Authority is gone. A&P are gone, et cetera, and they were all in [indiscernible] a year ago. When coupled with a particularly strong quarter a year ago where FFO per share was down [ph] 11% for a tough year-over-year comparison. Those vacancies this quarter, along with the inclusion of poorly leased Sunset Place and CocoWalk resulted in a reduction of portfolio lease percentage of 120 basis points to 94.3% and a physical occupancy reduction of 200 [ph] basis points.
Those vacancies, in addition to some strong bad debt recovery and percentage rent positives in last year's quarter resulted in anemic same-store growth comparison by [indiscernible] 150 to 200 basis points lower than they would otherwise have been. When you think about it, it does say an awful a lot about the portfolio that same-store grew 1.5% in the quarter that occupancy dipped as much as it did.
It would be wrong to conclude that leasing activity has trailed off, however, as can be seen in the leasing done this quarter. There was a lot of it. 93 comparable deals, that's more leases any quarter in the last couple of years from 427,000 feet of space had an average rent of 31 25, 14% higher than the tenants they replaced. In fact, for the first 9 months of this year, we've done 269 comparable deals or 1.2 million square feet, 17% more volume than the first 9 months of 2015.
And that leads to the discussion I want to have our initial guidance for '17 of $5.83 to $5.93 per share, so let me pivot now and use the rest of my prepared remarks to discuss 2017. I think this will make us one of the first to issue guidance, and this year's particularly required explanation.
And let me start out by being crystal clear that despite 4% [indiscernible] FFO growth at the midpoint of guidance next year, nothing has changed our outlook as the achievability of hitting or beating our long-term business plan goal of doubling income for 10 years. In fact, it's precisely because of the [indiscernible] 2017 that I have greater confidence we'll get there. To make it as clear as possible, we included the schedule on this year's -- in this quarter's press release and 8-K on the reconciliation of FFO guidance -- on FFO guidance page that will parallel the comments I'm about to make. A little background first as to why we're so aggressively repositioning so much our portfolio. We see we have seen consumer behavior changing and changing at an accelerated pace and impacting nearly every business. Retail real estate is no exception. That's why a couple of years back, we turned up the heat on virtually every initiative we had at the same time in every facet of our business at a time when capital was cheap and [indiscernible] best-of-class portfolio in the best possible shape in markets where consumers demand a higher level of service and in an environment they want to hang out as an integral part of their lines. Of course, it takes time, all the more than we would like, but reviewed it as critical to the long-term strengthening of this real estate portfolio. We feel that we're best positioned to do this, given the location of our real estate and our track record of success in transforming different types of retail real estate.
So we accelerated the timing to start the second phase of our big mixed-use development before the paint was dry in the first phase even though second phase construction affects first phase performance until and overall sense is established.
We jumped into Miami with not 1 but 2 new retail opportunities located retail destinations even though the existing income stream will, of course, be disrupted in preparation of the process. We accelerated the full buildout of growth, first  with the option of the 12 acres and NOS and with respect build now fully leased [indiscernible] Building and currently with the announcement to move forward with 215,310,000 square foot office retail tower in the anchor industry.
We restructured our personnel through decentralization investment initiative so that the the human capital was sufficient, properly aligned and has the tools necessary to accelerate progress in both the mixed-use and core portfolios. We took advantage of a very favorable capital environment, both by delevering through current [indiscernible] and somewhat ahead of development spend and by turning on our debt portfolio with $700 million of 30-year [ph] unsecured bonds, creating a level of safety unmatched by any of our peers.  Of course, at the expense of lower earnings led by higher short-term interest expense in lower level of We have and continue to identify more value-enhancing redevelopment opportunities with our new decentralized structure than ever before in our history. And we're getting more faster even though they hurt short-term earnings. Many of those opportunities are possible by our ability to get back on the anchor business. And it's this last point, the one related to the [indiscernible] redevelopment pools sparked by vacancies that is one of the 3 main reasons 2017 appears late even though it is this redevelopment initiative that drives significant value creation and earnings growth to follow. And if the market were softening and the cost of money is increasing, the quality of the real estate location has always been [indiscernible] possible. We're got the best volume growth in the fourth [ph] quarter. I'll give you some numbers.
The release of the excess anchor in the portfolio gives an obvious drag -- earnings drag into the bigger development plan. Then in some cases, entitled, then leased, then turned over to the tenant for interior buildout, then occupied, then finally, rent pay. Generally, we're not just trying to release vacant offices, we're trying to reposition and fortify retail destinations, and that simply takes longer.
Consider this. We have 700,000 square feet of anchor and near-anchor vacancy in the quarter. That's more than doubled the box vacancy that we historically have carried. In Sports Authority, AMC, Hudson Trail [indiscernible] you know their names. The prior ramp on that 730,000 feet was 19 75 and represents $14.5 million of rent or $0.20 a share of former in-place annual rent that's missing.
As of today, we've got 42% of that space released and released at 37% higher rent than was previously being paid. This released the and DSW at Brick shopping center. So Field & Stream and [indiscernible] are at Melrose shopping center, T.J. Maxx at Pentagon Row to L.A. Fitness and Gilmore, et cetera. Every one of those deals is part of a much more comprehensive repositioning of the shopping center, not merely a releasing of the box. But it generally doesn't become rent paying until '17 and '18 with the heavy weighting toward the back end of '17 and '18. Accordingly, we forecast 2017 to be roughly 5 million or $0.07 a share lower than it otherwise would be.  Of course, the validation of these redevelopment shopping centers will be significant when completed.
Now let's go to the big developments and talk with a natural short-term dilution that comes from the delivery and lease-up process associated with the residential development and Phase 2 of assembly and Pike & Rose as well as the dilution that comes from a probable reconfiguration of CocoWalk that we considered in our 2017 guidance.
First, the Phase 2 residential building under construction at both Assembly and Pike & Rose. At Assembly, the 447 unit residential building called and at Pike & Rose, the 272-unit residential building called The Henry will both begin deliveries and lease up in '17. The dilution that comes from this process is expected to exceed $4 million or $0.06 a share. Operating costs, marketing, interest expense naturally exceed revenue as development turns over this building's expenses exceed revenue significantly at first, unless those buildings leased up. It's unavoidable and will create earnings drag of about $2 million before interest and an additional $2 million at the FFO line. Those 2 buildings alone are expected, however, to create well over $100 million of value when stabilized. 
Similarly, at CocoWalk in Florida, while we haven't completely finalized our development plans and numbers, we do hope to able to get those plans to our investment committee early next year, which allow us to begin repositioning space and tenants and beginning construction at the portion of the shopping center in 2017. As we expect -- as you would assume, occupancy at CocoWalk and at Sunset, for that matter, will get worse before it gets better, and we thought it prudent to include the impact of Miami's first step toward repositioning estimated at a couple of cents a share in our guidance. Obviously, the value is expected to be created at CocoWalk [indiscernible] in 2017 accounting losses. Basically, our 2017 guidance would have been roughly $0.16 a share higher if we were simply not building Phase 2s at Pike & Rose for Assembly and not proactively taking out our anchor space. Hopefully, the enhancements we're making to our disclosure, including the timing of income coming online will provide more clarity now and in the future.
The final significant item affecting 2017 guidance is our lower near-term operating income expectations at Pike & Rose, continuing softness in the Montgomery County, Maryland residential market, especially in the last 90 days. And the ongoing construction disruption of Phase 2 simply make me uncomfortable maintaining 7% yield guidance at Pike & Rose. And accordingly, you'll note a change in our disclosures for both the first and second phases as I alluded to earlier [indiscernible] so really need to be used together to a 6% to 7% yield with better disclosure on the time periods, we're getting there. The disclosure now also includes site maps we're adding that make the proximity of the Phase 2 construction and Phase 1 quite apparent along with the land and entitlements for future spaces. I, we remain positive as ever on what we're creating there, but have our our eyes wide open as to the additional time that it's going to take to get there. The combined impact of that lower expected yield and lower pace negatively impacting our '17 guidance by about $0.06 a share. All told, at $0.22 a share or more that's pushed back from '17 to the next 12, 24, 36 months in addition to the positive momentum in contributions for the many initiatives we're working on and from those that we'll add to in the future. So that's it for my prepared remarks. We've got a lot going on around here, huge investment in our future, lots of construction in progress on the balance sheet and the right type of products for the future on some of the best of the real estate and some the best markets of the country, our heads are down and we continue to execute. I look forward to spending more time with many of you in a couple of weeks in Phoenix going through this and wherever else you'd like to talk through. Now let me turn it over to Dan before opening up the lines for your questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don, and Leah, and good morning everyone done covered a lot in his remarks so I'll fill in a few places as it relates to the third quarter and the balance of 2016. Then I want to spend some time going through a few specific areas that will help
componenttext:
Thank you, Don, and Leah, and good morning everyone done covered a lot in his remarks so I'll fill in a few places as it relates to the third quarter and the balance of 2016. Then I want to spend some time going through a few specific areas that will help you with your modeling of Federal's going forward. 
First, the third quarter. The $1.41 of FFO per share and same-store NOI growth of 1.5% were fully in step with our expectations for the quarter. As Melissa specifically discussed in our second quarter call, same-store growth is expected to decelerate in the second half of 2017, with most of that concentrated in the third quarter. Now that was due not only to the difficult third quarter comp we faced but also due to the impact on occupancy and cash flow of our anchor repositioning activity.
With portfolio occupancy at 93.1% at quarter end versus 95.1% at third quarter 2015, note that almost 150 of the 200 basis point diminution can be attributed to those 8 anchor boxes that Don referenced in his remarks. The 3 A&Ps, 3 Sports Authorities, Hudson Trail and Hancock which occupancy in '15 were gone in the third quarter of 2016. Also note that this vacancy totaling over 320,000 square feet is at highly productive centers located in Bensenville markets, many of which we are redeveloping, remerchandising at Assembly Square in Boston, Melville Mall in [indiscernible] in North Bethesda, Westgate in San Jose, to name a few. Needless to say, we feel very good about our ability to reposition these boxes [indiscernible]  
Through the first 3 quarters of 2016, our same-store growth stands at 3%, 1.9% excluding redevelopments. We project fourth quarter to be in line with this run rate and expect same-store growth for the year to remain in the 3% area.
Next, on the development front with respect Assembly Row and Pike & Rose, contribution for the third quarter was $6 million, up from $4.9 million during the second quarter. Assembly Row Phase 1 is 100% leased and now is producing approximately 95% of its projected stabilized property operating income or POI. Ask Don mentioned, Pike & Rose Phase 1 is behind from a run rate perspective, mostly driven by softness in effective rents at the PerSei And currently, we are closer to a 60% of projected stabilized deal on a run rate basis. Although we are pleased to be hitting our occupancy projections, the was 98% leased and Pallas almost 86% leased at quarter end. Further, we continue to demand premiums to the market of 10% to 15%. Out west at 500 Santana Row, we are slightly ahead of plan and expect Splunk to open at the end of the fourth quarter. Just a reminder, this 234,000 square-foot development is delivering a 9% cash on cost yield. Given the success at 500 Santana combined with the continued strong demand office space in the submarket, we are moving forward with the development of 700 Santana Row, a 310,000 square foot office and retail development located at the end of Santana Row, which will effectively finish off the street. We are projecting a stabilized cash on cost of 7% with projected delivery in 2019 and stabilization in 2021.
Now let me cover a few areas to provide additional clarity for your modeling in Federal going forward. As it relates to the core businesses and the impact of our anchor repositioning initiatives, we expect overall portfolio occupancy to stay at its current 93% through fourth quarter and remain at this level for most of 2017. We project occupancy will begin to improve at the end of 2017 and continue into 2019. With respect to the 730,000 square feet of anchor on [indiscernible] vacancy in effect during the third quarter, 42% or 310,000 square feet is leased. Of that 310,000, 135,000 will be rent paying by the end of 2016 with start dates for the remaining 175,000 square feet coming on over the course of 2017 and into 2018.
At this point, I would like to take a moment to highlight a new disclosure in our 8-K regarding Assembly Row, Pike & Rose as well as the recently added 700 Santana Row. In our supplemental information exhibit starting on Page 16, we have added detail that provides annual guidance from the timing of property operating income at these developments as each of the phases grow towards stabilization. We've also included site plans on the following pages for both of these communities to provide you with a sense of the progress and the scale of these projects and also to provide some context of the interconnection between the phases of each development.
Now let's turn to the balance sheet. As you know, at the beginning of the third quarter we raised $250 million of 3-year unsecured notes that are break record yield for a 30-year of [ph] 3.75%. That issuance is now reflected in our quarter-end metrics. Let me highlight a few of them.
Net debt to EBITDA stands at 5.2x. Our average debt maturity remains at a sector-leading 11-plus years, and our weighted average interest rate is just above 4% with almost all of it fixed. On the equity side, we raised $55 million of common stock through our ATM program during the quarter at an average price per share of $159.38, bringing our year-to-date total ATM issuance to $146 million. As a result of this activity, at quarter end, we had cash in the balance sheet of $100 million, and our $800 million credit facility was completely undrawn. From a capital standpoint, the significant level of liquidity positions us well as we close out 2016 and head in to 2017. As it relates to development and redevelopment, we expect to spend approximately $150 million in the fourth quarter and $400 million to $450 million in 2017. We will fund these capital requirements through a combination of cash on hand, free cash flow, opportunistic issuance under our ATM program and utilization on our line of credit, which we expect to repay rebate through bond issuance in late 2017, early 2018 or sooner if an attractive window available to us. This mix will be dictated by our objective of maintaining our debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 5x to 5.5x range. 
Finally, on the acquisition front where we don't have anything concrete we could report at the moment. We continue to pursue a number of compelling opportunities. While the market remains frothy from a valuation standpoint, we do see long-term value on these opportunities, we'll be aggressive in our pursuit. With 13 years of investment experience in my previous seat, I couldn't be more excited to bring that experience to Federal and work with Jeff Berkes and his acquisitions team in West Coast and with Barry Guardian and his team as my partners on the East Coast as well as with the entire Federal Realty Investment committee.
Lastly, before I turn it over to questions, I'd like to talk to you about my initial impressions from being here for almost 3 months from a, call it, a-new-to-Federal point of view.
First and in my view most importantly, the understanding commercial real estate business is constantly changing and changing quickly, especially in retail is ingrained into Federal's DNA. Federal's approach is proactive and dynamic. It does not approach filling vacancies simply to maintain occupancy and cash flow at the property but where it makes sense, uses that vacancy to reposition, remerchandise and redevelop the entire asset. Each decision that is made is made with the long-term goal of ensuring that each center is relevant for the long term.
Second, the real estate really is that good. Before coming to Federal, I was aware that I had the best-in-class portfolio. My first months here, I've traveled East and West, Coast seeing about half the portfolio so far, and the properties are even better than I had imagined. Third, I am convinced that we are creating the right environments of the mixed-use properties that we are currently developing. I spent time at Assembly Row, Bethesda Row and Santana Row. And to give you a little insight into my personal life, I currently live at Pike & Rose, my work a block away and spend a majority of my free evenings and many weekends at property. You could say I've done my due diligence, a real live-work-play experience, and I couldn't be more confident in the communities we are creating a Pike & Rose and Assembly Row. Lastly, I'm truly impressed with the management here. It'll be easy for senior management to sit back and simply rely upon the power of best-in-class portfolio to grow, but there's foresight and dynamism in the way management is looking to implement its growth initiatives and is practically making investments in people and systems in order to make this happen. You could imagine that during his first 2.5 months here, digging into the detail that support these initial observations I share them with you with confidence and conviction. I look forward to seeing many of you at NAREIT and spending more time with each of you going forward to help you see what I'm seeing at Federal.
With that, operator, you can open up the line for questions.

So my question is how you're thinking about stock buybacks these days with your stock not trading at a double-digit discount versus NAV? And how are you currently thinking about buybacks versus other capital allocation alternatives?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is a long-term business and the notion of changing the capital spending plan and the issuing equity or defining equity, et cetera, based on a 3-month quarterly earnings point to me is not appropriate. We have capital needs that are very clear, very m
componenttext: This is a long-term business and the notion of changing the capital spending plan and the issuing equity or defining equity, et cetera, based on a 3-month quarterly earnings point to me is not appropriate. We have capital needs that are very clear, very much in place and all value-accretive. So the notion of continuing the program where we are is what we believe. Now 4 things that have not started for development that have not started, the CocoWalk conversation that I had in my prepared remarks, et cetera, it's very possible that those -- the decisions to start additional will depend on where the marketplace goes in 2017. But every single thing -- the big point of being disappointed by the guidance of where we are it's, for the most part, as I think it's pretty clear to you is necessary to create the value that we're creating. So the idea of doing a significant buyback at this point is off the table.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Appreciate those comments. And you mentioned -- Let's see, getting res [ph] 37% higher on the new dilution boxes, 42% of space. Curious if you're expecting similar upside for the other remaining 60-ish percent, how those conversations are going and
componenttext: Okay. Appreciate those comments. And you mentioned -- Let's see, getting res [ph] 37% higher on the new dilution boxes, 42% of space. Curious if you're expecting similar upside for the other remaining 60-ish percent, how those conversations are going and when you think you'll have that space tied up.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I've got and we're going to talk through this in Phoenix to the extent there's more time to do that, the ability to do that, we've got to schedule that [indiscernible] at 7,300 square feet, got the schedule that shows the 309 of it, the 42% that's go
componenttext: What I've got and we're going to talk through this in Phoenix to the extent there's more time to do that, the ability to do that, we've got to schedule that [indiscernible] at 7,300 square feet, got the schedule that shows the 309 of it, the 42% that's gone already that shows the specific deals and the timing of those specific deals for the 37% rollover derisked. I've got the schedule shows prospects and shows approximately where we think the rents would be. Approximately, they wouldn't be at 37, but they'd be double-digit, may be more than low double digits, may be higher than that. But again, that is the process that we're going through. The most important thing you have to come away with on this is that these are part and parcel of bigger -- of shopping center repositioning as opposed to filling the boxes. And I just don't think that is really kind of understood as well as it should be. It is a value-creative proposition here, not a defensive one.

componenttextpreview: I'm curious on Pike & Rose. How did the net rents that you're now putting in the 2017 guidance compare to what your original pro forma was? And maybe Dan, could you kind of walk us through the timing of NOI and FFO drag in your 2017 guidance at Pike & Ros
componenttext: I'm curious on Pike & Rose. How did the net rents that you're now putting in the 2017 guidance compare to what your original pro forma was? And maybe Dan, could you kind of walk us through the timing of NOI and FFO drag in your 2017 guidance at Pike & Rose as it opens just kind of that base and price of absorption some of the factors that are going on in there.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take the first part of that on the second part of Jeff's question. One of the things we really wrestled with this time is pretty -- Washington, D.C. in general pre-election kind of every year goes into of "fold your hands and not do much" kind
componenttext: Yes. Let me take the first part of that on the second part of Jeff's question. One of the things we really wrestled with this time is pretty -- Washington, D.C. in general pre-election kind of every year goes into of "fold your hands and not do much" kind of mode, and we have seen that in spades over the last 3 months, not only in Pike & Rose but anecdotally, everything we hear with respect to not only any other residential project but other real estate projects. So the decision-making that happens is -- has really slowed down. Now we wanted to see we're 6% [ph] leased at Pallas at about $2.40 a foot, Jeff. We expect that $2.40 [ph] a foot to grow but far more modestly over the next couple of years that we had initially projected. So I think we're expecting that $2.40 through the next few years to go to something like $2.55. And initially, that number was $2.85 or $2.90. So I want to do something for you for a second on -- if you wouldn't mind and indulge me, and it relates to our residential operations and our ability to figure out how to do that you wouldn't mind. I think if you take a look at what happens with us at Bethesda, what happened with us at Santana Row, what happened with us behind Congressional, we know how to build residential. I think we do a really good job at it. If you went back in 2008 when we opened up Bethesda Row's [indiscernible] 180 units there, we underwrote $2.55 and we hit $2.40 or $2.39 or something like that. So we missed those numbers in 2008, too. And if you can imagine what it was like, it's probably understandable.  We're at $3.10 a foot today, and that's over 3% CAGR over that period of time in a market where it also has a lot of additional supply. So the notion that -- from my perspective, the prudence to take that into 6 to 7 is simply a recognition of not only the supply in the market but what is happening to create that real street with [indiscernible] on top of the other. And accordingly, I just didn't feel right keeping the number where it was. But I don't -- I'm hoping that you don't view that as, "My gosh, what in the world are these guys doing in residential?" Take a look at Bethesda, take a look at the other actual numbers in the West Coast, take a look at Congressional, and I think you'll feel a whole different about that. But that's where we are, $2.40 to the mid-$2.50s or so over the period of time that we guided as opposed to something that was much closer to $2.85 or 2.90.

componenttext: Yes. I think I will point you to in terms of the ramp-up. And in 2017, our assumptions assume that we'll get about 75% of that income in 2017 and progress into 2018 and stabilize in 2019 at that number. I think that, that provides. And I think for each of the phases, we've made an attempt to kind of give you that guidance you can see how that ramp-up progresses.

componenttext: That's a good question. Right where we expected them to be in that first phase, but even in there, a little slower than we had hoped. In the second phase -- the big pieces that we have in place, the big stuff that we have on schedule, the smaller stuff that has come will be weaker, so it'll be a little diminution I expect on the retail rent that we're getting. In total on the project where we are today, 48 plus 16 -- 64% of POI is basically leased or heavily under lease negotiation now and at 77% of GLA. So a lot of it is locked in, including the big important boxes that need to be there from portion of Pinstriped to H&M ROI, et cetera.

componenttextpreview: Yes. The easy one to talk about is Assembly. We're kicking it. We've got like 55 of them already locked up way ahead of where we thought and ahead of the numbers that we thought we were going to get. And at Pike & Rose, we're on pace [indiscernible] I thi
componenttext: Yes. The easy one to talk about is Assembly. We're kicking it. We've got like 55 of them already locked up way ahead of where we thought and ahead of the numbers that we thought we were going to get. And at Pike & Rose, we're on pace [indiscernible] I think we've got 19 or 20 of them effectively done, and those have been done at or about where the underwriting was. That also has slowed down. It's the same kind of slow process over the last 3 months that we saw at -- that we saw in the rental products. So I'm looking for this election to get over, looking for some sense of freedom, if you will, in the greater Washington, D.C. market, particularly Montgomery County.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not an on-off switch as we talked about before. It's not and you turn it up as that market looks more attractive. You turn it down as they look less attractive. Certainly, the stuff we've been looking at when we forecast on a lot of this stuff is har
componenttext: It's not an on-off switch as we talked about before. It's not and you turn it up as that market looks more attractive. You turn it down as they look less attractive. Certainly, the stuff we've been looking at when we forecast on a lot of this stuff is hard for us to make sense of. We absolutely remain in the market. We are on a couple of things right now that if they make I think a real positive, but we got a ways to go see if they make. But again, it's not an on-off switch. It has been deemphasized because you compare it to the premium even at 6% obviously that they're getting in development.

componenttextpreview: I'll take the first piece of that first. With regards to what's embedded in same-store guidance for next year, given some of the volatility and just the amount of moving pieces in our anchor repositioning initiatives, we think that kind of staying in line
componenttext: I'll take the first piece of that first. With regards to what's embedded in same-store guidance for next year, given some of the volatility and just the amount of moving pieces in our anchor repositioning initiatives, we think that kind of staying in line with this year kind of 3% area is what we have in our model. As it relates to -- there are a couple of boxes that we project will be coming back. One is already released. The AC Marbach's at Assembly Row, which effectively, we proactively went after. It's still occupied and they will vacate at the end of the year. That space will be vacant for most of 2017 until Trader Joe's takes a big chunk of it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Same with Club here at Santana Row, which is being converted out and transferred to another use. It's going to be a very big positive, but it's going to come out of '17. So that process is, I think, should continue. Net-net, you should see increases overa
componenttext: Same with Club here at Santana Row, which is being converted out and transferred to another use. It's going to be a very big positive, but it's going to come out of '17. So that process is, I think, should continue. Net-net, you should see increases overall, particularly as we get to the latter part of the year.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow-up on Jeff's question. You talked about slower growth, affecting slower growth in residential rent Phase 1 at Pike & Rose, but are you actually expecting there to be any roll-down of ready rent at Pallas over the next year or
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up on Jeff's question. You talked about slower growth, affecting slower growth in residential rent Phase 1 at Pike & Rose, but are you actually expecting there to be any roll-down of ready rent at Pallas over the next year or so? And maybe you can give some color on how the retail and restaurants are performing in the midst of all the construction.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, we don't expect rent to roll down at In fact, one of the things that's been very clear is they continue to command a premium in the marketplace, and that's a real important fact. Listen, we're not going to say -- I don't think we're going to see
componenttext: Yes. No, we don't expect rent to roll down at In fact, one of the things that's been very clear is they continue to command a premium in the marketplace, and that's a real important fact. Listen, we're not going to say -- I don't think we're going to see the increases that I hope we were going to see as the rest of the supply in the marketplace dissipated a little bit, given the construction that's underway. The construction has absolutely impacted the Phase 1 restaurants a little bit. Restaurants are doing fine, just not great. The retailers are not doing well until that second phase opens up. So there is clearly softness throughout Pike & Rose, but it's funny, you got those and you've got [indiscernible] who both live there and spend the time there. And every single time they come in and say, "Don't worry about it." We are in terms of getting it right. Also, with respect to construction and how that is moving along, we're moving along on-time and on budget, which we're really pleased about. So the -- when you look at who's coming here, REI is not adding new space. REI is relocating from 2 miles away or 1.5 miles away to a place that is a whole lot better in terms of what they believe their customer, the same with Porsche the same with a number of the restaurants that we're talking about in Phase 2. So what we are seeing -- and that makes me really happy because it's not adding more retail supply into the marketplace, is relocating the better tenants to better products. That's what you should expect as we move forward. So we've got to get Phase 2 open.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on the disruption, I guess, at Pike & Rose. One, how come we keep hearing about the disruption there, but we don't necessarily hear about it at Assembly? What's unique at Pike & Rose where it's becoming more of an issue than it is at Assembly?
componenttext: Question on the disruption, I guess, at Pike & Rose. One, how come we keep hearing about the disruption there, but we don't necessarily hear about it at Assembly? What's unique at Pike & Rose where it's becoming more of an issue than it is at Assembly?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really clear, really easy to say. The market stinks compared to Assembly. So you have construction that's going on at Assembly, but you got a very strong event at the market. The power right through to the extent that human beings are coming in decid
componenttext: It's really clear, really easy to say. The market stinks compared to Assembly. So you have construction that's going on at Assembly, but you got a very strong event at the market. The power right through to the extent that human beings are coming in deciding where they're going to live compared to what the supply choices are at Pike & Rose Montgomery County, we don't have that luxury. There are other choices, there are other places, there are lower rent alternatives that you can pay, given the environment that's there. If you just think about that in so many different ways, when you have a strong market, some of those stuff that's coming out in Silicon Valley, we're having to solve Silicon Valley today [indiscernible] just blow me away. The things people will do and put up with when there supply in the marketplace is -- just doesn't matter. There's a lot of choice in the markets, it does.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then for that second bucket where you're walking you through for the 2017 bridge and you talk about the development and value-creation drag, how much of that $0.06 to $0.10 is really tied to the Miami kicking off those projects as oppose
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then for that second bucket where you're walking you through for the 2017 bridge and you talk about the development and value-creation drag, how much of that $0.06 to $0.10 is really tied to the Miami kicking off those projects as opposed to Pike & Rose and Assembly?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It is a couple of cents in Miami. And we really kind of thought should we put that guidance, should we talk about that, but here's what's happening in Miami. We'll talk about that for a few minutes. The easier of the 2 to talk about is CocoWalk. Coco
componenttext: Yes. It is a couple of cents in Miami. And we really kind of thought should we put that guidance, should we talk about that, but here's what's happening in Miami. We'll talk about that for a few minutes. The easier of the 2 to talk about is CocoWalk. CocoWalk -- the dilution that would come from CocoWalk is part of a plan that would knock down part of the shopping center and effectively redevelop physically a big part of the shopping center. And obviously, from demolition cost to lost rents to disruption, obviously, that's dilutive. To the extent, we can't get the numbers to work and again, that will come through the investment committee next year, we won't do that. But I did not want to not include that in guidance to the extent we can get to it. At Sunset, it's a different story. At Sunset, we are dealing with a broken property. We've known that from the beginning. We had some nice income and FFO from that property in the first couple of years that we have it. But obviously, that income stream is being reduced as the conversation of a redeveloped property has become very clear and have tenants sit there and don't perform. So there, we know we got at least another year of entitlement work to do to be able to get to what is a much more significant redevelopment. We're not -- the only impact in 2017 will be a slowly shrinking income stream over there. So most of what we're talking about here is CocoWalk and a little bit of Sunset in '17.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Morgan with Canaccord.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going to the 700 Santana that you talked about 2019 opening and 2021 stabilization. Obviously, in the case of the Splunk site there, it was preleased. Could you give any kind of color about how you think about the tenancy for 700 Santana, how much yo
componenttext: Just going to the 700 Santana that you talked about 2019 opening and 2021 stabilization. Obviously, in the case of the Splunk site there, it was preleased. Could you give any kind of color about how you think about the tenancy for 700 Santana, how much you would look to pre-lease, how chunky it might be.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jeff. So remember on 500 Santana Row, we did not pre-lease that building. We started and after construction was underway we leased 100% of the building so just want to make sure you understand that. Before I get into the specifics on how we intend to
componenttext: It's Jeff. So remember on 500 Santana Row, we did not pre-lease that building. We started and after construction was underway we leased 100% of the building so just want to make sure you understand that. Before I get into the specifics on how we intend to approach the leasing of 700, let me tell you what 700 is. 500 Santana Row was adding an office building to Santana Row and a bunch of parking spaces that we can use nights and weekends. 700 is a lot more than that. With 700 Santana Row, we are capping off the end of Santana Row and really, for all intents and purposes, except for our last residential project over the east side of the site, we're finishing Santana Row. So 700 Santana Row is some 30,000 square feet or about [ph] that of additional retail and restaurant on the ground floor with a magnificent plaza in front of it that's really going to complete how Santana looks and feels, and it's a 1300 space parking garage, which is going to significantly add to a parking pool at the end of the street and help us drive rents and sales for the south of Santana Row. So unlike 500 Santana, it's not just an office building. It is kind of a signature development that really caps off and finished 700 Santana -- or finishes Santana Row. Now as it relates to the lease of the office space, we are already out the market. It's way early. We already have a couple of nibbles, which are exciting but leasing early will kick off in earnest, like it does with every building in Silicon Valley, when there's actually a hole in the ground and construction activity, and that's not going to be until sometime next year. As we get into the end of the year and we start to do tours and fuel interest in the building, we'll be making a decision about whether we look to lease that building 100% to one tenant or whether we break it out. When leased 500, we were very intent on leasing that building to one tenant. 700 will have to wait and see. I think there's a higher likelihood we can hold a tenant at 700, which is why you're seeing an extended stabilization period vis--vis building like 500.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing, Paul, I would add to that is we had our board out here, and we're talking about it is the requirement on tenants here, just like everywhere else in the country to be in places that are fully amenitized and really environmentally friendly t
componenttext: The only thing, Paul, I would add to that is we had our board out here, and we're talking about it is the requirement on tenants here, just like everywhere else in the country to be in places that are fully amenitized and really environmentally friendly to what they are is huge. And the notion of finishing up the back parts looking straight down in a row has a whole lot of appeal to a whole lot of developers, and there's not other products that's -- that can be like that, which is what we heard from Splunk, which is why this validates this in addition to having with headquarters here in addition to Wakefield there's the 300 Santana Row that's leased, so this is becoming or has become a far more validated office location. Of all the possible places to put offices in Santana Row, that's the best spot. So with considering all of that, we decided to move forward.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And if we look at the supply pipeline, Paul, in the market right now, there's really only one other supportive amenetized place where office tenants can go. And by the time we're leased in 700, that option may go away, and we may be the only amenetiz
componenttext: Yes. And if we look at the supply pipeline, Paul, in the market right now, there's really only one other supportive amenetized place where office tenants can go. And by the time we're leased in 700, that option may go away, and we may be the only amenetized place. But regardless, nobody has got the amenities we do. And like Don said, that's hugely, hugely important to all the companies, tech and non-tech, to recruit and retain employees so we're pretty bullish on it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's very helpful. Did you -- if I missed it or not, but did you give the cost and the yield target?
componenttext: Great. That's very helpful. Did you -- if I missed it or not, but did you give the cost and the yield target?

componenttextpreview: Yes. It's in the 8-K on Page 16.
componenttext: Yes. It's in the 8-K on Page 16.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll take a look. My other question then, going back to Pike & Rose, just bigger picture. If you think about you've had a lot of the mixed-use projects. In some, you've gone more all in. In Pike & Rose, you started more modestly. And a lot of this i
componenttext: Okay. I'll take a look. My other question then, going back to Pike & Rose, just bigger picture. If you think about you've had a lot of the mixed-use projects. In some, you've gone more all in. In Pike & Rose, you started more modestly. And a lot of this is case-by-case and market-by-market but in retrospect, as you look at Pike & Rose, would you have tried to structure Phase 1 a little bit differently or was it just an issue in terms of the residential market there and kind of you still think the phasing was right?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, a hindsight is a tough way to look at the things. There's no question about that if we've given everything I know, we would probably put the money that is in the residential building on Pallas on the retail street first. I would've done that. We had
componenttext: Paul, a hindsight is a tough way to look at the things. There's no question about that if we've given everything I know, we would probably put the money that is in the residential building on Pallas on the retail street first. I would've done that. We had some disagreement within the company whether that made sense because at the time, we did what we did for a very good reason. And that was the existing shopping center that was there, which we did not disturb during the initial phase extremely productive and effectively allowed us to move some of the tenants from that shopping center into the new shopping center like [indiscernible]. So there were good reasons to do it, but it is important to have enough critical mass on the street to be able to create the environment. Now if the residential market has stayed as strong as it was, none of this would've mattered. And back to like most questions before, the residential empowered right through without the environment on the street fully created. But when you have weakness in the marketplace, there's no question that the reliance on the health of the established retail street is a critical component. I don't know if that helps or not, but that's what happened.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at Pike & Rose and, I guess, Pallas specifically, how much values embedded in the top source versus the rest of the building? So you may be 80% -- 86% leased but how much of that -- of the top floors does that value relate to the rest of the build
componenttext: Looking at Pike & Rose and, I guess, Pallas specifically, how much values embedded in the top source versus the rest of the building? So you may be 80% -- 86% leased but how much of that -- of the top floors does that value relate to the rest of the building?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Craig. There's no question that the top floors and we've got 20 units -- 12 left to go -- 12 left to go up there. It's disproportionately higher. Those units have been slower going. That is part of the math feeling uncomfortable wi
componenttext: That's a good question, Craig. There's no question that the top floors and we've got 20 units -- 12 left to go -- 12 left to go up there. It's disproportionately higher. Those units have been slower going. That is part of the math feeling uncomfortable with the 7 [ph] number that was left there, so you're on to an important part of it. Basically, the lower floors and the cheaper rent have more price sensitivity in a weaker market, effectively, than we had hoped. So I can't do a percentage for you, but I will tell you that the preponderance of units left are in those upper floors, and that does -- we don't believe w3 going to get to the rents that we wanted to get to up there and particularly in the first roll or 2.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just thinking of Pike & Rose in total, how much value is assigned to retail, offices, resi and other?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have that here but the -- you'll never get me to think differently on this. These projects are into growth. They're integrated projects. The retail is critical to the resi, the office is critical to the retail, all the way around. So we look at th
componenttext: I don't have that here but the -- you'll never get me to think differently on this. These projects are into growth. They're integrated projects. The retail is critical to the resi, the office is critical to the retail, all the way around. So we look at them as total projects. So I don't have the pieces here. I expect we'll have it there for you in Phoenix, but you'll never get me to suggest that those things will be looked at separately.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: And just real quickly in terms of the anchor closings, how many would you put in the bankruptcy bucket, and how many would you put on your proactive repositioning bucket?

componenttext: It's about half and half. In looking in total, you've got spaces there a couple of 6 [ph], and we're breaking them up as part of bigger redevelopment. So it's not as pure and as clear as you'd like them there, but about half and half.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, you're pretty fired up. Haven't heard you this fired up for a long time. So you're revving on the high side. Your energy level is coming through. So we put a lot of thought into it. Just question for you. You guys have obviously spent a lot of time t
componenttext: Don, you're pretty fired up. Haven't heard you this fired up for a long time. So you're revving on the high side. Your energy level is coming through. So we put a lot of thought into it. Just question for you. You guys have obviously spent a lot of time thinking about the redevelopment projects that you're rolling out. You have a lot that you've done over the years with experience at Santana and Assembly and others. And it sounds like the residential like we understand that the residential Montgomery is more so that's pressuring the rents on the residential side, but can you just walk through why the retail would be pressured there? Is that purely because some of the retail that leases at the smaller spaces is sort of directly attributing to how the residential is going and those more of amenity-based and they're saying, "Hey, if the people aren't here, I'm not going to pay rent." Or just help us walk through how those 2 are intertwined.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess what I would say -- and Chris is here. I don't know -- I assume he'll go and add to what I say. But the reality is today and we've been talking about this for a while, retailers -- and this includes the boxes, this includes small people, the
componenttext: Well, I guess what I would say -- and Chris is here. I don't know -- I assume he'll go and add to what I say. But the reality is today and we've been talking about this for a while, retailers -- and this includes the boxes, this includes small people, the small shops and includes really [indiscernible] are a whole lot more cautious with their underwriting and are a whole lot more -- the negotiations are more retail-centric than they are landlord-centric at the moment in a number of places. And when it comes to development, the ability to underwrite sales in a new development is less predictable. So if the market is softer -- and I do believe the market generally is softer from a standpoint of propensity to take risks. And it certainly is in the area then you underwrite lower going up lower numbers are lower rent lower rent is hard negotiation. It takes longer to do and it also includes the other term associated with it. That's really what it's about, from my perspective as I see it. The other thing and you see it in Assembly to the other -- going the other way, when you got a big sample size of first phase retail project there and that first phase is very successful, it makes a whole lot easier to leave that second phase. We don't have a big sample size in the first phase I'm a little bit [indiscernible] and accordingly, you have tougher economics to negotiate here. Having said that, I just don't -- I don't want -- I can't overemphasize enough the fact that the anchor system in the second phase is done and is critical to the project. So even if rents were a little lower in the remaining small shop base, that is not a big cost for the differential and the yield.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add on exactly what Don said, and I would remind you we got 1 million feet on. We got to make sure we differentiate our projects. Pike & Rose is truly unique and authentic to anything else we own on The fact that we're almost 80% leased on ou
componenttext: I would just add on exactly what Don said, and I would remind you we got 1 million feet on. We got to make sure we differentiate our projects. Pike & Rose is truly unique and authentic to anything else we own on The fact that we're almost 80% leased on our retail in Phase 2 GLA is fantastic. So just keep all of that in mind as you're talking more strength as The Street open as the experience can be more of a full experience for the consumer, it's only going to get stronger.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Look, you go to the site, you can see that. But I guess the question is, Don, from what -- when you guys talked about sort of a NAREIT and second quarter when you revised down the yield expectation till now and now they're being revised down, I gue
componenttext: Right. Look, you go to the site, you can see that. But I guess the question is, Don, from what -- when you guys talked about sort of a NAREIT and second quarter when you revised down the yield expectation till now and now they're being revised down, I guess, is that just that the market has been continued soft and, therefore, that's impacted the retail discussions more? And then the second part of that is for Dan G, should we expect have been with the delay through 2019 until stabilization, does that mean that this project weighs on earnings until then? Or are there other things in the company that will act as offset so it's not as though mentally we think about Pike & Rose weighing on the company through 2019, but it's that it takes longer to stabilize, but there are other positive offsets to that within the total organization?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Phase 2 -- the Phase 1, Phase 2 yield reductions are largely residential. Don't make a big deal about the retail. It's not that. That answers the first part of the question. The second part of the question is Pike & Rose is accretive to the company. I
componenttext: The Phase 2 -- the Phase 1, Phase 2 yield reductions are largely residential. Don't make a big deal about the retail. It's not that. That answers the first part of the question. The second part of the question is Pike & Rose is accretive to the company. It is not weighing down the company. We're talking about a value-additive project here. And if you look year-over-year, I mean the numbers about the income that contributed from this project and the continues to go up. So it's not that at all. And certainly, when coupled with the anchor lease-up, when coupled with the opening of Splunk and other development projects, when coupled with the redevelopments all the way through, that the total company continues. And as I started to say compared to the beginning of my remarks where we thought it was going to be in total over the long term. So you clearly have a soft period of time here and from an accounting perspective if you will, a cash flow perspective relative to value creation but not from a long-term value creation.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one question in terms of kind of medium-term strategy. Once you look past the current projects, kind of what's your appetite to do further projects or take back certain anchor space that will cause near-term drag? I fully get the longer-term value cr
componenttext: Just one question in terms of kind of medium-term strategy. Once you look past the current projects, kind of what's your appetite to do further projects or take back certain anchor space that will cause near-term drag? I fully get the longer-term value creation here, but what's that appetite to take more space back things will cause that near-term drag to where, okay, '17 growth will be muted but then more projects '18 will be muted as well because of these longer-term value creation projects.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, it's such a great question, and it gets down to the balance of the business plan. The -- when I try to address this in my remarks as I could, the combination of all of the things, including the decentralization, which is really working as it relat
componenttext: George, it's such a great question, and it gets down to the balance of the business plan. The -- when I try to address this in my remarks as I could, the combination of all of the things, including the decentralization, which is really working as it relates to getting to redevelopment and getting to focus, those things as you have pointed out are dilutive in the short term. There's a lot of it. There's no doubt about that. It's happening at the same time that 2 major development projects, Pike & Rose and Assembly Row, are coming up with a heavy construction phase, which are also dilutive. So all of those things happening at the same time have the balance move down to 4% growth, rather than 6% growth or as they're coming out, 8 or 9. If we don't do any more, George, you're looking at 8% and 9% earnings growth. That's the notion of getting there but not having additional future raw material doesn't excite me. So I suspect what you will see is head down and executing what we have a slow down at the period of new raw material for new projects the bulk of '17 to allow us to get back into balance. But this long-term business plan includes those initiatives as the way we create value. So you will see them. I'm not going to tell you every year, you have to wait till next year, you have to wait till the year after that, you have to wait till the year after that for earnings because that's not fair to do, and it's not what our is. You should see an acceleration in '18 you, should see an acceleration in '19 of the earnings growth rate.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. Dan, if -- just going back to the same-store NOI guidance for next year that you softly provided, is that inclusive or exclusive redevelopment and sort of just trying to understand whether or not things like CocoWalk would be included in your thoughts or not.

componenttextpreview: Yes, that's inclusive of redevelopment. And yes, we're including CocoWalk in that number, which obviously, will have a negative impact on that number. And that's why -- there's a lot going on. I think that with the anchor repositioning, we're including Co
componenttext: Yes, that's inclusive of redevelopment. And yes, we're including CocoWalk in that number, which obviously, will have a negative impact on that number. And that's why -- there's a lot going on. I think that with the anchor repositioning, we're including CocoWalk and Sunset, but that 3% is something we're -- area we're comfortable with.

componenttext: And then just -- do you have any additional color on guidance as it relates to maybe G&A?

componenttext: G&A for next year is going to be, call it, $36 million, $37 million, roughly about $9 million a quarter.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Last question, Don. The development exposure as it relates to CIP is continuing to move higher as you guys put more money into projects that will deliver revenue down the road. Do you have a sense as to what peak CIP levels will be? And then
componenttext: Okay. Great. Last question, Don. The development exposure as it relates to CIP is continuing to move higher as you guys put more money into projects that will deliver revenue down the road. Do you have a sense as to what peak CIP levels will be? And then when you think about how you manage risk, what are you comfortable with and how do you measure that risk as it relates to the amount of development that's in progress?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's a very fair question, Chris. And by the way, CIP at the end of the fourth quarter will be lower than CIP at the end of the third quarter as we put this one building into service, and that is, for all intents and purposes, a single building. So
componenttext: Yes. That's a very fair question, Chris. And by the way, CIP at the end of the fourth quarter will be lower than CIP at the end of the third quarter as we put this one building into service, and that is, for all intents and purposes, a single building. So the notion that we'll continue to always rise is not what you should be assuming. Basically, at the end day, 10% of the value of this company with respect to big development is what I feel comfortable with and not more than that. In fact, you sit back and take a look, take a look over the last 3 years, you'll see that we peaked higher than we are today a couple of years ago and remember the year was '13? When effectively we had all the Phase 1s that were not yet in service but going and so you see this heavy construction in the Phase 2s right now. Those things that are put into service will reduce the CIP and I don't think -- I think the way you should look at it is the EBITDA coverage, which we're very comfortable with in the low to mid-5 fixed charge through the roof. It's kind of why we prefunded a bunch of this development in the form of reducing our leverage in the company turning out for 30 years is what we've got. But on broad basis, Chris, look at 10% of the enterprise value as kind of a rough estimate of the math. It's really much more limited by our debt coverage though and our fixed charge coverage and what we place in reserves.
