headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Federal Realty Investment Trust Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Le
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Federal Realty Investment Trust Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Leah Andress. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Dan G, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster, Melissa Solis and James Mil
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call are Don Wood, Dan G, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Chris Weilminster, Melissa Solis and James Milam. They will be available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results.
Although Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations can be attained.
The earnings release and the supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. These documents are available on our website at federalrealty.com.
[Operator Instructions] And now I'd like to turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of our third quarter 2016 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Leah, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we reported third quarter 2016 FFO per share of $1.41, 3.7% better than last year's exceptionally strong quarter and above our internal expectations. Given these results, we're comfortable reaffirmi
componenttext:
Thank you, Leah, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we reported third quarter 2016 FFO per share of $1.41, 3.7% better than last year's exceptionally strong quarter and above our internal expectations. Given these results, we're comfortable reaffirming our previously issued guidance range for full year '16, in effect narrowing it a bit to $5.63 to $5.67. 
I want to talk about the third quarter's reported results, expectations for the balance of the year, and most importantly, what this means for '17 since we released initial guidance last night that falls short of Street expectations, mostly for value-enhancing initiatives that have short-term costs. More on that in a few minutes.
Let's get started with the quarter. At $1.41 a share, following $1.38 in the first quarter, $1.42 on the second, we're happy with that result, given the fact that as anticipated and as we've discussed previously, this is the quarter when you really see the full effect of the big vacancies we've been talking about in the past few quarters. Sports Authority is gone, the A&P, Hancock Fabrics, Hudson Trailer boxes are gone, et cetera, and they were all in and rent paying a year ago. When coupled with a particularly strong quarter a year ago where FFO per share had gone 11%, this all made for a tough year-over-year comparison. Those vacancies this quarter, along with the inclusion of poorly leased Sunset Place and CocoWalk, resulted in a reduction of our portfolio's lease percentage of 120 basis points to 94.3% and a physical occupancy reduction of 200 basis points.
Those vacancies, in addition to some strong bad debt recoveries and percentage rent positives in last year's quarter, resulted in an anemic same-store growth comparison by some 150 to 200 basis points lower than they would have otherwise have been. When you think about it, it does say an awful a lot about the portfolio that same-store grew 1.5% in the quarter that occupancy dipped as much as it did.
It would be wrong to conclude that leasing activity has trailed off, however, as can be seen in the leasing done this quarter. There was a lot of it. 93 comparable deals, that's more leases than any quarter in the last couple of years, for 427,000 feet of space at an average rent of $31.25, 14% higher than the tenants they replaced. In fact, over the first 9 months of this year, we've done 269 comparable deals for 1.2 million square feet, 17% more volume than the first 9 months of 2015.
And that leads me to the discussion that I want to have about our initial guidance for '17 of $5.83 to $5.93 per share, so let me pivot now and use the rest of my prepared remarks to discuss 2017. I think this will make us one of the first to issue guidance and this year particularly requires explanation.
And let me start out by being crystal clear that despite 4% projected FFO growth at the midpoint of guidance next year, nothing has changed in our outlook as to the achievability of hitting or beating our long-term business plan goal of doubling income over 10 years. In fact, it's precisely because of the items diluting 2017 that I have greater confidence we'll get there. To make it as clear as possible, we've included a schedule on this year's -- in this quarter's press release and 8-K on the reconciliation of FFO guidance -- on the FFO guidance page that will parallel the comments I'm about to make. 
A little background first as to why we are so aggressively repositioning so much of our portfolio. We see -- we have seen consumer behavior changing and changing at an accelerated pace and impacting nearly every business. Retail real estate is no exception. That's why a couple of years back, we turned up the heat on virtually every initiative we had at the same time in every facet of our business at a time when capital was cheap in an effort to put this best-of-class portfolio in the best possible shape to thrive in markets where consumers demand a higher level of service and an environment that they want to hang out in as an integral part of their lives. Of course, it takes time, often more than we would like, but we view it as critical to the long-term strengthening of this real estate portfolio. We feel that we're best positioned to do this given the quality locations of our real estate and our track record of success in transforming different types of retail real estate.
So, we accelerated the timing to start the second phases of our big mixed-use developments before the paint was dry in the first phase even though second phase construction affects first phase performance until the overall sense of place is established.
We jumped into Miami with not 1, but 2 new retail opportunities that fixed broken but well-located retail destinations even though the existing income stream will, of course, be disrupted in preparation of that process. We accelerated the full build-out of Santana Row, first with the option on the 12 acres across the street called Santana West then with the spec build, but now fully leased Splunk office building and currently with the approval and announcement to move forward with 215,310,000-square foot office and retail tower that will anchor the end of the street.
We restructured our personnel through a decentralization and systems investment initiative so that the human capital was sufficient, properly aligned and had the tools necessary to accelerate progress in both the mixed-use and the core portfolios. We took advantage of a very favorable capital environment, both by delevering concurrent with and somewhat ahead of heavy development spend and by turning on our debt portfolio with $700 million of 30-year unsecured bonds, creating a level of safety unmatched by any of our peers, of course, at the expense of lower earnings caused by higher short-term interest expenses and lower overall leverage. We have and continue to identify more value-enhancing redevelopment opportunities with our new decentralized structure than ever before in our history and we're getting more of them started faster even though they hurt short-term earnings. Many of those opportunities have been made possible by our ability to get back on the performing anchor boxes. 
And it's this last point, the one related to the far deeper redevelopment pools sparked by anchor vacancies that is one of the 3 main reasons 2017 appears light even though it is this redevelopment initiative that will drive significant value creation and earnings growth to follow. And if the markets are softening and the cost of money is increasing, the quality of the real estate location has always been the best hedge possible. We've got the best volume growth in the portfolio. I'll give you some numbers.
The re-lease of the excess anchor vacancy in the portfolio creates an obvious drag, earnings drag, until the spaces are coordinated into the bigger development plan. Then, in some cases, entitled, then leased, then turned over to the tenant for interior build-out, then occupied and finally rent paying. Generally, we're not just trying to re-lease vacant boxes, we are trying to reposition and fortify retail destinations and that simply takes longer.
Consider this. We have 700,000 square feet of anchor and near-anchor vacancy in the quarter. That's more than double the box vacancy that we have historically carried. It's Sports Authority, it's A&P, it's Hudson Trail, it's Hancock Fabrics, you know their names. The prior rent on that 730,000 feet was $19.75 and represents $14.5 million of rent or $0.20 a share of former in-place annual rent that's missing.
As of today, we've got 42% of that space re-leased and re-leased at 37% higher rent than was previously being paid. It's re-leased to Ulta and DSW at Brick shopping center, to Field & Stream and Uncle Giuseppe's at Melville Shopping Center, to T.J. Maxx at Pentagon Row, to L.A. Fitness at Delmar, et cetera. Every one of those deals is part of a much more comprehensive repositioning of the shopping center, not merely a re-leasing of the box. But it generally doesn't become rent paying until '17 and '18 with a heavy weighting toward the back end of '17 and '18. Accordingly, we forecast 2017 to be roughly $5 million or $0.07 a share lower than it otherwise would be.  Of course, the value creation of these redeveloped shopping centers will be significant when complete.
Now let's go to the big developments and talk through the natural short-term dilution that comes from the delivery and lease-up process associated with the residential development and Phase 2 of Assembly and Pike & Rose as well as the dilution that comes from a probable reconfiguration of CocoWalk that we considered in our 2017 guidance.
First, the Phase 2 residential building under construction at both Assembly and Pike & Rose. At Assembly, the 447-unit residential building, Whole Montage [ph], and at Pike & Rose, the 272-unit residential building called The Henri will both begin deliveries and lease up in '17. The dilution that comes from this process is expected to exceed $4 million or $0.06 a share. Operating costs, marketing, interest expense naturally exceed revenue as development turns over these building's operating fees. Expenses exceed revenue significantly at first unless those buildings lease up. It's unavoidable and will create an earnings drag of about $2 million before interest and an additional $2 million at the FFO line. Those 2 buildings alone are expected, however, to create well over $100 million of value when stabilized. 
Similarly, at CocoWalk in Florida, while we haven't completely finalized our redevelopment plans and numbers, we do hope to able to get those plans through our investment committee early next year, which will allow us to begin repositioning space and tenants and beginning construction at a portion of the shopping center in 2017. As you would expect -- as you would assume, occupancy at CocoWalk and at Sunset, for that matter, will get worse before it gets better and we thought it prudent to include the impact of Miami's first step toward repositioning estimated at a couple of cents a share in our guidance. Obviously, the value expected to be created at CocoWalk far exceeds the 2017 accounting cost. Basically, our 2017 guidance would have been roughly $0.16 a share higher if we were simply not building Phase 2s at Pike & Rose or Assembly and not proactively taking out our anchor space. Hopefully, the enhancements we're making to our disclosure including the timing of income coming online will provide more clarity now and in the future. Those are Dans ideas.
The final significant item affecting 2017 guidance is our lower near-term operating income expectations at Pike & Rose. Continuing softness in the Montgomery County, Maryland residential market, especially in the last 90 days, and the ongoing construction disruption of Phase 2 simply made me uncomfortable maintaining the 7% yield guidance at Pike & Rose. And accordingly, you'll note a change in our 8-K disclosure for both the first and the second phases, as I alluded to earlier, are so integrated that they really need to be used together to a 6% to 7% yield with better disclosure on the time periods for getting there. The disclosure now also includes site maps that we're adding that make the proximity of the Phase 2 construction to Phase 1 quite apparent, along with the land and entitlements for future phases. I -- we remain as positive as ever on what we're creating there, but have our eyes wide open as to the additional time that it's going to take to get there. The combined impact of that lower expected yield and lower pace are negatively impacting our '17 guidance by about $0.06 a share. All told, a $0.22 a share or more that is pushed back from '17 to the next 12, 24, 36 months in addition to the positive momentum in contributions for the many initiatives we're working on and from those that we'll add on to in the future. 
So, that's it for my prepared remarks. We've got a lot going on around here, it's a huge investment in our future, lots of construction in progress on the balance sheet in the right type of products for the future on some of the best pieces of real estate in some the best markets of the country, our heads are down and we continue to execute. I look forward to spending more time with many of you in a couple of weeks in Phoenix going through this and whatever else you'd like to talk through. 
Now let me turn it over to Dan before opening up the lines for your questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don, and Leah. And good morning, everyone. Don covered a lot in his remarks so I will fill just a few places as it relates to the third quarter and the balance of 2016. Then I want to spend some time going through a few specific areas that will
componenttext:
Thank you, Don, and Leah. And good morning, everyone. Don covered a lot in his remarks so I will fill just a few places as it relates to the third quarter and the balance of 2016. Then I want to spend some time going through a few specific areas that will help you with your modeling of Federal going forward. 
First, the third quarter. The $1.41 of FFO per share and same-store NOI growth of 1.5% were fully in step with our expectations for the quarter. As Melissa specifically discussed in our second quarter call in August, same-store growth is expected to decelerate in the second half of 2017 with most of that concentrated in the third quarter. Now that was due not only to the difficult third quarter comp we faced, but also due to the impact on occupancy and cash flow of our anchor repositioning activity.
With portfolio occupancy at 93.1% at quarter end versus 95.1% at third quarter 2015, note that almost 150 of the 200 basis point diminution can be attributed to those 8 anchor boxes that Don referenced in his remarks: the 3 A&Ps, 3 Sports Authoritys, Hudson Trail and Hancock Fabrics, which were all in occupancy in '15 were gone from third quarter of 2016. Also note that this vacancy, totaling over 320,000 square feet, is at highly productive centers located in dense in-fill markets, many of which we are redeveloping and remerchandising like Assembly Square in Boston, Melville Mall in Long Island, Montrose Crossing in North Bethesda, Westgate in San Jose, to name a few. Needless to say, we feel very good about our ability to reposition these boxes effectively.
Through the first 3 quarters of 2016, our same-store growth stands at 3%, 1.9% excluding redevelopments. We project fourth quarter to be in line with this run rate and expect same-store growth for the year to remain in the 3% area.
Next, on the development front with respect to Assembly Row and Pike & Rose, contribution for the third quarter was $6 million, up from $4.9 million during the second quarter. Assembly Row Phase 1 is 100% leased and now is producing approximately 95% of its projected stabilized property operating income or POI. As Don mentioned, Pike & Rose Phase 1 is behind from a run rate perspective, mostly driven by softness in effective rents at the PerSei and Pallas apartments and currently we are closer to a 60% projected stabilized POI on a run rate basis. Although we are pleased to be hitting our occupancy projections, the PerSei almost 98% leased and Pallas almost 86% leased at quarter end. Further, we continue to demand a premium to the market of 10% to 15%. 
Out west at 500 Santana Row, we are slightly ahead of plan and expect Splunk to open at the end of the fourth quarter. Just a reminder, this 234,000-square foot development is delivering a 9% cash on cost yield. Given the success at 500 Santana, combined with the continued strong demand for office space in this submarket, we are moving forward with the development of 700 Santana Row, a 310,000-square foot office and retail development located at the end of Santana Row, which will effectively finish off the street. We are projecting a stabilized cash on cost of 7% with projected delivery in 2019 and stabilization in 2021.
Now let me cover a few areas to provide additional clarity for your modeling of Federal going forward. As it relates to the core businesses and the impact of our anchor repositioning initiatives, we expect overall portfolio occupancy to stay at its current 93% through fourth quarter and remain at this level for most of 2017. We project occupancy will begin to improve at the end of 2017 and continue into 2019. 
With respect to the 730,000 square feet of anchor or near-anchor vacancy in effect during the third quarter, 42% or 310,000 square feet is leased. Of that 310,000, 135,000 will be rent paying by the end of 2016 with start dates for the remaining 175,000 square feet coming on over the course of 2017 and into 2018.
At this point, I would like to take a moment to highlight the new disclosure in our 8-K regarding Assembly Row, Pike & Rose as well as the recently added 700 Santana Row. In our supplemental information exhibit starting on Page 16, we have added detail which provides annual guidance on the timing of property operating income at these developments as each of the phases grow towards stabilization. We've also included site plans on the following pages for both of these communities to provide you with a sense of the progress and the scale of these projects and also to provide some context of the interconnection between the phases at each development.
Now let's turn to the balance sheet. As you know, at the beginning of the third quarter we raised $250 million of 30-year unsecured notes that are REIT record yield for a 30-year of 3.75%. That issuance is now reflected in our quarter-end metrics. Let me highlight a few of them.
Net debt-to-EBITDA stands at 5.2x. Our average debt maturity remains at a sector-leading 11-plus years and our weighted average interest rate is just above 4% with almost all of it fixed. 
On the equity side, we raised $55 million of common stock through our ATM program during the quarter at an average price per share of $159.38, bringing our year-to-date total ATM issuance to $146 million. As a result of this activity, at quarter end, we had cash on the balance sheet of $100 million and our $800 million credit facility was completely undrawn. 
From a capital standpoint, the significant level of liquidity positions us well as we close out 2016 and head in to 2017. 
As it relates to development and redevelopment, we expect to spend approximately $150 million in the fourth quarter and $400 million to $450 million in 2017. We will fund these capital requirements through a combination of cash on hand, free cash flow, opportunistic issuance under our ATM program and utilization on our line of credit, which we expect to repay through a bond issuance in late 2017, early 2018 or sooner if an attractive window is available to us. This mix will be dictated by our objective of maintaining our debt-to-EBITDA ratio in 5x to 5.5x range. 
Finally, on the acquisition front, while we don't have anything concrete we can report at the moment we continue to pursue a number of compelling opportunities. While the market remains frothy from a valuation standpoint, we do see long-term value in these opportunities and we'll be aggressive in our pursuit. With 13 years of investment experience in my previous seat, I couldn't be more excited to bring that experience to Federal and work with Jeff Berkes and his acquisitions team on the West Coast and with Barry Carty and team as my partners on the East Coast as well as with the entire Federal Realty Investment Committee.
Lastly, before I turn it over to questions, I'd like to talk to you about my initial impressions from being here for almost 3 months from a, call it, a-new-to-Federal point of view.
First, and in my view, most importantly, the understanding that the commercial real estate business is constantly changing and changing quickly, especially in retail, is ingrained into Federal's DNA. Federal's approach is proactive and dynamic. It does not approach filling vacancies simply to maintain occupancy and cash flow at the property, but where it makes sense, uses that vacancy to reposition, remerchandise and redevelop the entire asset. Each decision that is made, was made with the long-term goal of ensuring that each center is relevant for the long term.
Second, the real estate really is that good. Before coming to Federal, I was aware that it had a best-in-class portfolio. In my first months here, I've traveled East and West Coasts seeing about half the portfolio so far, and the properties are even better than I had imagined. 
Third, I am convinced that we are creating the right environments at the mixed-use properties that we are currently developing. I had spent time at Assembly Row, Bethesda Row and Santana Row, and to give you a little insight into my personal life, I currently live at Pike & Rose, I work a block away and I spend a majority of my free evenings and many weekends at the property. You could say I've done my due diligence, a real live-work-play experience and I couldn't be more confident in the communities we are creating at Pike & Rose and Assembly Row. 
Lastly, I've been truly impressed with the management here. It would be easy for senior management to sit back and simply rely upon the power of best-in-class portfolio to grow, but there is foresight and dynamism in the way management is looking to implement its growth initiatives and is proactively making investments in its people and its systems in order to make this happen. 
You could imagine I've been in the weeds during this first 2.5 months here, digging into the detail that support these initial observations so I share them with you with confidence and conviction. 
I look forward to seeing many of you at NAREIT and spending more time with each of you going forward to help you see what I'm seeing at Federal.
With that, operator, you can open up the line for questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: You haven't been asked this one a while, but given your historical valuation premium, but what a difference one quarter makes. So, my question is how you're thinking about stock buybacks these days with your stock now trading at a double-digit discount by our estimates NAV? And how are you currently thinking about buybacks versus other capital allocation alternatives?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Haendel, this is a long-term business and the notion of changing the capital spending plan and the issuing equity or buying equity, et cetera, et cetera, based on a 3-month quarterly earnings point to me is not appropriate. We have capital needs that are
componenttext: Haendel, this is a long-term business and the notion of changing the capital spending plan and the issuing equity or buying equity, et cetera, et cetera, based on a 3-month quarterly earnings point to me is not appropriate. We have capital needs that are very clear, very much in place and all value-accretive. The notion of continuing the program where we are is what we believe. Now 4 things that have not started for development that have not started, the CocoWalk conversation that I had in my prepared remarks, et cetera, it's very possible that those -- the decision to start additional will depend on where the marketplace goes in 2017. But every single thing -- I mean, the big point of being disappointed by the guidance of where we are, it, for the most part, as I think it's pretty clear to you, is necessary to create the value that we're creating. So, the idea of doing a significant buyback at this point is off the table.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, appreciate those comments. And you mentioned -- let's see, getting rents 37% higher on the new -- the lease that you're signing for the boxes, 42% of space. Curious if you're expecting similar upside for the other remaining 60-ish percent, how those
componenttext: Okay, appreciate those comments. And you mentioned -- let's see, getting rents 37% higher on the new -- the lease that you're signing for the boxes, 42% of space. Curious if you're expecting similar upside for the other remaining 60-ish percent, how those conversations are going and when you think you'll have that space tied up.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I've got, and we're going to talk through this in Phoenix to the extent there's more time to do that, and the ability to do that, we've got a schedule that shows that whole 730,000 feet. I've got a schedule that shows the 309,000 of it, the 42% that'
componenttext: What I've got, and we're going to talk through this in Phoenix to the extent there's more time to do that, and the ability to do that, we've got a schedule that shows that whole 730,000 feet. I've got a schedule that shows the 309,000 of it, the 42% that's done already that shows the specific deals and the timing of those specific deals for the 37% rollover. The rest, I've got that schedule shows prospects and shows approximately where we think the rents would be. Approximately, they wouldn't be at 37%, but they'd be double digit, maybe more than low double digits, maybe higher than that. But again, that is the process that we're going through. The most important thing you have to come away with on this is that these are part and parcel of bigger -- of shopping center repositioning as opposed to filling the boxes. And I just don't think that is really kind of understood as well as it should be. It is a value-creative proposition here, not a defensive one.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious, on Pike & Rose, how did the net rents that you're now putting in the 2017 guidance compare to what your original pro forma was? And maybe, Dan, can you kind of walk us through the timing of the NOI and FFO drag in your 2017 guidance at Pike &
componenttext: I'm curious, on Pike & Rose, how did the net rents that you're now putting in the 2017 guidance compare to what your original pro forma was? And maybe, Dan, can you kind of walk us through the timing of the NOI and FFO drag in your 2017 guidance at Pike & Rose just as it opens? I'm just kind of wanting to think through like that pace and price of absorption, some of the other factors that are going on there.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take the first part of that, and Dan, jump on in on the second part of Jeff's question. One of the things we really wrestled with this time is pretty -- Washington, D.C., in general, pre-election kind of every year goes into a "fold your hands
componenttext: Yes, let me take the first part of that, and Dan, jump on in on the second part of Jeff's question. One of the things we really wrestled with this time is pretty -- Washington, D.C., in general, pre-election kind of every year goes into a "fold your hands and not do much" kind of mode and we have seen that in spades over the last 3 months not only at Pike & Rose, but anecdotally, everything we hear with respect to not only any other residential project but other real estate projects. So, the decision-making then happens is -- has really slowed down. Now we wanted to be -- we're 86% leased at Pallas at about $2.40 a foot, Jeff. We expect that $2.40 a foot to grow, but far more modestly over the next couple of years than we had initially projected. So, I think we're expecting that $2.40 through the next few years to go to something like $2.55. And initially, that number was $2.85 or $2.90. So, I want to do something for you for a second on, if you wouldn't mind and indulge me, and it relates to our residential operations and our ability to figure out how to do that. I think this is a good time to talk about, if you wouldn't mind. If you take a look at what's happened with us in Bethesda, what's happened with us at Santana Row, what's happened with us behind Congressional, we know how to build residential. I think we do a really good job on it. If you were back in 2008 when we opened up Bethesda Row's upstairs product, 180 units there, we underwrote $2.55 and we hit $2.40 or $2.39 or something like that. So, we missed those numbers in 2008, too. And if you can imagine what 2008 was like, I think that's probably understandable.  We're at $3.10 a foot today, and that's at over 3% CAGR over that period of time in a market where it also has a lot of additional supply. So, the notion that -- from my perspective, the prudence to take that 7% -- to 6% to 7% is simply a recognition of not only the supply in the market but what is happening to create that real streak with the second phase right on top of the other. And accordingly, I just didn't feel right keeping the number where it was. But I don't -- I'm hoping that you don't view that as, my gosh, what in the world are these guys doing in residential? Take a look at Bethesda, take a look at the actual numbers on the West Coast, take a look at Congressional and I think you'll feel a whole lot different about it. But that's where we are, $2.40 to the mid-$2.50s or so over the period of time that we guided as opposed to something that was much closer to $2.85 or 2.90.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's see. So, I don't know, Dan, if you had anything to add on there.
componenttext: Let's see. So, I don't know, Dan, if you had anything to add on there.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I will point you to in terms of the ramp-up, we've added that additional disclosure on Page 16 of our supplemental where I think that gives a fairly good guidance with regards to how property operating income at Phase 1 of Pike & Rose will ra
componenttext: Yes, I think I will point you to in terms of the ramp-up, we've added that additional disclosure on Page 16 of our supplemental where I think that gives a fairly good guidance with regards to how property operating income at Phase 1 of Pike & Rose will ramp up. We project kind of a stabilized $17.5 million property operating income on Phase 1. And in 2017, our assumptions assume that we'll get about 75% of that income in 2017 and it'll progress into 2018 and stabilize in 2019 at that number. I think that, that provides -- and I think for each of the phases, we've made an attempt to kind of give you that guidance, you can see how that ramp-up progresses.

componenttext: Yes, that's a good question. Right where we expected them to be in that first phase, but even there, a little slower than we had hoped. And in the second phase, the big pieces that we have in place -- where is that schedule that has what was leased, the big stuff that we have on schedule, the smaller stuff that is to come will be weaker, so it'll be a little diminution I expect on the retail rent that we're getting. In total on the project, where we are today, 48 plus 16, 64% of POI is basically leased or heavily under lease negotiation now and at 77% of GLA. So, a lot of it is locked in including the big important boxes that need to be there from Porsche to Pinstripes, to H&M, Sur La Table, Lucky, REI, et cetera.

componenttext: And you kicked off condo sales at Assembly in, I think, Q2. How is the pace and price of sales there performed versus your expectation?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the easy one to talk about is Assembly. We're kicking it. We've got like 55 of them already locked up way ahead of where we thought and ahead of the numbers that we thought we were going to get. And at Pike & Rose, we're on pace. It's only I think we
componenttext: Yes, the easy one to talk about is Assembly. We're kicking it. We've got like 55 of them already locked up way ahead of where we thought and ahead of the numbers that we thought we were going to get. And at Pike & Rose, we're on pace. It's only I think we've got 19 or 20 of them effectively of 100 done and those have been done at or about where the underwriting was. That also, though, has slowed down. It's been the same kind of slow process over the last 3 months that we saw at -- we see in the rental products. So, I'm looking for this election to get over. I'm looking for some sense of freedom, if you will, in the greater Washington, D.C. market, particularly Montgomery County.

componenttext: It's not an on-off switch, as we talked about before. It's a knob and you turn it up as that markets  those markets look more attractive. You turn it down as they look less attractive. Certainly, the stuff that we've been looking at when you start talking about forecast, most forecast on a lot of this stuff is hard for us to make sense of. We absolutely remain in the market. We are on a couple of things right now that if they make, I think, a real positive, but we got a ways to go see if they can make. But again, it's not an on-off switch. It has been deemphasized compare to the premiums, even at 6% obviously that youre getting in development.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Well, I'll take the first piece of that. First, with regards to what's embedded in same-store guidance for next year, given some of the volatility and just the amount of moving pieces in our anchor repositioning initiatives, we think that kind of stay in line with this year, kind of the 3% area is what we have in our model. As it relates to -- there are a couple of boxes that we project will be coming back. One is already re-leased, the A.C. Moore box at Assembly Row, which effectively we proactively went after. It's still occupied and they'll vacate at the end of the year. That space will be vacant for most of 2017 until Trader Joe's takes a big chunk of it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Same with Bay Club here at Santana Row, which is being converted out and transferred to another use. It's going to be a very big positive, but it's going to come out in 2017. So, that process is, and I think, should continue. Net-net, you should see incre
componenttext: Same with Bay Club here at Santana Row, which is being converted out and transferred to another use. It's going to be a very big positive, but it's going to come out in 2017. So, that process is, and I think, should continue. Net-net, you should see increases overall, particularly as you get to the latter part of the year, though.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just to follow up on Jeff's question. You talked about slower growth -- expecting slower growth in residential rent at Phase 1 at Pike & Rose, but are you actually expecting there to be any roll-down of resi rent at Pallas or PerSei over th
componenttext: Okay. And then just to follow up on Jeff's question. You talked about slower growth -- expecting slower growth in residential rent at Phase 1 at Pike & Rose, but are you actually expecting there to be any roll-down of resi rent at Pallas or PerSei over the next year or so? And maybe you can give some color on how the retail and restaurants are performing in the midst of all the construction.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, we don't expect rents to roll down at Pallas and PerSei. In fact, one of the things that's been very clear is they continue to command a premium in the marketplace and that's a real important fact. We're not going to say -- I don't think we're go
componenttext: Yes. No, we don't expect rents to roll down at Pallas and PerSei. In fact, one of the things that's been very clear is they continue to command a premium in the marketplace and that's a real important fact. We're not going to say -- I don't think we're going to see the increases that I had hoped that we were going to see as the rest of the supply in the marketplace dissipated a little bit, given the construction that's underway. The construction has absolutely impacted the Phase 1 restaurants a little bit. The restaurants are doing fine, just not great. The retailers are not doing well until that second phase opens up. So, there is clearly softness throughout Pike & Rose. But it's funny, you've got both Milam and you've got Guglielmone who both live there and spend their time there. And every single time they come in and say, don't worry about it. We are cooking in terms of getting it right. Also, with respect to the construction and how that is moving along, we're moving along on time and on budget, which I'm really pleased about. So, the -- and when you look at who's coming here, REI is not adding new space. REI is relocating from 2 miles away or 1.5 miles away to a place that is a whole lot better in terms of what they believe their future customer is, the same with Porsche, the same with a number of the restaurants and retailers that we're talking about for Phase 2. So, what we are seeing, and that makes me really happy because it's not adding more retail supply into the marketplace, it's relocating the better tenants to a better product. That's what you should expect as we move forward. But we've got to get Phase 2 open.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on the disruption, I guess, at Pike & Rose. Why -- how come we keep hearing about the disruption there, but we don't necessarily hear about it at Assembly? What's unique to Pike & Rose where it's becoming more of an issue than it is at Assembly?
componenttext: Question on the disruption, I guess, at Pike & Rose. Why -- how come we keep hearing about the disruption there, but we don't necessarily hear about it at Assembly? What's unique to Pike & Rose where it's becoming more of an issue than it is at Assembly?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, for that. It's really clear, it's really easy to say. The market stinks compared to Assembly. So, you have construction phasing going on at Assembly, but you've got a very strong residential market to power right through to the extent that h
componenttext: Thanks, Mike, for that. It's really clear, it's really easy to say. The market stinks compared to Assembly. So, you have construction phasing going on at Assembly, but you've got a very strong residential market to power right through to the extent that human beings are coming in and deciding where they're going to live compared to what their supply choices are. At Pike & Rose Montgomery County, we don't have that luxury. There are other choices, there are other places, there are lower rent alternatives that you can take given the environment that's there. If you just think about that in so many different ways, when you have a strong market, some of the stuff that's happening out here in Silicon Valley, and we're having this call from Silicon Valley today, where [indiscernible] just blow me away. The things people will do and put up with when there is limited supply in the marketplace, it just doesn't matter. When there's a lot of choice in the market, it does.

componenttext: Got it, okay. And then for that second bucket where you're walking through for the 2017 bridge and you talked about the development and value-creation drag, how much of that $0.06 to $0.10 is really tied to the Miami kicking off those projects as opposed to Pike & Rose and Assembly?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a couple of cents in Miami. And we really kind of thought out should we put that in guidance, should we talk about that. But here's what's happening in Miami. Let's talk about that for a few minutes. The easier of the 2 to talk about is CocoWalk
componenttext: Yes, it's a couple of cents in Miami. And we really kind of thought out should we put that in guidance, should we talk about that. But here's what's happening in Miami. Let's talk about that for a few minutes. The easier of the 2 to talk about is CocoWalk. CocoWalk -- the dilution that would come from CocoWalk is part of a plan that would knock down part of the shopping center and effectively redevelop physically a big part of the shopping center. And obviously, from demolition cost to lost rents to disruption, obviously, that's dilutive. To the extent we can't get the numbers to work, and again, that will come through Investment Committee next year, we won't do that. But I did not want to not include that in guidance to the extent we can get to it. Over at Sunset, it's a different story. At Sunset, we have -- there is a broken property. We've known that from the beginning. We had some nice income and FFO from that property in the first couple of years that we had it. But obviously, that income stream is being reduced as the conversation of a redeveloped property becomes very clear and as tenants sit there and don't perform. So there, we know we've got at least another year of entitlement work to do to be able to get to what is a much more significant redevelopment. We're not -- the only impact in 2017 will be a slowly shrinking income stream over there. So, most of what we're talking about here is CocoWalk and a little bit of Sunset in '17.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Morgan with Canaccord.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going to the 700 Santana that you talked about 2019 opening and 2021 stabilization. Obviously, in the case of the Splunk site there, it was preleased. Could you give any kind of color about how you think about the tenancy for 700 Santana? How much yo
componenttext: Just going to the 700 Santana that you talked about 2019 opening and 2021 stabilization. Obviously, in the case of the Splunk site there, it was preleased. Could you give any kind of color about how you think about the tenancy for 700 Santana? How much you would look to pre-lease? How kind of chunky it might be?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, it's Jeff. So, remember on 500 Santana Row, we did not pre-lease that building. We started at spec and after construction was underway, we leased 100% of the building. So just want to make sure you understand that. But before I get into the specific
componenttext: Paul, it's Jeff. So, remember on 500 Santana Row, we did not pre-lease that building. We started at spec and after construction was underway, we leased 100% of the building. So just want to make sure you understand that. But before I get into the specifics on how we intend to approach the leasing of 700, let me tell you what 700 is. 500 Santana Row was adding an office building to Santana Row and a bunch of parking spaces that we can use nights and weekends. 700 is a lot more than that. With 700 Santana Row, we are capping off the end of Santana Row and really, for all intents and purposes, except for our last residential project over on the east side of the site, we're finishing Santana Row. So, 700 Santana Row is some 30,000 square feet or about that of additional retail and restaurant on the ground floor with a magnificent plaza in front of it that's really going to complete how Santana looks and feels. And it's a 1,300-space parking garage, which is going to significantly add to the parking pool at the end of the street and help us drive rents and sales for the south end of Santana Row. So, unlike 500 Santana, it's not just a spec office building. It is kind of a signature development that really caps off and finishes 700 Santana -- or finishes Santana Row. Now as it relates to the lease up of the office space, we are already out in the market. It's way early. We already have a couple of nibbles, which are exciting. But leasing really will kick off in earnest, like it does with every building in Silicon Valley, when there's actually a hole in the ground and construction activity and that's not going to be until sometime next year. As we get into the year and we start to do tours and field interest in the building, we'll be making a decision about whether we look to lease that building 100% to one tenant or whether we break it up. When we leased 500, we were very intent on leasing that building to one tenant. 700 we'll have to wait and see. I think there's a higher likelihood we can multi-tenant at 700, which is why you're seeing an extended stabilization period vis--vis building like 500.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing, Paul, I would add to that is that -- we had our board out here and Jeff and I have been talking about it ad nauseam is the requirement by tenants here, just like everywhere else in the country, to be in places that are fully amenitized and
componenttext: The only thing, Paul, I would add to that is that -- we had our board out here and Jeff and I have been talking about it ad nauseam is the requirement by tenants here, just like everywhere else in the country, to be in places that are fully amenitized and really environmentally friendly to what they are is huge. And the notion of finishing up the back parts looking straight down Santana Row has a whole lot of appeal to a whole lot of office developers and there's not other product that's -- that can be like that, which is what we heard from Splunk, which is why -- which by the way validates this in addition to AvalonBay having their West Coast headquarters here in addition to...

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Cushman & Wakefield.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cushman & Wakefield, the 300 Santana Row that's fully leased. So, this is becoming or has become a far more validated office location. Of all the possible places to put office at Santana Row, that's the best spot. So, with -- considering all of that, we d
componenttext: Cushman & Wakefield, the 300 Santana Row that's fully leased. So, this is becoming or has become a far more validated office location. Of all the possible places to put office at Santana Row, that's the best spot. So, with -- considering all of that, we decided to move forward.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So, if you look at the supply pipeline, Paul, in the market right now, there's really only one other sort of amenitized place where office tenants can go. And by the time we're leasing 700, that option may go away and we may be the only amenitized pl
componenttext: Yes. So, if you look at the supply pipeline, Paul, in the market right now, there's really only one other sort of amenitized place where office tenants can go. And by the time we're leasing 700, that option may go away and we may be the only amenitized place. But regardless, nobody has got the amenities we do, and like Don said, that's hugely, hugely important to all the companies, tech and non-tech, in this market to recruit and retain employees, so we're pretty bullish on it.

componenttext: Okay, I'll take a look. Just my other question then on -- going back to Pike & Rose, just bigger picture. If you kind of think about you've had a lot of the mixed-use projects. And some, kind of you've gone more all in. In Pike & Rose, you started more modestly and a lot of this is case-by-case and market-by-market. But in retrospect, as you look at Pike & Rose, would you have tried to structure Phase 1 a little bit differently or was it just an issue in terms of the residential market there and kind of you still think the phasing was right?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, hindsight, man, is a tough way to look at things. There's no question about it that if we've given everything I know, we would probably put the money that is in the residential building in Pallas on the retail street first. At least, I would've done
componenttext: Paul, hindsight, man, is a tough way to look at things. There's no question about it that if we've given everything I know, we would probably put the money that is in the residential building in Pallas on the retail street first. At least, I would've done that. We had some disagreement within the company whether that made sense because, at the time, we did what we did for a very good reason and that was the existing shopping center that was there, which we did not disturb during the initial phase. It was extremely productive and effectively allowed us to move some of the tenants from that shopping center into the new shopping center like La Madeleine. So, there were good reasons to do it, but it is important to have enough critical mass on the street to be able to create the environment. Now if the residential market had stayed as strong as it was, none of this would have mattered. And back to like Muellers questions before, the residential would have powered right through without the environment on the street fully created. But when you have the weakness in the marketplace, there's no question that the reliance on, or the health of the established retail street is a critical component. I don't know if that helps or not, but that's what happened.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttextpreview: Yes, looking at Pike & Rose, and I guess, Pallas specifically, how much value is embedded in the top floors versus the rest of the building? So, you may be 80% -- 86% leased, but how much of that -- of the top floors, that value, related to the rest of th
componenttext: Yes, looking at Pike & Rose, and I guess, Pallas specifically, how much value is embedded in the top floors versus the rest of the building? So, you may be 80% -- 86% leased, but how much of that -- of the top floors, that value, related to the rest of the building?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Craig. There's no question that the top floors and we've got, I don't know, 20 units -- 12 left to go -- 12 left to go up there. It is disproportionately higher. Those units have been slower going. That is part of the math and me f
componenttext: That's a good question, Craig. There's no question that the top floors and we've got, I don't know, 20 units -- 12 left to go -- 12 left to go up there. It is disproportionately higher. Those units have been slower going. That is part of the math and me feeling uncomfortable with the 7% number that was left there. So, you're on to an important part of it. Basically, the lower floors and the cheaper rent have more price sensitivity in a weaker market, effectively, than we had hoped. So, I can't do a percentage for you, but I will tell you that the preponderance of units left are in those upper floors and that does -- we don't believe we're going to get to the rents that we wanted to get to up there and particularly in the first roll or 2.

componenttext: Guys, I don't have that here, but the -- listen, man, you'll never get me to think differently on this. These projects are integral. They're integrated projects. The retail is critical to the resi, the office is critical to the retail, all the way around. So, we look at them as total projects. So, I don't have the pieces here. I expect we'll have it -- we can have it there for you in Phoenix, but you'll never get me to suggest that those things would be looked at separately.

componenttext: It's about half and half. In looking in total, you've got spaces there, a couple of 6, we're breaking them up, they're part of bigger redevelopment. So, it's not as pure and as clear as you'd like them there, but I'd say about half and half.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, we put a lot of thought into it. Just question for you. You guys have obviously spent a lot of time thinking about the redevelopment projects that you're rolling out. You have a lot that you've done over the years with the experience at Santana and As
componenttext: So, we put a lot of thought into it. Just question for you. You guys have obviously spent a lot of time thinking about the redevelopment projects that you're rolling out. You have a lot that you've done over the years with the experience at Santana and Assembly and others. And it sounds like the residential, like we understand that the residential Montgomery is more so that's pressuring the rents on the residential side, but can you just walk through why the retail would be pressured there? Is that purely because some of the retail that leases at the smaller spaces is sort of directly attributing to how the residential is going and then those are more amenity based and they're saying, hey, if the people aren't here, I'm not going to pay the rent? Or just help us walk through how those 2 are intertwined.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess what I would say -- and Chris is here. I don't know if he would -- I assume he'll add on to what I say. But the reality is today, and we've been talking about this for a while, retailers and this includes the boxes, this includes small peopl
componenttext: Well, I guess what I would say -- and Chris is here. I don't know if he would -- I assume he'll add on to what I say. But the reality is today, and we've been talking about this for a while, retailers and this includes the boxes, this includes small people -- the small shops, it includes really most categories, are a whole lot more cautious with their underwriting and they're a whole lot more -- the negotiations are more retail-centric than they are landlord-centric at the moment in a number of places. And when it comes to development, the ability to underwrite sales in a new development is less predictable. So, if the market is softer, and I do believe the market generally is softer from the standpoint of propensity to take risks and certainly in the Washington D.C. area, then you underwrite lower numbers. Lower numbers are lower rent, lower rent is a harder negotiation. It takes longer to do and it also includes the other terms associated with it. That's really what it's about from my perspective as I sit and see it. The other thing, and you see it up in Assembly to the other -- going the other way, when you've got a big sample size of first phase retail project there and that first phase is very successful, it makes a whole lot easier to lease that second phase. We don't have a big sample size in the first phase of Pike & Rose and that goes a little bit back to the question that was asked before, and accordingly, it's a tougher economics to negotiate here. Having said that, I just don't -- I don't want -- I can't overemphasize enough the fact that the anchor system in the second phase is done and is critical to the project. So even if rents are a little lower in the remaining small shop space, that is not a big cause for the differential in the yield.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add on exactly what Don said and I would just remind you, we've got 1 million feet on Rockville Pike. We need to make sure that we differentiate our projects. Pike & Rose is truly unique and authentic to anything else we own on Rockville
componenttext: Yes, I would just add on exactly what Don said and I would just remind you, we've got 1 million feet on Rockville Pike. We need to make sure that we differentiate our projects. Pike & Rose is truly unique and authentic to anything else we own on Rockville Pike. The fact that we're almost 80% leased on our retail on a Phase 2 GLA is fantastic. So just keep all of that in mind as you're talking it through. As we get more strength as the streets open. As the experience can be more of a full experience for the consumer, it's only going to get stronger.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, yes. No, look, you go to the site, you can see that. But I guess the question is, Don, from what -- when you guys talked about sort of at NAREIT and second quarter when you revised down the yield expectation till now and now they're being revised d
componenttext: Right, yes. No, look, you go to the site, you can see that. But I guess the question is, Don, from what -- when you guys talked about sort of at NAREIT and second quarter when you revised down the yield expectation till now and now they're being revised down, I guess, is it just that the market's been continued soft so therefore that's impacted the retail discussions more? And then the second part of that is for Dan G, should we expect then that with the delay through 2019 until stabilization, does that mean that this project weighs on earnings until then? Or there are other things in the company that will act as offset so it's not as though mentally we think about Pike & Rose weighing on the company through 2019, but it's that it takes longer to stabilize, but there are other positive offsets to that within the total organization?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Phase 2 -- the Phase 1, Phase 2 yield reductions are largely residential. Don't make a big deal about the retail, it's not that. Thats the answers to the first part of the question. The second part of the question is Pike & Rose is accretive to the
componenttext: The Phase 2 -- the Phase 1, Phase 2 yield reductions are largely residential. Don't make a big deal about the retail, it's not that. Thats the answers to the first part of the question. The second part of the question is Pike & Rose is accretive to the company. It is not weighing down the company. We're talking about a value-additive project here. And if you look year-over-year, I mean, they gave you the numbers of the income that has contributed from this project and that continues to go up. So, it's not that at all. And certainly, when coupled with the anchor lease-up, when coupled with the opening of Splunk and other development projects, when coupled with the redevelopments all the way through, that the total company continues. And as I started to say at the beginning of my remarks where our business plan is flat on right where we thought it was going to be in total over that long term. So, you clearly have a soft period of time here, and from an accounting perspective if you will, a cash flow perspective relative to value creation but not from a long-term value creation perspective.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one question in terms of kind of medium-term strategy. Once you look past the current projects, kind of what's your appetite to do further projects or take back certain anchor space that will cause near-term drag? I fully get the longer-term value cr
componenttext: Just one question in terms of kind of medium-term strategy. Once you look past the current projects, kind of what's your appetite to do further projects or take back certain anchor space that will cause near-term drag? I fully get the longer-term value creation here, but what's that appetite to reduce -- take more space back, things that'll cause that near-term drag to where, okay, '17 growth will be muted but then could do more projects, will then '18 will be muted as well because of these longer-term value-creation projects.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, it is such a great question and it so gets down to the balance of the business plan. The -- and I tried to address this in my remarks as best I could, the combination of all of the things including the decentralization, which is really working wel
componenttext: George, it is such a great question and it so gets down to the balance of the business plan. The -- and I tried to address this in my remarks as best I could, the combination of all of the things including the decentralization, which is really working well as it relates to getting to redevelopment and getting to focus, those things as you have pointed out are dilutive in the short term. There's a lot of it. There's no doubt about that. It's happening at the same time that 2 major development projects, Pike & Rose and Assembly Row, are coming up with their heavy construction phases, which are also dilutive. So all of those things happening at the same time has the balance move down to 4% growth rather than 6% growth or as they're coming out 8% or 9%. If we don't do any more, George, you're looking at 8% and 9% earnings growth. The notion of getting there, but not having additional future raw material doesn't excite me. So, I suspect what you will see is head down and executing what we have, a slowdown at the period of new raw material for new projects for the bulk of '17 to allow us to get back into balance. But this long-term business plan includes those initiatives as the way that we create value. So, you will see them. I'm not going to tell you every year you have to wait till next year, you have to wait for the year after that, you have to wait for the year after that for earnings because that's not fair to do and it's not what our anticipation is. You should see an acceleration in '18 you, should see an acceleration in '19 of the earnings growth rate.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then last question, Don. The development exposure at least as it relates to CIP is continuing to move higher as you guys put more money into projects that will deliver revenue down the road. Do you have a sense as to what peak CIP levels
componenttext: Okay, great. And then last question, Don. The development exposure at least as it relates to CIP is continuing to move higher as you guys put more money into projects that will deliver revenue down the road. Do you have a sense as to what peak CIP levels will be? And then when you think about how you manage risk, what are you comfortable with and how do you measure that risk as it relates to the amount of development that's in progress?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's a very fair question, Chris. And by the way, CIP at the end of the fourth quarter will be lower than CIP at the end of the third quarter as we put the Splunk building into service and that is, for all intents and purposes, a stabilized buildin
componenttext: Yes. That's a very fair question, Chris. And by the way, CIP at the end of the fourth quarter will be lower than CIP at the end of the third quarter as we put the Splunk building into service and that is, for all intents and purposes, a stabilized building. So, the notion that it will continue to always rise is not what you should be assuming. Basically, at the end of the day, 10% of the value of this company with respect to big development is what I feel comfortable with and not more than that. In fact, if you sit back and you take a look at -- take a look over the last 3 years, you'll see that we peaked higher than we are today a couple of years ago. Remember the year was '13? When effectively we had all the Phase 1s that were not yet in service, but going and so youre seeing this heavy construction in the Phase 2s right now. Those things as they are put into service will reduce the CIP and I don't think -- I think the way you should look at it is debt-to-EBITDA coverage, which we're very comfortable with in the low to mid-5, fixed charge coverage that's through the roof. It's kind of why we prefunded a bunch of this development in the form of reducing our leverage in the company, terming out for 30 years is what we've got. But on broad basis, Chris, look at 10% of the enterprise value as kind of our rough estimate of the math. It's really much more limited by our debt coverage though and our fixed charge coverage and what we placed into service.
